TRANSLATION. 
(Verse 1.) Homage to Sambhu, beauteous with the yal-tail fan that is the moon kissing his lofty head, the foundation-column for the structure of the city of the triple world, 
(Triges 2-5) While the victorious reign of-haill the refuge of the whole world, darling of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, sapreme Lord, supreme Master, ornament of Satyasraya's race, embellishment of the Chalukyas, king Tribhuvanamalla, vas advancing in a coure of saccogsively increasing prosperity, to endure) as long as moon, sun, anl stars ; --one who finds Bustenance at his lotus-feet 
(Verse 2.) As the sovereign, saying that "he 18 the leader in battle and likewise a perfect counsellor anong the most capable of fitting and reliable deliberations, there are no others (equal to him)," thas graciously has aggrandised him, and, being pleased at his conduct, abundantly praises him, hence the blest General Bhima alone among generals is addressed with jāua and bappu.? 
(Lines 8-15,) Hail! while the maha-samantadhipati who has obtained the five great musical sounds, great august General, bestower of desirable rewards apor cultured and agreeable persons, man of might according to his word, sun to the park of the lotuses of nobility, ornament on the face of the province of Kashmir, decapitator of traitors against his lord, bee to king Tribhuvanamalla's lotus-feet, exalted in bravery, High. Minister, president of the intendants, steward of the household, provincials registrar, the General Bhivaneyye, was administering 
S 
. 
Road -Darsha 
2 Words expressing high approval and admiration. On the forma partafe pt. Narendra inscra. BYol. XIII, p. 825, D. $. 
No. 8.] 
THREE INSCRIPTIONS OF LAKSHMESHWAR 
35 
WHEY 
WILL 
- 
the Palasige Twelve-thousand and the achchre-pannāya of the Seven-and-a-half Lakh Country one who finds sustenance at his lotas-feet 
(Verse 3.) A Mēru in pride, distinguished by bounty, a Dharmarāja's son Yudhisl.thirs 1. in righteousness, a unique King of Celestials (Indra) in magnificeuce, endowed with the excel lences of the powers of lord, counsel, and enterprise 
(Verse 4.) With affection of spirit the congregations of sages naine the General Madhava, on the occasion of his trampling down and slaying those who confront him in battle, a Spirit of Doom of the time of dissolution ; on the occasion of his making gifts to impoverished futurs, a walking Tree of Desire ; on the occasion of his giving protection when men come and pray for refuge, a solid adamantine hoase. 
(Verse 5.) By generating Madhava, who is the best of onges, who follows the conise of Manu, the Creator made atonement for beving created other inferior inen of reprobate ch racter 
(Verse 6.) lo mercy, righteousness, power, magnifcence, profundity, firmness, policy, pleasing conduct, courtesy, skill, valour, regular practice of duty, excelleuce, (ani) knowledge of many arts, Madhava has become exceedingly exalted on earth, a lord of the goddess of splendid fame. 
(Lines 25-31.) Haill he who possesses all titles of honour such as "he who is adorned with all positive virtues, illustrious in the office of High Minister, exalted in dignity, endowed with the three powers of lord, coon-el, and enterprise, giacions to sages, a charming Brabn a in appreciation of sentiments of skilful poetry, a lion to the great elephants proud fremen, a full moon of the autumual season to the ocean of his kindred, a jewel-mine of nobility, a bee to the lotus-feet of Bhavaal's Lord [Sival, lofty in valour," the High Minister, Controller of the achch24-parnya, (and) General Madhava-Bhatta 
(Laves 31-33.) Hail! on Sunday, the 5th of the bright fortnight of Ashadha in the cyclic year Chitrabhānu, the 27th (year) of the Châlukya-Vikrama era, during a ryatipāta, 
(Lines 33.43 ) The General Madhava-Bhatte, while happily administering the achcut pannyit, for the personal enjoyinent of the god Svayambhu-Somēśvara (and) the god Nudds śvara of the capital city Purigere, presented to the gods, with laving of the feet of Mahendra soma Pandita, prior of the local establishment, and with pouring of water, the pannaya tax (collouted) wherever tennnts of estates selling betel-leaf within the 48,000 muttar of the lands of Parigore bring the leaf) in loads conveyed either on shoulder-poles (?) or in head-loads, likewise the panzaya on betel-leaf sold in Puiigere, likewise a total of 530 leaves on each load and 300 on euch head-lord sold there after deduction of the tax, together with tenants' tay and fines for offences. So the governors administering the pannaya shall maintain this pious ondowment. 
(Lines 43-46 a prose formula of the usual type.) (Verres 7-9: common Sangkrit veises.) (Verse 10 : a Kavarese commonitory stanza.)

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL. XVI. 
vediment remains; and on this the only sculptures visible are a liviga on a stand with & squatting ball to the proper right. The text below this is contained in three compartinents, all of them about 2 ft. wide. The first of these, comprising II 1-5, 18 about 4* in. high; the second, ll. 6-68, some 4 ft. 3 in, high; and the third, ll. 69-70, about 2 in. bigh. The character is the fair Kaparese of the middle of the twelfth century, with letters varying in height from me in. to min.--Apart from the Saoskrit stanzas Nos. 1, 2, 15, and 26, the language is Old Kanarest. The ancient ? has been changed to r in kurit= (1 10) aud rogard daria (1. 42), and elsewhere to b. The upadhmaniya appears in -payahpūru. (l. 25) und Vüchappati (1. 54) P is changed to lo only in the Dames Turlaha (1l. 22, 32, 48, 50, 58) and Hānu igall= (11. 65-6; elsewhere Panungallu). Among the words of lexical interest we may notice Chaluku (1. 5), jagadalu (1. 6), nirvvadhe (1. 15), kamdar usti (1. 27), kanuna y su (1 27), ullēkha in the sense of high flashing” (1. 57), gadduge (1. 58), and kandarane, "carving” (1. 70). 
The record chronicles three endowments, and was redacted in its present form on the occa sion of the last of these. The first part, after a prelude (vv. I--), opens with a series of stao zas (11. 6-10) praising in succession Permădı-Rā[ja], by whom Vikramāditya VI seems to be meant (v. 5), Tailapa (ie. Abavamalla Nurmadı Taila II), Satyäśraya, and Vikrama, i.e. Vikramaditya VI (v. 6); and Vikramaditya's successes over the Cholas, Nēpālas, and Gürjaras are glorifed (v. 7). Then comes the formulæ referring the grant to Vikramăditya's Teiga (1l 10-12), followed by verses giving the lineage of bis feudatory the Kādamba Mahã-Mandalesvaia Taila (II) or Tailaba-dēvarasa of Hängal (11. 12-17). He was the son of Santa (Santivarman) and Sriya-dēvi; aud Suuta had four brothers, named Taila [I], Māvuli, Choki, uod Bikki (1.e. Vikiana). After this comes de piose passage giving to Tailaha all the standing titles of his family and referriug the grant to his reigu (11. 17-24). Then we have some verses in praise of the town of Purikara, le Lakslimuöslwar (1) Mahá-syayambhu-Somanátha, or Dakshina-Soma, "the Somnath of the South” (ll. 26-28), and the prior of that establishment, Mahindrasoma Pandita-dēvas (II. 28-30); and then comes au interesting prose paragraph (11. 30-34) ielating how the latter paid a visit to the Mala-Mandalesvara Tailaba-dēva (the above-mentioned Kādamba Tarla II) ut Pánungallu, find gave him his blessing and gift of the Saiva eucharist, in return for which he received from Tailaha the gift of the town of Kallavana for the maintenance of hus temple (ll. 34-38). A formal ending of the usual kind then brings the first section to a conclusion (II. 38-40). 
The second part then opens with a verse in praise of the Chāļukya Taila II, who in allusioni to his title Nürmadr-Tarla, "a hundred times a Taila," is bere called Irmadz-padirmade-1ūrmadi Taila, "twice, twelve times, a huudred times a Taila" (11. 41-42), and it then formally refers itself to his reiga (11. 12-). We are then introduced in three verses to another Kādamba prince, Māvuli-Taila, also called Tailaha-dēva and simply Taila, a grandson of the above mentioned Tailaha II, bo was raigping at Nareyangallu (11. 11-18), and Sonanātha (l. 48-49). He had a feudatory, the dlabā. Mandalēśvara Vira Pāņdya, who at the time was holding the manneyų or seigniory of the Puligere rad (11. 19-51), while the General Mahādēvarasa was governing the same district and the Banavābe country in the office of 
* Cf. the phrase in a Sogal inscription, l 11-12, snanam măduvargge gaddngeya nīram. It seems to ho the same as the Kashmiri gordur, * aspersion," - Coremonial spriukling." 
2 Ou this pedigree see Dyn. Kanür. Desti, PP 559 sqq. 
3 Awong other titles he is described as Dafavaoma-raza-nyukta (1 29), *einployed in the araja 03 Dasavarm21.* Properly praga means & cattle-atall; bere peilaus at siguifies t royal court. Who Daśasaruan Was is a mystery. 
* On Milch-Pandya, who also appears as ruling at this time in Uchchangi-durga over Yol&inbavadi, see Dyn Kaxar. Distr., pp. 456, 458, PSOCI, Nos 116, 117, 139, Mysore Inse). Voc. 8, 9, 3, 301, 30Ho sus Taller ut Vijaya Pandjie 
No. 8.] 
THREE INSCRIPTIONS OF LAKSHMESHWAR 
mēl-ülke (11. 51-52), and the Generals Biddarasa and Attirāja (or Attiparaja) were administering the Puligere nad under the orders of Mahāděvaras (11 52-55). The record then relates in prose that Māvuli-Tailaha after a visit to the temple at Puligere confirmed his grandfather's gift of Kallayana, with some further provisions, the trustee being Jžānasoma Pandita-dēva (11. 56-64). 
The final section (11. 64-70) records.& sapplementary grant, by which Dakarasa, general 10 command of the Hanungallu Five-hundred, in concert with the controllers of the treasury, assigned one pana from every town and village in his district for the supply of lamps in the same temple, and brings the inscription to an end by a series of -verses from which we learn that Jñanasõma, the prior of the temple, was the son of the above-mentioned Mahõndrasoma and Maliyakka, and that the engraver was Räjõja, son of Jinnöja and younger brother of Chova. 
The date of the first grant is given an II. 34-35 as the 92nd year of the Chafuky Vikrama era, Sarvajit; Pushya suddha 13, Sunday, the uttarayana-sankranti , & vyatipata. These details are discrepant. The trthr mentioned corresponded to Sunday, 29 December, A D. 1107, and ended about 18 h 37 m. after mean sunrise (for Ujjain), but the uttarayana-sankranti of that year took place about 6.50 A M. on Wednesday, 28 December Mr. Sewell informa me that according to the Srddhanta-8romani the tithi was 20 December, but the uttarayana sariikränté occurred on Tuesday, 24 December, at I h. 5 m, 20 8. after mean sunrise. 
The second grant is dated on Il. 59-60 28 the 3rd year of Trailökyamalla, Angiras ; Pushya suddha 8, Monday ; the uttarayana-bankranti ; #vyatipāta. This is quite irregular. 
zestion corresponded to Saturday, 6 December, AD: 1152, ending about 10 h. 38 m. after mean sunrise. On the other hand, the uttarayana-sankranti occurred on Wednesday, 24 December 
The third grant bears as date the 4th year of Trailokyamallah, Srimukha; Chaitra Amavasya, a Monday (IL 64-65) This again is wrong, for the given tétht was current on Thursday, 26 March, AD 1153, ending about 21 h. 24 m. after mean sunrise. 
The geographical names mentioned are Pumkar& town (II. 3, 26) and province (l. 51), and their synonyms, Puligere town (1 57) and province (11. 50, 52); the Cholas, Nēpālas, and Gür jaras (1, 9); Banavāsi town (11. 12, 17), and its synonym Jayantīl (11, 13, 18, 45); Banavano province (1. 51); the Pānungallu or Hānungallu Five-hundred (Il. 22, 35, 68, 65-6), the wole-utdu or standing camp of Pānungallu (IL. 23, 32); the Kundavure Thirty (1. 36); Kallavana (11. 36, 59, 61); the tirthas (1. 39); and the nels-vidu of Nareyangallu (11, 46, 63). On Purikara or Puligere see above, p 31. Pānungallu or Hānungalla is now Hängal, and Nareyaogallu Narēgal. Kundavara is possibly the same as Kuqdär, the modern Naröndra, og pbich soe above, Vol. XII, p. 298. Kalla vapa I am quable to identify.

THREE INSCRIPTIONS OF LAKSHMESHWAR.

TRANSLATION. 
(Verse 1.) Victorious ever is he who is composed of accumulated bliss, of knowledge, and of power, from whose mere will arose all the worlds 
(Verse 2: identical with verse 1 of inscr. A. above 
(Verse 3.) May (the god Sömanātha of] the South, who is kuown as Abhava [siva], embellishing the fortune of the blest city Parikara, causing weal in both spheres of existence, [bless] the worshippers of his feet 
(Verse 4) Nandı, the Mountain's Daughter, the diadem moon, the tall pile of braided locks, all this the excellent Svayambhu [bestowed upon] the poble (scrons) of the Chaluki lineage 1 
(Verse 5 ) An ordament of the blest Chalukya lineage, a jagadala against hostile kings, an embellishment of the whole earth, incomparable in majesty, is king Permāņı... 
(Verse 6 ) Like the ocean perfectly protecting numbers of families of kubhrit kings, or mountains] who came to him for refuge, king Tailapa ruled the earth, then king Satyāśraya, 
theu] the blest king Vikrama most lofty in dignity, a frontal decoration of the lady [the. .. Chaļukya] lineage. 
(Verse 7.) Swiftly (?). ..by his boldness having driven to fight the Chola, by his strokes the incomparable king Vikramāditya overwhelmingly crushed the Nēpāla mouarch, burned the Gürjara sovereign's brilliant city (so that it was .] lustreless (?) smoke, in indignation tore up and flang away the roots of banded sovereigas. 
(Lines 10-12.) While the (victorious ] reign of .. % king Tribhuvanamalla was advancing in a course of successively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars :-One who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet 
(Verse 8) [Ruler of the city (?) of] Banavāsī, devoted to the worship of the universally adored lotus-feet of Madhukēša the lord of the faultless city of Jayanti, eager for mighty battle. is Taila. 
(Verse 9.) His father was king Sânta, skilled in shattering . . . ; his mother forsooth was the latter's chief queen Sriya-dēvi, perfect in righteousnes ; the group of princes consisting of king Taila, Māvuli, Choki, and Bikki are rich in fame : what righteousness is that of the blest prince Taila, who has worthy ancles and father's 
(Verse 10.) Reigning undisturbedly like Bali over his country, being known as a true hero, one who 18 stained with the red hue of the bright minium lying thick upon the temples of the elephants of the sky-quarters, mighty of splendour, the Kadamba lion who shatters proud foes bas marie the circle of earth free from obstruction, so that many praise him 
(Lines 17-24.) Hail ! the Mahă-Mandalēśyara who has obtained the five great musical sounds, who has all the titles of honour such as ' lord of Banavāsī best of cities; receiving the grace of boons from the god Madhakośvara of Jayanti ; naturally scented with mask ; ornament of the race of the Kādamba emperor the great king Mayūravarman, which is sprung from the Three-eyed [Siva] and Earth, presides over eighty-four towns, is consecrated in the consecratory rites of eighteen World-renowned horse-sacrifices to the (God of the) Frontal Eye [Siva] and the Four-armed (Vishnu), binds its furious elephants to great crystal pillars crowning the massive peaks of the lord of mountains Himayat, and is delightful in its great majesty , he who is attended by the noise of permaţti drums and 
i [It looksjas if the verse meant to say that Svayambha with Nandı etc. might confer blessing on the Chalaki lineage - H. K. S.] 
Sapply the usual Chalukya formula, as above, insor A., 1 2 ff * [Kaniya-janakar is ancles, not uncles and father, _H, K. S.]

(other) musical instrunents, brilliant with a banner (having the device) of a great ape; having as crest a lion lofty in pnde , bestowing gold on the needy; causing victory in strife ; ornainent of the Kadambas; man of might against adversaries," the Maha-Mandalēśyara Tailahe dēvarasa, while royally controlling with the internal authority of the tribhõgal the Five hundred of Panungallu so as to suppress the wicked and protect the superior, being in the enjoyment of pleasant conversations at the standing camp of Pānungallu : 
(Verse 11 ) To speak of all the hillocks, the crowd of temples, all the lines of valleys, the lotus-pools in the waters filling the maltitude of brilliant ponds, likewise all the earth adorned therewith, the bright parks of sandal-treesYerily the aspect of Purikara town is a charming sigut for the world.? 
(Line 26 ) There, moreover : 
(Verse 12 ) In the joyous offering of consecrated rice-grains one after another & kolagas is filled ap*; heace I know not how to celebrate (fittingly) the magnitude of the famous eminence of the Phallos of Siva. 
(Verse 13.) The Self-born assumed a unique natural form made without turning of the lathe, without graving, without separation, without craftsmanship; Sõma of the south there condescended to burst forth out of the ground. 
(Lines 28-29) The Prior of the establishment of the god Maha-avayambhu-dömanāths, who has thus been described : 
(Verse 14.) There flourished a seat of pions observances, a treo of desire to the lineage of all great ascetics, a servant in Daśavarman's court (?), the cleric Mahēndrasoma Pandita dēva. 
(Lines 30-38.) So Mahendrasoma Pandita-dēva, most reverend in devotion to calmness, self-control, the major and the minor disciplines, having taken unguents of saffron and bland sandal and fragrant scents prepared for [that decorated.-H, K. S.] the worship of the divinely bles feet of the most noble god Somanåtba, and likewise rice-grains left over from his sacred meal [grece.-H. K. S.], went to Panungallu and pronounced a blessing upon the Maha Mandalesvara king Tailaha, who, realising with extreme joy the singular qualities of both the establishment and the deity, said “Let us give to the god. Somanátha for his personal enjoyment a town in oar province," and having thus reflected, in concert with the treasurers. ministers, and generals, on a holy lunar day on which Sunday, the 13th of the bright fortnight of Pushya in the cyclic year Sarvajit, the 32nd of the Chalukya-Vikrama era, occurred together with the uttarayana-samkrānti and & oyatipato, laved the feet of Mahēndrasoma Pandita and with pouring of water granted as an imperial gift, together with a copper-plate charter, the town Kallavand in the Kundapura Thirty, a county of the Five-hundred of Pānungallu, for the personal enjoyment of the god Səmanāthau, in perpetuity for as long as moon and son endure, on sarva-namasya tenure with immunity from all conflicting claims, 
(Verse 15 : A common Sanskrit formula.) (Verse 16 : a similar Kanarese stanza.) (Line 40.) For them that preserve (this foundation), fruit of endless merit,

(Verse 17.) There has becomo eminent a brilliant sun bringing to bloom the lotuses of the fair Chalukya lineage, a lord of the whole circle of earth, king Irmadı-Padirmadi-Nürmadi Taila, on whose broad breast appears the lady Fortune, on wbose arm (appears) the noble lady Victory, to whom the lady Earth is an amoi ons leman 
(Lives 12-15 ) While the victorious reign of . . king Trailokyamalla was ad vancug in a course of successively inci casing prosperity, (to endue) as long as moon, sun, and star:-One who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet 
(Verse 18 ) Māvull-Tala, the Viceroy beloved of Earth, whose origin derives from the Kādımba race, (and) to whom arises grace of boons from the god Madhukëśvara of Jayanti, 
(Verse 19.) thinking of (lis) possession, to wit the standing camp of Nareyangal, (las) subjects, the band of (luis) friends, the elders, the senior treasurers, the excellent ministers, has been solicitous to strengthen (then) 
(Verse 20 ) Standing in the line of succession and holding the royal rank, devoted to right eousness, kıvg Taila has sought tor unending bliss in the next world--oh, what is design!- and become & vessel of holinesg} 
(Lines 48-49 ) So after having for several years adorned the fortunes of that realm, the Kādamba lion king Tailaha, being in the glory of the festival of visitation of the god 
Somanātba 
(Verse 21.) The lady Victory, accomplishing the vow of the sword-edge, and the goddess of Speech, surpassing the point of an arrow,5 have come and displayed themselves (respectrurly) upon the ar'ın and in the mouth of king Vira-Pāndya 
(Lines 50-51 ) While this labā- Mandalëśvara was royally administering the seigniory of the Puligere county *-- 
(Verse 22 ) The General Mahādēvarasa, most irresistible in valour, was administering the land of Purikara aud the land of most beauteous Banaväse in perpetual superior control 
(Lines 52-53 ) Under the command of this qugust General, the General Biddaraga and the noble High Minister Attirāja were administering the county of Puligere As regards their digaitymo 
(Verse 23.) In (his) greatness in speaking not two (things), in turning not his back on the field of battle, (and) in holding not amorous sport with others' wives, when one considers, who is equal to the General Biddarāja? 
(Verse 21.) As he is known as a Vāchaspati (Brahman] of sweet speech, a possessor of moon-bright glory, an ocean of policy according to the famous six qualities, are there others equal (to thee), senior General Attiparaja ? 
(Lines 56-64.) The Maha-Mandaleśvara king Māvuli-Tarlaba, having come to the capital town Puligere in order to spend the festival of visitation of the god Sömanātha, purified his body in the stream of the high-flashing Celestial River consisting of the rays from the god Soma's toe-nails, and gave a thousand aspersions with streams of milk and water; and, renew.

(Lines 61-66 ) On Monday, the last day of Chaitra in the cyclic year Srīmukha, the 4th of the Chalukya Trailokyamalla's (negnal) years, Dākarasa, General (2n charge) of the Five-hundred of Hānungallu, and the treasurers granted for the regular perpetual lamps of the god Sömanātha one pana from each of the villages and hamlets of the Five-bundred of Hānungallu. 
(Verse 25.) The (god) worshipped by him is Soma the Lord of Gods, sovereign of the triple world, praised by sages [01, celestials] ; his good father is Mahēndrasoma; his mother is Māļıyakkarenowned for her conduct, adorned by refinement: how fortunate is this Jõānasõna, a fall moon (soma) to the ocean of all yırtues, a . . ample brilliant moon to the lotuses the lineage of holy men

7 
C.-OF THE REIGN OF JAGADEKAMALLA II: THE 10TH YEAR This is on a slab with a rounded top containing sculptures, namely a linga on a stand in the centre, with a squatting bull to the proper right and a cow suckling a calf to the proper left; apparently there is a scimitar over the latter, and on the top are the sun (on proper right) and moon (on left). The inscribed area below this pediment consists of three parts The first (containing lines 1-2 of text) is about 1 ft 71 in wide and 2 in high; the second (lines 
7) is about I ft 10 in, wide and 1 ft 3 in high, the third (lines 18 to end) is of about the same width and 3 ft ll in high.-The character is a very good Kanarese of the period. The average height of the letters in the first half of the inscription is about in, after this they begin to decrease, and towards the end average only about in.--The language is Old Kanarese, with formal Sanskrit verses (Nos 1, 32) and a Sanskrit phrase (Il 60-61). It is not certain whether the avagraha denotes, as in pare Sanskrit, a completely vowelless consonant, or whether the powel 24 was inserted there, the spelling of dyaduyaso-rjjrtan in 1 20, where the second d is written with avagraha and is followed by ya, saggests that the d represents du. The u padirmaniya is used in Brihnhpati (1 56). The archaic l appears as ? in regardan (1. 4); elsewhere it h89 become / The treatment of initial p in Kanarese words is inconsistent: in verse it usuully remains, yet we find hore (1 13), Timngedud= (l. 13), hāl (1. 48), hon (1 48), and in prose we have pannero (126), Priligere (11 50, 64), padedri (11 52, 55), beside hattare (1 52), holao (11. 53, 58, 60), hala (11 58-9), horeya (1 59), and halla" (1.59) The archaic ending of avon (1. 37) is noteworthy. As lexically interesting we may notice stambēra (1. 20). apparontly formed metru gratia as a variant of the regular stambērama by the analogy of ga 
* On this point see my remarks on the Mädagihál inscription, above, Vol. XV, p. 318. 
No. 8] 
THREE INSCRIPTIONS OF LAKSHJESHVAR.

. 
beside "gama ; hêraga (l. 21), a fora throwing some light upon the meaning of the official title lueri-sandhz-v2g7 ani, which hence would seem to mean a minister in charge of the secret intelli gence-department of foreign policy (cf. Kittel, s.v. hēriya); and kandarane, “carying " (1. 64) 
The record, after invocation of Siya, begins with a short metrical genealogy of the Western Chalukyas from Tailapa (19. Tarla II) to the reigning sovereign, Jagadēkamalla [II], whom it duly glorifies (ll. 2-15) It then refers itself in formal prose to the latter's leign (1l. 15-17), and devotes four stanzas (11 18-21) to the laudation of his minister Készrāja, also called Keśavadēva, Kēsimayya and Jayakéside-yarasa in 1 J1, a distinguished general who had defeated the Cholas, Līlas, and Gurjaras, and who was also a minister of foreign affairs, an officer of the treasury, and an administiator of the royal seraglio ; we next learn from thie prose of 11. 21-27 that he was at this time administering the Belvala Three-bundred, the Huligere Three-hundred, the Halasige Twelve-thousand, and the Hāpumgallu Five hundred. A series of 10 reuses (Il 27-39) then introduces us to the following pedigree of generals : 
Āditya-Bhatta Mēlamayya 
Drönáchārya, m. Chamala-dēvi 
Āchiraja or 
Mēcba, Mechi, Mēcharasa, Mēcbiraja or Mēcbana 
Kanchi Achar988 
212 Vennala-dēvi and Laliya-dēvi Four further verses (11. 39-44) bring us to the province of Purikara (ie Puligere or Huligere), now beiug ruled by a certain Jayakēśi-dēva, of the Manala? family, and its capital, of the same name, with its sanctuary of Vaba-Svayambhu-Somanātha, of which the prior (ãohārya) was Jõānasõna Pandits-dēva, the son of Mahendrasāma, the son of Dāvasoma. After a verse in praise of “Kāšava the minister of king Sõmēśvara," who must be the pre viously mentioned general Kēsimayya, and Jagadēkamalla's father Bhülőkamalla-Sūmēsvara III (11 4-15), and another in honor of Jõanasona (11. 15-17), we learn from two stanzas (11 47-49) that Mâcherasa set up a golden finial (kalasu) upon this temple, and gave for this purpose 100 mattar of land in Kunduravalli. The details and date of this gift, for which Iñānasoma was trustee, are theu specified in prose (il 49-61), and another verse adds some further details (11 61-62) The Wurds Kurnnata-suavi-mukhya-pandutara (1 6+), which I have translated as “ of an eminent scholar among Kanarese master-poets" may equally be taken as a proper naine, the noir de plume of the author of the inscription. The engrayer was Chavõja, son of Jinnöja of Puligere (ib.), on whon see above, inscription B., 1. 70 
The date is given on ll. 56-57 as the 10th year of the reign of Jagadēkamalla, the cyclic year Prabhava, Ashādha suddha 12; Thursday, the dakshinayana-samkranti; ai vyatipātu. This is irregular. The givea title corresponded actually to Thursday, 12 June, A.D. 1147, on which it ended 17 h. after mean suprise (for Ujjain) But the dukshinīyand-sainkranti, or Karka-sankrantı, took place, according to the Arya-srdellinta, exactly a fortnight later, on 
Thursday, 26 June, 15 h 51 m. after mean sunrise, and Mr R. Sewell has pointed out to me that by the Siddhanta-ścromani, and probably by the Bialnia-siddhinta also, it was due ou Wednesday, 25 June, about 14 h. after mean suprise. 
The geographical names mentioned are: the Beluvala Three-hundred (11 25-6); the Huligero Three-hundred (1. 26), or Puligere nad (1 50), sanskritised as Purikara (1. 39), the town of Huligere (1 53), or Puligers (1. 61), or Purikara (ll. 40, 45 f.); the Halasige 
1 See Dyn Kanar, Distr., p 4.58. 
2 This is the same as the Manalēra family, ou which sec above, Vol V1, p 52, and Mysore Archæol Report, 1908-9, p. 16. An ancestor of this official, also named Jayakžai, figures in a Hulgui inscription of Sala 960, 
8 Sue above, inscriptions A, and B,EPIGRAPHIA INDICA.

Twelve-thousand (1. 26); the Hānungallu Five-hundred (1. 26), Kuntala ( 39), Ekkalavāda (1. 19); Kunduravalli (11 49, 51-53); Ittage (11. 53, 58 f.); Nittür (1). 53, 60); Kanterike (l. 59); Benakana kola, “ Bauaka's Lake” (1 60); the tirthas (1. 63); and vamous nations (11. 7, 18, 22-3). Beluvala (Belvala) and Huligere are well known; and Huligere town is the modern Lakshmēshwar. Halasige is Halsi. Hānuðgallu is the modern Hāngal. Ekkalavāda 18 the name of the district in which lay Kunduravalli; and the latter may be identified with the village styled " Kunderballi” in the Postai Directory, “Koondurwullee" on the Indian Atlas, sheet 41, and “Kudravlı" on the Bombay Survey, sheet 334, which lies in lat. 15° 8', long 75° 36', about 5 miles ENE. from Lakshmēshwar Nittür ("Neetoor" on the Indian Atlas) lies in lat. 15° 91, long. 750 345.

THREE INSCRIPTIONS OF LAKSHMESHWAR.

mattarıma Siva-pada-śökharan 
[31*] Sva-dattāri para-dattam vā yo haréta vasu(s)m 63 dharām [*] Ba(shashtin varsha-sahasrani vishthāyān jāyatë krimih 1 [32*1 
Gamgå-sägara-Yamuna-sangamadolu köti kavileyan brahmanaram limgigalam 
sale punya-dinamgalo 64 l=alidavargal-apparuiratuidan=alidar 
533*1 Srimat-Karnnāta-sukavi.mukhya. panditara kavite Küvāri-chakravartti Puligereya Jinnöjara agra-gatam Chāvôjana kandarane 
TRANSLATION. (Verse 1 : identical with v. 1 of inscr A.) 
(Verse 2.) There flourished a morning-sun to the lotus-lake the blest beauteous Chalukya lineage, a grim elephant to the coppices of young plantains (consisting of) countless froward enemy kings, a lord of earth whose pair of lotas-feet was rubbed by the gems of angust obeisant monarchs' diadems, au eager wooer of the goddess of universal victory, Tailapa. 
(Verse 3.) His son was Satyāšraya, embellishment of the Chalukyan. A son of the latter moparch's younger brother was king Vikrama, (likewise) the excellent Ayyana (and) Jayasimha the wooer of the goddess of glory. The last-named king's son was Ahavamalla, victor in battle, mainstay of empire; that king's son was the lord of earth Sonēšvara. 
(Verse 4.) That king's younger brother, the valiant king Permādi, & consuming fire to the forest of the-froes of the Cholas, breaking down the acacias in the marshes of the Gürjera kings, ruled this land. 
(Verse 5) Haughty with his might of arm, king Vikramaditya reduced his foes to the condition of a village of Bbillas, giving them severally splendours with drums consisting of skipping crickets, with bands of bright singers ronsisting of thickets of roeds, with royal stools consisting of the ground, with lamps composed of gems in the hoods of serpents, with gay robes of snakes' slonghs. 
(Verse 6.) This sovereign's son Bhūlókamalla became distinguished, acquiring the crole of space, having a radiance of glory like moonbeama, unfathomable of majesty, wrestler against the proud. 
(Verse 7.) His son is a storm-blast upon the lamps hostile kings, a lion to the furious elephants hostile princes : who are there that do not thus speak of the Emperor Jagadēka. malla ? 
(Verse 8) The pain of the Tortoine's hard carapace has stopped ; the load on the Serpent king's splendidly jewelled head has diminished; the burden on the neck of the elephants of the sky-quarters bas abated : this is because Jagadekamalla bears without labour the realm of earth upon the puissant place of firmness, his own arm. 
(Lines 15-17.) While the victorious reign of . , 2 the majestic Emperor king Jagad. ēkamalla was advancing in a course of sucoessively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars 
(Verse 9.) A bee to his lotus-feet, righteous in conduct, having counsels skilful in shatter. ing tbe Chola, Lala, and Gürjara monarchs, a true hero is the General Käsirāja. 
(Verse 10 ) Having an picious characteristics [or, characteristics of a high-bred elephant in constant embellishment, born of a noble family for, berd], abondant in boanty [or, rut-ichor

Winning high fame through receiving the embraces of the beloved elephant-cow of Lakshmi he is a bull-elephant of victory for the exalted Jagadēkamalla: through this high distinction the General Kēsirāją of the Elephants has gotten this appropriate name. 
(Verse 11.) Kēšavadēva is (in charge) of rat-raging elephants, of squadrons of horse of the high office of the ministry of) peace and war for the secret service (?) and Lālas, (and) of tbe treasury, a controller of the prosperous seraglio. 
(Verse 12.) “This forsooth is a troop of noble horses sent by the Malava " * (thi column of fiery elephants sent by the king of Kalinga "_" (this is) a diadem of various gems sont as tribute in terror by the Cholikas' monarch "%: as each of them with these words bronght (these things) and laid them down before him, Kašava overspread with his glory earth, ocean, mountains, and sky. 
(Lines 21-27.) Hail' while he who posseases all titles of honour, high minister, master of the stables of elephants and horses, treasurer, general supervisor, minister for peace and war for the secret service () and the Lālas, favourite, head of the army, the great august General Késznayya, was reigning: in government of the Beluvala Three-bundred, the Huligere Three-hundred, the Halasige Twelve-thousand, and the Hānumgallu Five-hundred so as to suppress the wicked and protect the cultured : 
(Verse 13) A bee to his lotus-feet, talented, a wind potent to aproot the trees haughty foemen, Fenerated by the good, is the General Méchiraja. 
(Line 28.) As regards the dignity of this noble man's lineage : 
(Verse 14 ) His maternal grandfather was the illustrious General Mēlamayya, renowned for Firtdes; he was & modero Celestial Tree on earth, praised throughout the world. 
(Line 30.) His paterual grandfather : 
(Verse 15.) Aditya Bhatta, abounding in the lore of the excellent books of the Vedas, polverising sin, rose (to honour) amidst the applause of the earth, so as to be served by the goddess of Fortune dwelling) in the lotus of his own race. 
(Verse 16.) To Aditya, who had all the virtues, there was a son Dronachārya, a master of the bow known as being like Gåņdiyi [Arjuna], as if he had been born to Pon* aud the renowned Sun-god. 
(Verse 17.) This poble man's high-born wife Chāmala-dēvi, who was known as a peer of the lady Fortuno, a peer of Arundhati in virtae, & peer of the lady Speech, adorned hon race, amidst the praises of the world, 
(Verse 18.) Their sons were the General Achirāja, the General Mecha, and the General Kance of the Spear, & tres of desire to sages. 
(Verse 19.) Are there in the present or the past any mortals that are equal to the moon- - light to his race, Acharaga, when he is compared with other men on this circle of earth girdled by the four oceans 
(Verse 20.) The line of glittering crests of the fire of doom, the tongue of great Räha, the fangs of the Destroyer, the biss of the black cobra, is the spear of the General Kamchi of the Spear.

(Verse 21 ) As truly he is called a brother to public women bright with the glances from their white eye-corners, one who holours worthy master-poets and sages, a son of Sıra, one with the form of the Love-god, a sou to others' wives, a friend to the lotus-pool of his own race, who can equal Mêchi, the right eastern face on the floor of the edifice of the religion of Siva 
(Verse 22.) Vengala-dēvi and Laliya-dēvi, the good wives of that treasure of courtosy the General Mēcbi, have flourished on earth, renowned in the world, as digits of the moon to the fresh water-lilies of their race. 
(Verse 23.) In the realm of Bharata the land of Kuntala shews itself in beauty. In it appears forsooth the province of Parikara; the capital city radiant within that district is Purikara town. 
(Verse 24.) The seignior of this county, the world renowned Jayakēžidēva, has become eminent by his glory, being known as a seat of Fortune, au ornament of the Manala race, a thunderbolt sbattering the Maināka his foes. 
(Verse 25.) There has arisen amidst joy the god sominātha of the South, with whom are seen (the sacred bull) Nandi, the ornameat of snakes, the Gauges, the high-braided hair, the Monutain's Daughter, and the balf-moon. 
(Lines 42-43 ) As regards the line of priors of the establishment of this god Mabā Svayambhu-Sõmanātha - 
(Verse 26.) Of the world-revered ascetio Dēvasóma (there was a son) sprang from the family of great ascetics, exalted in all virtues; of this ascetic Mahēndrasoma (there was) a son, Jõānasôma-Pandita-dēva. 
(Verse 27 ) Kēšava, minister of king Sönēšvara, bas verily maintained the merit of desiring not others' wives, of abiding not in falsehood, of being known as an incarnation of righteousness, so that the earth praises him. 
(Verse 28 ) The incomparable Jñānasoma, lord of ascetics, has so distinguished himself that men say: "Is it the Love-god who has assumed a brilliant abounding mass of high braided locks ? is it the Tree of Desire that joyfully has settled permanently in happiness at the establishment of Sõmēśvara in Purikara under the guise of an ascetic ? is it the Ocean that displays its profundity in the form of a Yögi" 
(Lane 47) While this continuous sequence of the succession of sons of great ascetics was flourishing : 
(Verse 29.) On the temple of Somēšau of the South, wlich is, as one may say, a massive finial of gold on the crest of the Golden Mountain, the incomparable Mécharasa has set & solid finial of gold. 
(Verse 30 ) The ornament of his lineage, having purchased for payment of gold a hundred nivartanas at Kunduravalli, within (the district of) Ekkalavā da, for (defraying the ed penses of) the golden finial, presented it under the name Kalasada-bālu. 
(Lines 49-55) Hail! He who posseases all titles of bonoar, the high minister, son to others' wives, brother to pablic women, son of Siya, restorer of the four churches, controller of the county of Puligere, the General Mēcbarasa, having presented money to the thousand retainers of the Mabā-Mandalesvara Jayakēsi-dëvarasa and to Maddirāja, mayor of Kundur avalli, Sövimayya, and Kēsimayya, and having thereby) purchased with washing of feet and

laving of hands the piece of estate connected with the lands of Ittage and the lands of Nittür (held for) the god's usufruct, forming a part of the area within the boundaries marking the four sides of access of Kunduravalli, which he measured out for these gentlemen and on which he Qeducted a dasuvandhaat the rate of ten per cent, on kanda2-ground, obtained as an imperial gift one hundred mattar arable soil by the rood according to the gadimba of Huligero, as a per petual endowment for the finial, to endure as long as moon and son, on sarva-namasya tenure, as the result of a petition made by him to his loud the great augast General Kēsımayya, the instrument and cause of the aplifting of the Chāļukya kingdom;

(Lines 58-61.) As regards the bounds of this hundred-mattar field of endowment-land : the north-eastern bound is a stone with the figure) of a Kinnari at the northera side of the waste lands of Ittage. As to the eastern bound, the limit is the running stream in the lands of Ittage As to the south-eastern bound, the limit is a stone with the figure) of a Kinnari on the l'Iter-bank to the east of the waste of Kantarike. As to the south-western bound, the limit is a stone (roith the figwe) of a Kinnarī at the south of Benaka's Lake. The north-western bound is a fixed boundary-stone (with the figure) of a Kinnari on the south of the lands of Nittar. Thus the four bounds are concluded 
(Verse 31.) Out of the hundred nattar assigned) for the finial, this general Méchana, who is indeed adorned with glory, world-famed, crowned with Siva's feet, has granted excellent land, six mattar for the well of Nandı, sir for the well of Gaurale faultless in virtue, thus (umounting to) twelve mattar. 
(Verse 32: a common Sanskrit formula ) (Verse 33. a Kanarese commonitory stanza) 
(Line 64.) The poem is that) of an eminent scholar among Kanarese master-poeta. The engraving (28 thut) of Chāvoja, eldest son of Jinnöja of Puligere, emperor of stone-musons. 
No. 9.--TWO JAIN INSCRIPTIONS OF MULGUND AND LAKSHMESHWAR. 
BY LIONEL D. BARNETT. 
The following two inscriptions have been edited froni ink-impressions prepared for the late Dr. Fleet, and bequeathed by him to the British Museum, where they now are. Though they relate to different foundations, they refer to the same lineage of Jain Garus, and havo two im portant verses la common; and this fact, together with their mention of the standard grammars of their day, gives them a more than ordinary interest. 
On this term see Ind. Ant, Vol. XXX, pp. 107, 267; Ep. Carn., Vol X, pt. i, Mb 172 1,259, CR. 9, Bg. 71, (t. 1, 14. It is a remission of is of the revende, uader varying couditions (e.ge as compensation for some public work, such as digging and maintaiau gwells). 
* The niganing of kand.. here is not clear. There may be some connection with the Tamil kandu, "cornfeld, or with the Marathi usage in the sense of contract. 
34. yoga ou which the declination of sun and moon is the same. 
No. 9] TWO JAIN INSCRIPTIONS OF MULGUND AND LAKSHMESHWAR. 
53 
www. 
ar 
A MULGUND INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA I: SAKA 975. 
Regarding the site and name of Mulgund, whence this inscription comes, it suffices to refer to Dr Fleet's remarks above, Vol XIII, p. 190. The present record was found on a slab in the local Jaia basti or temple. The stone is surmounted by a rounded pediment with trun cated top, which contains some sculptures, viz. in the centre a squatting Jina in me niche or köshtha-pañgara, on the proper nght a figure, perhaps representing a worshipper ; over 10 the sun ; to the proper left of the Jina, a cow with sucking calf; and above it the moon Below this 18 the inscribed area, in two compartments, with a width of about 2 ft. 41 in. ; the upper one, containing lines 1-2. is about 3 in. Ligh, and the lower one, containing the rest of the re cord, is some 4 ft in height. A transcription is given in the Elliot Collection, Vol 1, fol 76h. of the Royal Asiatic Society's copy; but it is very incorrect, and omits & considerable part of the text Tho stone is very much worn, anal in many places the writing is almost illegible. The character is an elegant monumental type of Kanarese of the period, with graceful upright letters paiying in height from 10. to in.---The language is Old Kanarese, with the exception of three Sanskrit stanzas, viz. verses 1, 7, and 10. It preserves the archaic l, in negaldan (11. 11, 18), pogalte (1. 16), and ēlpatt- (1. 29) On the word sivata (1 22) of above, Vol. XV, p. 105. For moggu (1. 25) see note in loco. 
The record, after invoking the blessing of the Jina Chandraprabha (11 1-2), refers itself to the reign of Trailõkyamalla, ie. Sõmēśvara I (11. 3-5), and states that at the time the Three-Hundreds of Belvola and Purigere were under the administration of his son, the Mahă-Mandalesvara Sõmēsvara [II], who bears among many other titles that of “lord of Vangi best of cities” and “ furious elephant of Amma " (11. 5-10) It then introduces a pious and eminent Jain sandhe-vigrah-adhikari, or officer of peace and war, named Beldēva ; he and his two younger brothers Baladēva and Säntivarma were the sons of Aggaladēva and Goujikabbe (1l. 10-17). Beldēva was a " servant " or " soldier" (bantu) of Kēģirāja, and a disciple of Nayasēna Süri (11 17-19) Then come two verses extolling Kancharasa, a local 
t the Sında family, who was induced by Beldēva to make a grant out of his own sīvata (11. 19-22) Next comes tbe spiritual pedigree of Nayasõna, and a enlogy of the latter's learning in the Sena or Chandrakavāta anvaya of the Müla Sangha there was an eminent divine named Ajitasēna Bhattāraka, whose disciple was Kanakasēna Bhattāraka, whose pupil was the eminent grammarian Narēndrasēna, who was the tencher of the incomparable grammarian Nayasēna (11 22-28). An estate, duly specified, and apparently in the sīvata of Kancharasa, was made over by Beldēva to Nayasēna as trustee for the supply of food to the local bastı (11. 28 ff.). 
The above-mentioned Ajitasēna may very possibly be the famous Jain divine of that pane, who was the prior of the Bankäpar monastery, and who was the spiritual guide of the Western Ganga king Mārasimha II (who piously starved himself to death at Ajtasēna's feet) and of the minister Châmundarāya (E. I, Vol V, pp. 152, 171, 180; Ep. Oarn, Insci. Sralana Belgola, Nos 38 and 67, and introduction, pp 20 and 34, Ep Carn, Vol VI, Kp. No 3, and introduction, p. 11). He appears to have been a teacher of a Kanakasēna, entitled Vādı-rāja, who is mentioned in several inscriptions as a disciple of Akalanka and teacher of the Ganga king Răchamalla (Ep. Carn., Vol. VIII i., Nr, Nos 35-7, 39, TI , No 199). This Ajitasena must be distinguished from the scholar of the same name, styled Vädībhasımba, Sabda chaturmukha, anı Tārkıka-chakravartin, who was a later scion of the same spuitual lineage, 
i On the Sindas see above, Vol XIV, p. 268 
2 A Šringaramangari or series of erotic verses is ascribed to him (gee Seshagiri Sastri's Report, IT, pp 83. 231 f, 234), but it seems more natural to refer it to the otber Ajitasana mentioned belowwif odced to any Ajitasénate54 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
and who flourished in the first half of the twelfth century A.D. (see E. I, Vol III, p. 188 ; Ep. Carn., Inser Sravana Belgola, No 54 ; Ep. Carn., Vol VIII ii., Nr, Nos. 35-7, 37, TI 192) It is not clear which of these two Ajitasõnas was the author of the Alarikārc-chintu manii and Muni-prakisika (a supercommentary on the grammar of Sākatāyana) mentioned by Mr. Rice in his introduction to the Karnataha Subdaruśāsana, p. 35 We find a similar dupli cation of Kanakasēnas ; for the one mentioned in our record can hardly be the same as Kinakasēna the disciple of Vipaçasēna (B. I, Vol. X, pp. 57, 69), or Kanakaséna the disciple of Virasēna, circa A D. 880 (zbrd, Vol. XIII, pp. 191, 193 f.), while a tradition records yet another as preceptor of Jinasēna the teacher of Mallisbēna. 
The grammarian Narēndrasēna of our record seems to be the same as Narendrasēday the author of a work on logic styled Pramana-pramoya-kililca (see S. R Bliandarkar, Catalogue of USS in Deccan College, p 327 ; A. V Kathavate, Report for 1391-5, p. Statement showing old and rare ALSS in Gujranwala and Delhi Districts, 1881-2, p 1l; Peter 800, First Report, p 1:26). But our inscription B. vill introduce us to a second Narendrasēna, it disciple of Nayasēna, who may also have some claim to this distinction, 
The date of our record is given on l. 29 as : Saka 975 (lapsed), the year Vijaya ; the uttarayana-sankrantz. This ought to correspond to Friday, 24 December, A.D. 1053, when the samkranti occurred about 1 h. 35 m. after mean sunrise, according to the Arya-siddhanta.? 
The only geographical names mentioned are: the Belvola Three-Hundred (1. 9), The Puligere Three Hundred (zb.), Mulgunda (1 21), Kirugere, or s Little Tank " (1. 31), 
Asagagere (1 33). On the first two see above, Vol XIII, p. 178 f, and XIV, p. 188. The Chandrakavat-ānvaya (1. 23) preserves the name of Chandrikayata, on which see above, Vol. XIII, pp. 192-1.

shashtır=yvarsha-sahasrāņi Visbthāyām jāyatē krimiḥ 2 [10*] 
TRANSLATION. (Verse 1.) May the radiant Jina Chandraprabba, whose blest pair of lotus-feet is licked by the mass of lustre from priceless gems in the coronets of gods bowing (to him) in intensity of devotion, who overthrows the pride of the Love-god, who is brilliant with glory pervading the belly of the three worlds, fully preserve from harm the congregation of the godly (so that it be) undistarbed. 
(Lines 3-5.) While the victorious reign of bail!--the asylum of the whole world, favour ite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, suprome Lord, supreme Master, Ornament of Satyäśraya'a race, embellishment of the Chalukyas, Trailökyamalla-deve, was advancıog in a course of successively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars : 
(Lines 5-10) While his son, the Mahā- Mandalēívars who has obtained the five great musical sounds, lord of vongi best of cities, terrible in battle, a sun anong princes, checking the fury of foemen's elephants, a fiery elephant to Amma, a treasure to his bousehold, a Kániua 
Karna] in bounty, a king of the Vatsas with laorses, a Cupid in beauty, & shaft in the heart of hostile kings, unique athlete of the world, head-jewel of feudatory princes, crest-Jewel of the Chalukyas, a destruction to foes, & rampart to the camp, a bee to the lotus-feet of Trailokya. malla-dēva, Sõmēśvara-déva, was governing the Belvola Three-Hundred and the Puligere 
Three-Hundred with enjoyment of pleasant conversations comme 
(Line 10.) One that finds sustenance at his lotus-feet. 
(Verse 2.) As a foandation of courtesy, a resort of loyalty, a dwelling place of discernment of truth, e native house of prosperity, a treasure of constant postinted bounty, a bome of dignity was Beldēva renowned, adorned with goodly speech, world-famed, filling the circle of space with glory bright as the rising moon. 
(Verse 3.) “Mert is the merit of giving ; conduct is loyalty to one's lord; wealth is designed to be a dwelhag for beneficence; principles are the principles of the sin-destroying Jinas": as this true conception came and established itself in them, accordingly Beldēva and the excellent Baladēva and the eminent santivarma fulfilled their religions duties with glory. 
(Lines 14-17) Thas of these three brethren, who were famed as exalted in the series of all virtues, stainless in the religion of the Judas, unceasing in beneficence to all people, hones of the creaping-plant of lofty fame, dear song of Aggaledēva, and cloths tightly swathing the slender belly of Gojjikāmbikā,3 the eldest, a Minister of Peace and War 
(Verse 4.) A bee to the Jinas' lotos-feet, like the Lovegod, a jewel-nine of fittiog thonghts, following the course of Manz, an ocean of courtesy, dissipating the defilement of the Kalı Age,

& henchman of Kesirāja, having moreover a mind fervent in adoration of Nayagēna Söri's lotas-feet, lofty, . . . discernment, he was renowned in the land. 
(Line 19 ) As this noble man revealed his spirit in his eminent practice of religion - 
(Verse 5.) À . . of the Sindas, one whose form gave delight to women, & geat of peerless courage, son of the Sında king, having fame like tbe radiant moonbeams, beloved of lovely women, 
(Verse 6.) stainless in the religion of the Jinas, & treasure of truthfulness, . . . apstinted bounty, is Kancharasa, resembling the (God of the) Five Arrows [Kāma], an orna ment to the Sindas' land of Mulgunda. 
(Lines 21-22.) He who, receiving from Kaõcharasa, (i.e Beldēva) a seat of such greatness and fame, being inspired to religion, made a grant out of his own sivatal with presentation of gold : 
(Verse 7) There has arisen the sana lineaga, a seat of radiant gems, jewels consisting of great men, in the ocean of the blest Müla Sangba 
(Lines 23-24) Ajitasõna Bhattāraka, worthiest of the Chandrakavāta lineage-his disciple Kana kasēna Bhattāraka-his disciple 
(Verse 8.) The Chandra (grammar), the Kātantra, the Jainēndra (grammar), the Sabdānušāsana, Pāpini, and the Aindra (grrimniar) were to the great Muni Narēndrasēna a single letter; to what other man are they possible p2 
(Lines 25-26.) Thus world-renowned was his disciple 
(Verse 9.) What shall I say of thee? As it may be said, “ How now, is the great sage Säkatäyana himself equal to Nayasēna) in the Sabdánaśāsana, Pāņinı in the Pāṇiniya Chandra in the Chandra, that Jinēndra in the Jainěndra, that Kumára forsooth in the Kaunāra ?", there are no others equal to Nayasēna-Pandita on the ocean-girt earth. 
(Lines 28-33.) Having laved the feet of Nayasēna Pangıta-dēva, who is thus a consummate master of all grammatical lore, at the uttarāyana-sankrantr of the cyclic year Vijaya, the nine hundred and seventy-fifth (year) of the Saka era, hes with the cognisance of the Mabājanas of the town and the establishment of the Five Mathas measured out by the pole of the Nagarēśvara's gadimba-sta udard and granted for the purpose of supplying food to the temple of the sacred demesne, in pious memory of his niother Gojjikabbe, a field of twelve mattar in the field of Kirugere, with immunity from all conflicting claims 
this field are on the north-east a stone (with the figure of a cow, on the south-east a stone (with the figure) of the sun, on the soath-west & stone with the figure) of the moon, on the north-west a stone (with the figure) of Padmavati,a to the south of Asagagere a garden of a 
thousand creeping-plants. 
(Verse 10. a common Sanskrit formula.)

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[Vol. XVI 
B. LAKSHMESHWAR INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGN OF VIKRAMADITYA VI: 
A.D. 1081. On the site of Lakshměshwar (the ancient Puligere, Purigere, or Purikara) I may refer to what I have written above, Vol. XIV, p. 188. The inscription is on a slab which was in the local Kachēri when the ink-impression was made; whence it originally came I do not know, The stone has a rounded pediment with some sculptures, namely a squatting Jina in the centre, with a cor and sucking calf on the proper left, surmounted by the sun (to right) and moon (to left); a figure or figures has apparently been effaced on the proper right. The inscribed area below this 18 about 3 ft. 2 in, broad and 3 ft. 6 in. high. The character is a fairly regular Kanarese type of the period, slightly angular and sloping. The letters vary from about in to 
in, in height, and in places are somewhat word. The cursive u occurs in avar., 1. 30.--The language is Old Kanarese, the only Sanskrit is verse 1 and a short quotation in verse 7. The archaic / is preserved in pogałtegan, 1. 9, negaltegam, l. 9, ilduv-, l. 15, negaldara, 1. 16, ild-, 11. 18, 24, negalda, 1 43, negaldan, 1. 44; it appears as r in hirttu, 1. 3, negartte, 1. 46, and as I in Nolumba, II. 8 ff, 23, pogalal, 11, 17, 26, negaldar, 1. 36, pēlvade, 1. 39, pogalalk-, 1 42; and it is falsely substituted for r in pelchutt-ire, 1. 18. It will be noted that in negaldara, l. 16, negalda, 1. 43, and negaldan, 1. 44, the second syllable is short metrically, while in negartie, l. 40, it is scanned as long (cf. above, Vol. XIII, p 327); hence it seems likely that negaldar, 1. 36, where it is also short, is a scribe's error for regaldar. Lexically interesting are avasura, l. 14 (appar ently meaning asura : cf. avalripe, avaguna, etc.), uddari, l. 18 (cf. above, Vol. XIII, p 327), bhuvana-bunbhuka, 1. 19 (ib pp 298, 327), prābda, 1. 26, pabb[e*), 1. 26, arttıga in the sense of " lover," l. 38, and gõja with the meaning of "moon," 1. 39 (cf. adja). 
The record, opening with the stock stanza Sranat-parama-gambłīra (1.1), refers itself in prose and verse to the reign of Tribhuvanamalla, or Vikramāditya (VI) (11, 2-5), and then introduces his younger brother Jayasimha III, the Yavarāja or Heir-apparent, to whom, besides many complimentary titles, it gives the full set of names found in some other records, 
Trailõkyamalla Vira-Nolamba Pallava-Permānadi Jayasió ha-dõva (11. 5-8). After two verses of forid compliments to him (Il. 8-10) and a statement in proset governing the “ Two Three-hundreds " (namely Belvola and Puligere), the Bankväse Twelve-thousand, the Santalige Thousand, and the Kandür Thousand (11. 10-11), it brings in one of his subordinate barons, the Mahasamantadhipati Eremayya (also called below Erakapa 
ega), a high minister, steward of the royal household, and general (11. 11-13), dwelling in verse upon his virtues and informing as that at the time he was administering the Puligere Three-hundred (Il. 13-19). Six yerses follow (11. 19-26), which expatiate on the equally sarprising merits of Eremayya's younger brother Döņa, who also held high office in the govern ment; and then comes a series of seven stanzas (11. 26–34) announcing that on a given date Dona assigned a grant for the Jain cult in Purikara (the modern Lakshmeshwar to the trustee. ship of Narēndrasēna [II], of the Sena Gana in the Māla Sangha, the senior disciple of Nayasēna Sūri, who in his turn was the senior disciple of Narēndrasēna [1]. We have already made the acquaintance of Narēndiasēna I and Nayasēna in the preceding record ; the present record, which quotes stanzas 8-9 of A., nopp carries the succession one generation further on. Our author next brings on the scene in yy. 23-34 (11 34-46) a distinguished family of pious Jains, namely Dinakara (11. 34-36), his sons Räjimayya (or Raja) and Dūdama (II. 36-42), Dūdama's wife Echikabbe and their daughter Hammikabbe (11. 42 43), Hammikabbe's husband Arasimayya or Arasayya (11. 43-44), their son the physician Kannapa or Kanna (1). 44-45), and Kannapa's sons Indapa, Išvara, Raji, Kalidēva, Adinātha, Sānti, and Pārsva (11. 45-46). Hero the record breaks off ; apparently it was 
WWW. 
* See Dynast. Kanar. Distr., pp. 453 f. 
No. 91 TWO JAIN INSCRIPTIONS OF MULGUND AND LAKSHMESHWAR 
59 
ww 
w wwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww WWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWW 
never finished. But it would seem that one of the last members of this pedigree was in some way concerned in the grant, perhaps as having petitioned Dona for it. 
Of Dūdama certain exploits are reported (11 39-42) which are rather obscure, owing to the loose and vague language used by the poet. The words seem to mean.“At the stern command of the sovereign be took captive the Lord of the Eighty-four. . . he in his tarn took captive ... Sõbhana, who in wrath bad seized, bound, and cast iuto prison king Inda . . .By his night of aim he took captive him who had cast his master into confinement, and inade him release him." The data given by the record are too scanty to enable is to identify these persons. Very 
ty-four” may be a Kadamba king, whose dynasty is regularly described in its titles as chaturasīta-ragar-adhishthita," presiding over eighty-four cities." An inscription of Saka 907 at Hülı (Elliot Collection, Royal Asiatic Society's copy, Vol II, fol. 336a.) mentions a person named Söbbanayya, whose pergade made a raid apon Huli in that year, but it is unsafe to connect him with the Sobhana of our record 
The date is given on l. 26 as the sixth year of the Vikrama era, Durmati ; Pushya krishna 6, a Friday , the yogni vyatīpāta; the uttarayana-silmkrānti. This is regular. The trthi mentioned was current on Friday, 24 December, A.D. 1081, when it ended about 9h 47 m. after mean sunrise (for Ujjain). The uttarayana-sankrante occurred on the same day 7 h 25 m. after mean sunrise, while the titha kri 6 was still current 
The places mentioned are the “ Two Three-hundreds ” (1 e. those of Belvola and Puligere), 1 10, the Banavāse Twelve-thousand, I 10, the Sāntalige Thousand, 1. ll, the Kandur Thousand, 1, 11, the Puligere Three-hundred, 1 18, and the town of Purikara 
(1.2 Puligere), 1 29.

TRANSLATION. 
(Verse 1) Victorious be the commandment of the Lords of the Three Worlds, enjoined by the Jinas, bearing for token the blest supremely profound doctrine of (different possibilities of predication 
(Lines 2-3.) Hail ! the refage of the whole world, favourite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, supreme Lord, sapreme Master, ornament of Satyāšraya's race, embellishment of the Chalukyas, Tribhuvanamalla-deva 
(Verse 2.) What emperors have completely torn up the roots of froward monarchs, scattered them with hartling bing into the waters, stood ap in the fore-front, and cleared the earth of thorns, right up to the surrounding) ocean ? A gem of emperors, the exceedingly puissant Vikramaditya, has cleared the earth of thorns and constantly protected it 
Lines 1-5 ) So, while the victorions reign of Tribhuvanamalla-dõva was advancing in a course of successively increasing proepenty, (to endure) as long as moon and stars -

(Lines 5-8 ) His younger brother hail he who is praised by the whole world, renowned among men, scion of the Pallavas, darling of Fortune and Earth, beir-apparent, Parame śvara [Supieme Lord] among kings, Mahēśrara [Great Lord] among warriors, adorned with valour, minion of the goddess of victory, guardian-gem to refuge-seekers, crest-gem of the Chalukyas, Tiinātra (Siva] in the fiay, parifying the Kshatıiyas, a king of the Angas [Karna] to fiery elepbants, a natural Love-god, plunderer of hostile kiags, champion of his elder brother, Trailökyamalla Vira-Nolamba Pallava-Permānadı Jayasımha-dēva

(Luines 9-10) Being known as a subject of such praise and distinction 
(Verse) Vīra-Nolamba, in whom are embodied the royal virtues, who bas no foes remain ing, towards whom the people's affection waxes great, the creeping-plant of whose glory stands erect, has hosts of foes bowing before him. 
(Lines 10-11 ) While he was protecting the Two Three-hundreds, the Banavāse Twelve thousand, the Sāntalige Thousand, and the Kandür Thousand with enjoyment of pleasing conversations ; 
(Lines 11-13) One who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet, the Mahāsā mantadhipati who has obtained the fiy great musical sounds, great august General foes, gallant to the lady the art of literature, bee to the lotus-face of Sarasvati, Le whose soul is matured by remerabiance of Hara's feet adored (by 11272), a jewel in the ear of Sarasvati, the High Minister, Stoward of the Household, (and) General, Eremayyan 
(Verse 5 ) A Biahmä in all arta, a sun of the Brāhman race, a moon to the ocean of the Vatsa gotra, a king Death to foes, is the General Erega a man of slight account in the series of worlds ? 
(Verse 3) If the lord Erega bas a resemblance (to anything) on earth, it is the earth, the ocean, (and) Indra's mountaina (to which he may be compared respectively) for weightinese, profundity, (and) solidity (But), if one considers, the earth, which became tremulous through the Demons, may become soraething different, the ocean, which had its profundity diminished by Rāma,t may become something different, the celestial mountain, which became light of weight through Krishna, may become something different, if sometime the caso should happen. 
(Verse 7) If one reflects, the distance between his merit and (other) illustrious men's merit may be said to be the distance between an elephant and a gnat; hence the sages' pbrase of what envy is there for merits » applies well to the lord Erega. 
(Verse 8) The creeping-plant of (his) goodly stainless glory has thus overspread the regions of space so that there is no gap; (hus) valour has wrought ...; (hus) weightiness is beyond comparison; his conduct has reached a crowning degree; it has been such that they say " a son of strengths has again been born": who are able to praise (adequately) Brega's eminence ? 
(Verse 9 ) As he lives in such fame and repate; as (his) distinction, in which he is known as a sweet springtime to his land, continues to increase; as he enjoys the government of the

(Verse 11.) Erega's younger brother is in valour the younger brother of him who shattered the troop of the Kuru race [Arjuna], in incomparable beauty the younger brother of Baladeva [Kțisbpa], in might of arm the younger brother of Yama's son [Bhima] 
(Verse 12) When enemy kings are bowing at the base of Erega's feet, it is Döna who makes them bow, so that their cry is “I cannot but bow"; he bears the burden of his lord's business, while the covetons and their like stoop (before hin). 
(Verse 13 ) As there appears no grudging in (his) generosity, nor shortcoming in his worthy conduct, nor shame in his behaviour, are any other men in the world of mortals equal to Döņa, who is a (God of the) Flowery Arrows to women, a preseryer of a multitude of agreeable cultured men, an expert in all arts equal to the Lotus-horn (Brahman) 
(Verse 14.) His deity is Pašu pati, a supremely helpful lord ; Nolamba, conqueror of hosts of foes, has cherished and supported him ; his father is Tikka, eminent for a series of brightest virtues ; his mother is Kalvāmbike, adorned with brilliant conduct, his elder brother is the renowned Erakapa, a gem of the company of generals - thus Dona is a dwelling-place for glory. 
(Verse 15.) In this Iron Age, this time of stress, there has been an outcry at the rise of an ocean of righteousness, so that it would seem as if the people of the earth altogether with one voice in their delight were joyously utter og praises, saying: “after a long time it has become visible, thus righteousness is coming to hand ? " 
(Verse 16.) Whilst Pushya of the year Durmati, the sixth in the series) of the years of Vikrama delightful in their course, the dark fortnight, and Friday and the sixth (lunar) day were in progress, while with these coincided a mana-yoga consisting of vyatipātat and the great uttarayana-samkrānti, the excellent man Döna, brilliant of fame, preserver of wide righteousness, here with generosity 
(Verses 17-18.) Having laved in this Purikara, a divine city, the feet of Narēndrasena Traividya,5 who is a moon to the ocean of the supreme Jinas' Church and a lotuses frind [sun] in the sky of the Sēna Gaņa, tbat mine of lustre sprung from the Müla Sangha, who is a bridegroom of the goddess of white fame, a chief of worthy ascetics, one to whom monarchs bow down, a man without fault 
(Verse 19 identical with verse 8 of inscription A.) (Line 30.) His senior disciple (Verse 20. identical with verse 9 of inscription A) 
(Verse 21 ) "He has cherished Sarasvati with delight of spirit, me he has despised; I do not exist while she is present--fier to cohabit with a rival wite is hard ! ” uttering these harsh words, swiftly mounting the elephant of the sky-quarter, Famt herself enviously refiles the worthy ascetic Nayagēna Sürı..

the triple lure, something ordinary-he whose pair of lotus-feet is beaten by diadems of stooping sovereigns, he who is renowned, he who is a sua in peerless lustre, a mirror to the lotus-face of the lady Fame who is renowned as being bright as stars, pearl-strings, Hara's laughter, ether, and frost, he who is an ocean of scriptural lore ? 
(Verse 23 ) Because of the magnificence of (his) extraordinary sun-like character owing to tbe presence of the majesty of conquered foes (appropriated by hin), because of his) firm mind devoted to the grand and brilliant Jain religion, because of (hus) peculiar quality of Bu perlative splendour by which he is knowa as a sin in the sky of the Bräbinan race, because of (hus) supremacy in peerless might, because of (his) peculiar eminence in bounty, and because of (his) truthfulness, Dinakara (was) a mine of exceeding lustre, a heap of godliness 
(Verse 24 ) As on the rise of the sun all darkness flees away, so with the rise of Dinakara the darkness of error flees away from the park of his race and is dissipated what a wonder! 
(Verse 25 ) His sons Räjimayya and Dudama are illustrious over the whole earth as being renowned among men, bees to the Jinan' lotus-feet, possessed of culture 
(Verse 26 ) All learned folk everlastingly praise lovingly with affection of spirit Raja, who is stainless and bright in brilliance, as being a bee to the Jinas' lotus-feet, gladdener of good men's souls, renowned over the whole earth, radiant with lustrous fame mounting to the tusks of the elephants of the sky-quarters, a tree of desire to cultured and agreeable men, exceeding in bounty to worthy recipients

(Line 39 ) If one would describe the measure of his beloved younger brother's valour 
(Verse 28 ) At the stern command of the sovereign he took captive the Lord of the Eighty-four; in his boldness he clasped not his hands (in submission), he in his turn took captive in a most marvellous manner that same sõbhana tho in wrath had seized, bound, and cast into prison king Inda is this singular degree of Düda's valour an ordigary thing ? 
By his might of arm he took captive him who had cast his master into con finement, and made him release bim”, thus this triple world lauds the valiant Dudama, acion of worthy Brāhmads. 
(Verse 30.) The excellent lady of Düda, who has thus heen described, far surpassed in beauty the Mind-born One's mistress [Rati] despite this praise, men do not withal fully com prehend in any way Échikabbo's beauty.

No. 10.-TWO KADAMBA INSCRIPTIONS OF NIRALGI. 
By LIONEL D. BARNETT 
The village of Niralgi, hence these records come, lies in the Hãngal täluka of Dharwar District, in lat 14° 52' and long, 75° 18', aboat 111 miles to the north-east of Hängal towa. Ås our inscriptions shew, it was formerly called Nīrili. The ink-impressions on which the texts of the following inscriptions are based were prepared for the late Dr. Fleet, and are now ju the British Museum. 
A.OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA I: SAKA 974. 
Ås to the exact site where this record was found and the character of the stone I have no information. The inscribed area is about 2 ft high and 2 ft. 5} in. broad The character is fairly good Kanarese of the period, with letters kiin. high. The palatal and the guttural nasals both occur "kañchanan (1.9), Emmangala (1. 15) -The language, except in the formal Sanskrit Teises and final fornalæ and the phrase Sarastatyaya namah (an error for Sara statyai framah) in 1 22, is Old Kaparese prose. The ! 18 preserved in =ggalleyemam (1. 1) and pēbo (1. 18) ; it is changed to l in baliyan (1. 13), and alz (11. 17, 19). On the phraso balıyag=atti see Dr. Fleet's remarks above, Vol. XI, P 3. 
The record begins by referring itself to the reign of Trailokyamalla-Abavamalla, i.e. Sõmēšvara I (11. 1-3), and then informs us that on a certain date the Kādamba Mahā-Mandalo. śvara Harikēsarin formally made over by deputy certain estates to the Three-Hundred Mahă jadas of Nirili for the maintenance of the Piriya Kere or Great Tank and the cult of the god Kali (II. 3-15). The document was drafted by the town-clerk Jõgivayya, and engraved by Chittoja (Il 21-22). Harikēsarin is the prince, also named Arikēsarin and Harigan, who figures in the Bankāpül inscription of Saka 977 published by me above, Vol XIII, p. 188,1 with titles almost the same as those given in the present record. I there stated (p. 169) that the year Saka 977 marked the earliest known connection of the Kādambas with the Baqavāsı province ; we are now able to trace it back to a date three years earlier, 
The date is given in Il. 11-12 as · Saka 974 (expired), the cyclic year Nandana ; Pushya suddha 13, Sunday ; the utterāyana-samkrantz; a vyatzpita. This is irregalar. In Nand.ina there as an intercalated Pushya If we take the given totha as belonging to the latter, it corresponded to Tuesday, 5 January, A D. 1053, en ding at 12 h 19 m after mean sunrise. Mr. R. Sewell, who has kindly checked my calculations in this paper, points out that the title saddha 13 in Nāja-Pushya of the samno year was expanged ; at mean aanrise or Weúnesday, 3 February, A.D. 1053, the current titluz tras suddha 12, and at the same moment on the following Thursday the current trthi was saddha 14. Furthermore, the uttarayant-sankranti took place on Wednesday, 24 December, AD 1052, at 19 h. 23 m after men suurise. 
* In my translation of that document I bare fallen into some errors, which I have tacztly corrected in my rendering of the present inscription,

Sarasvatyaya namah 
TRANSLATION. 
(Lines 1-3.) While the victorious reiga ofail!--the asylum of the whole world, favourite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, ornament of Satyāśraya's race, embellishment of the Chalukyas, king Traiļokyamalla-Ābavamalla, was advancing in a course of successively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars :--- 
(Lines 3-11.) Hail! The Maha-Mandalēśvara who has obtained the five great musical sounds, who bears all titles of honour such as “lord of Banavāsı best of cities, ornament of the race of the Kadamba emperor the great king Mayūravarman, which is spring from the Three-eyed [Siva] and Earth, presides over eighty-four cities, is consecrated in eighteen world-famous horse-sacrifices to the god of) the Frontal Eye [Siva] and the Four-armed [Vishnu), has established its might upon the massive summits of the great Mount Himavat, binds its fiery elophants to columns of crystal, aud is charming with great majesty, he who is (uttended) with the noise of permatti drams and (other) musical instruments, who is resplendent with a banner (bearing the devue) of a great ape, is canopied in glory, and has for crest a stately lion ; giver of gold to the needy, call8u of victory in the fray, man of might to adver. saries, sun of valour, a Närăgana of the gallant, a lion for his elder brother " the Mabā Mandalëśvara Harikësarı-dēva, - 
(lines 11-12.) On Sunday, the thirteenth of the bright fortnight of Pushya in the cyclie year Nandana, the 874th (year) of the Saka era, at the uttarayana-sankranti, in a vyatipāla,l.. 
(Lines 12-15.) Having sent a summoner to the Three-hundred Mahajanas of the Agre Hära of Nīrili, convened them, and laved their feet, made over with pouring of water the house tax to the Great Tank, and a garden of six-bundred trees and a field of one mattar to the god Kali of that place. Happiness! great fortune ! 
(Lines 15-19: a prose commonitory formula of the asaal type.) (Verses 1-2: two common Sanskrit verses.) 
(Lines 21-22 ) The town-clerk Jõgivayya wrote tris record). The stone-mason Chittoja executed the order. Happiness' great fortune 1 homage to Sarasvati ! 
2S 
B.-OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA II: SAKA 998-7. In the case of this epigraph also I have been unable to trace the site whence it comes, or to find any details as to the stone. The inscribed area, which is much worn by weather, com prises an upper compartment, on which are lines 1-2, and a lower one containing all the rest; it is nearly 4 ft high and 2 ft. 71 10. wide..The character is Kadarese, rather straggling and clamsy, and resembling the Peggar inscription of AD. 978 (20. $ of " Coorg Inscriptions," revised edition). The cursive forms of m, y, and v (above, Vol. XII, p. 335) are all found here :-o in "batumam aud ) bridyatvanzam, 1. 22, mandalilca", 1. 24, srimar", 1.33, dharmma", 11. 37, 39, kavrleyumam, 11. 39-40, palakam, 1. 40, Rāma", l. 41, y in osa ikrantiyandum, lk. 31-32, Unchagêriya, 1. 32; and u in querevare, 1. 23. The ñ is written in pancha", ll. 30, 38, 
0. The height of the letters varies from in, tosin.--The language is Old Kanarese, except 
72 
um 
. 
A zõga in which the declinations of sun aud moon are oqual. 
No 10] 
TWO KADAMBA INSCRIPTIONS OF NIRALGI. 
69 
wwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww 
www 
er 
h 
in the Sanskrit verses ou II. 40-42 and the barbarous concluding formula. The archaic locours once, in példa, 1. 39, it is replaced by l in balz', 11 10, 33, baliya, 1, 36, alio, 11. 39-40, and by q in mēl-ārkeyya, l. 13 (El blunder for Palheya) and Arppattara, 1. 32 In regard to lexico graphy, we may notice baliyan=atti, 1. 10, and balty-atti, 1. 33 (soe above, inscr A), mänps, I 22, (?) tottu, 1, 22, (?) brīdyatva, 1 22, polisim, . 23 (perhaps connected with pole, "to shine" or “to be swung aboat”: should we then read here polepen ?), aud avanguite, . 28 (in Kittel's Dictionary avangota). 
VIS 
The record is tuofold, comprising two endowments, and probably was engraved at the time when the second was granted The first (1l 1-13) opens by referiing itself to the reigui of a Chālakya king whose name is here lost, but that it was Bhuvanaikamilla (Sõmēśvara II) is proved by the reference to him and the date in l. 8. It then mentions (11 3-5) thu Nahi. Mandalēśvara Vikramāditya-dēva (possibly the king's younger brother, afterwards Vikrama ditya VI), and likewise (11 5-7) a noble of the Pallava lineage paned Bhuva Pallava-Permānadı Vi[shouvardhana-V2]jayāditya, and bearing a raong his other titles that of " lord of Kanchi bost of citios", and it stites that, wbeu Vikramaditya and Vishnu vardhana-Vijayaditya were at Bankāpura in the course of a tour of state in the service of kiug Bhuvanaikamalla, in Sakı 996, they granted the village of Basalūr, in the Elambı Twonty, to the 300 Mahājanas of Nirili for the maintenance of the cult or Rāmēśvara (a well-known form of Siva) at Pomballi (11. 7-13). 
Then comes the second record (11. 13-43). It begins by jutroducing, in prose, with the usual titles of his lineage and some others, the Kadamba Maba-Man.laləsvara Săntivarman, *lord of Banavāsı best of cities" (1l 13-21), and extols his valoar and glory in four verse& (11. 21-30). After this comes the formal statement that in Sakı 997, when at Unohagēri, he, in concert with two other bigh officers of state, renewed the grant of the first record (ll 30-12). Bichchara Gangayya made the fair copy, and Sūdāja engraved it (11. 42-13). 
There are two dates. The first is given on 11 8-9 as : Saka 996, Ānanda , the full, moon of Asvayuja ; an eclipse of the moon This seems to be regular. The tithi mentioued was current at sunrise on Tuesday, 7 October, A.D. 1074, and ended about 20 h 3 m. after mean sunrise (for Ujjain) On that day there was a lunar eclipse, in wbich total obscura tion began 19 h. 30 m after noen sunrise, while the above tithr was still current. 
The second dato is given on 11 31-32 as. Saka 997, Rakshasa; Pushya suddha l; Sunday, the uttarayınu-samkianti This is quite wrong. Pushya suddba 1 of given year corresponded to Friday, 11 December, A.D. 1075, on which it ended about ll h 15 m after mean sunrise. The uttarayana-sankranta, on the other hand, occurred on Thursday, 24 December, about 18 h. after meau sauise, so that Friday was reckoned as the first day of Makara. 
The places mentioned are: Kanchi (11 6, 7); the nele-vīdu of Bankāpura (1 8); Pomballi ill. 10, 35), the Pānungal Five-hundred (1 12), the Elambi Twenty (ll. 1.... 36); Basalūr (16); Banavāsı (11. 18, 30), the nele-vidu of Unchagērı (1 92); and the tirthas (1. 37), besides a rather obscure phrase näd=ērppattara (1. 32), which is perhaps a mis take for nadzirppattuta, “the Twenty of the county," viz. Elambi. Pomballi is the modern Hombli, lying 34 miles nearly south of Niralgi, ia lat 14° 49' and long. 75o 171 One is tempted to identify Dñchagēri with the modern Wunchigēri, near Kumti , but the distance from Niralgı is considerable. Kāñchi (Conjeevaram), Bapkāpara (Bankıpür), and Panangal (Hängal) are well known. Elambi and Basalür do not seem to be traceable. 
See Dyn. Xanar. Dostr., p. 444 and n. l. 
2 See Dyr, Kanar. Distr., p. 501.
