TRANSLATION. (Lines 1-3) Fortune! While the reign of-bail !--the asylum of the whole world, (favourite] of Fortune and Earth, [great Emperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, ornament] of Satyāśraya's (1ace, embellishment of the Chalukyas, king Bhuvanaikamalla,] was advancing (in a course of successively incieasing prosperity, (to endue) as loug as mron, sun, and stars] . 
(Lines 3-5.) When he who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet-bail I-the Maba-Mandale śvara who has obtained the five great musical sounds, having all titles of honour such as <iucarnation of Gauri apd Ganēša (?), beloved of Pārvatī, protection . ," the Mabi mandalēšvara Vikramaditya-dēva, 
(Liues 5-9.) Likewisewhail lathe scion of the heroic Pallava race illustrious over the whole world, favourite of Fortune and Earth, .. of the Pallavas, unfailing in speecb, lord of Kanchi best of cities, Bhuvapaikamalla-Pallava-Permānadı Vishnuvardhana (?) Vijayāditya, in concert (urth hiun), having made a tour of state for king Bhuvanaikamalla, at the standing canzpl of Bankāpura, 
(Lines 8.13.) On the full-moon day of Āśvayuja in the cyclic year Ānanda, the 988th (year) of the Saka era, during an eclipse of the moon, having sent a summoner and convened the Three-hundred Mabajanas of the Agrahāra of Nīrili and laved their feet, made orer with pouring of water Basalür, a town belonging to the Elambi Twenty, a county of the Pânun gal Elve-hundred, with full internal authority of higher administration, for the baths and oblations of the god Räplēśvara of the sanctuary of Pomballi, for scents and incense, for perpe tual larans, for the learned men of (the cult of iva resident in the monastery, for the Brah mans, and for the charity-hall. 
(Lines 13-21 + Hail! The Maha-Mandalēśvara säntivarma-dēva, who bears all titler of honour such as "he whose poissance of great might is established upon the massive summits of the great Mount Himavat mighty of majesty, the emperor of all central mountains; a magnifi cent san in the sky of the Kadamba race; he whose awful rod-like arm is adorned by the residence of heroes' Fortune won by the victories of his arms aplifted on the occasion of many a fray; a fire of Doom to potent foemen's races ; inspired with majesty and wrath; sprung from the lineage consecrated in the consecratory rites of eighteen world-renowned horse-8acri fices to the God of) the Frontal Eye; presiding over eighty-four cities; lord of that best of cities the peculiarly excellent Banavāsi; lion of the Kadambas ; ornament of the race of the Kādamba Emperor, the great king Mayűravarman; he who 18 (saluted) with the noise of permat drums and (other) musical instruments, who is resplendent with a banner (bearing the device) of a great ape, who has for crest a lion stately in pride ; giver of gold to the needy, man of might to adversaries, sun in battle, cause of victory in the fray, furious elephant for his elder brother" 
(Verse 1.) When puissant hostile monarchs come bowing at his feet for refuge, in fear and terror of his irresistible night of arm yearning for the word “stop," they confess their shame : at once, aha ! as they swell in pride, put forth effort, become arrested, bend, contract them selves, boil in rage, strike in resistance, confronting (thee) . .. Will they be able to con tend in the fray, 0 Rudra of the Kadambas 
(Verse 2.) O king Santa, thou Death-spirit of cosmic dissolution to warriors of paissant enemy princes, ornament of princes, Bhairava to princes, Trinētra [Śiva] to princes, grindstone to princes, thou whose footstool is rubbed by prinogs creata, thou frontal diadem of princes, what princes on earth are like to thee ?

Verse 3.) When, confronting foes with the fire of bis puissant wrath, aba! he is slaring me when by the might of his arm, hurrah ! he terrifies the Guardians of the Spaces, more 
onuntains, shakes the whole earth, brings dread upon the elephants of the spaces, dries in the ocean, what high spirit! Say, ho! is not the Rudra of the Kadambas instantly effective in his wrath ?

(Lines 30-33.) Hail! the Maha-Mandaleśvara who has obtained the five great maacal sonnds, lord of Banavāsi best of cities, the Maha-Mandalēśrara Santivarms-déta, ( Sunday, the first of the bright fortnight of Pushya in the cyclic year Rakshase, the 997th (year) of the Saka era, on the uttarayana-samkrānti, when he was at the standing camp of Unchagēri in the Seventy (?) of the county, having sent a summoner and convened the Three Handred Mahajanas of Nīrılı,

No. 11.--THREE INSCRIPTIONS FROM HOTTUR. 
BY LIONEL D. BARNETT. 
RNIL 
Hotturor, to give it its ancient name, Pottiyur-is a village in the Bankápar taluka of Dharwär District, lying in lat. 14° 56' and long. 75° 16', some three miles nearly dae south from Shiggaon. The ink-impressions from which the following inscriptions have been edited by me were prepared for the late Dr. Fleet, and are now in the possession of the Trustees of the British Museum. 
L 
. 
A. OF THE REIGN OF SATYASRAYA : SAKA 929. 
This inscription is cut upon a rectangular block, divided into six horizontal bands, and sur mounted by a stepped top; I can find no record of the site where it stands, or stood. The stone is a viragal, with sculptures of the usual type : in the uppermost compartment, 2 seated god with a fan-bearer on each side ; below this, lines 1-6 of the inscription ; below this, the hero heing carried up to heaven by deities, one on each side; below this, lines 7-12 of the inscription; below this, a battle-scene, representing in the centre the hero with a bow, facing to the proper left and shooting against two archers, while a third man is falling pierced with 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA, 
[VOL. XVI. 
arrows at his feet, and six cows stand behind him; below this is the base. The width of the inscribed bands is about 2'ft. 5 in., and their height about 64 in They are very much worn, and parts-happily not material--are quite broken away -The character is Old Kanarese of the period, rather clumsy and irregular. The height of the letters varies yenerally between in. and in. The cursite y appears in chayamgala[mn], 1. 5, and ogēriya, l. 12 (see above, Vol XII, p. 335). The language is Old Kaparese prose. Original 1 is preserved, and sometimes 2 is wrongly written for 1. The words talaran, l. 9 (see above, Vol. XVI, p. 80), and eltu (eltam, 1 10, and eįtige, 1. 11), the source of the modern ettu, are deserving of notice. 
The record, after giving the date (1. 1), describes in detail an invasion by the Chola king, whom it styles Rājaraja Nitya-vinoda Rājēndra-vidyadhara Nürmadi-Chola (Il. 1-3). This evidently refers to Rajarāja I, who was reigning at the time, and bore the title of Natya. vinoda (South-Ind. Inscr., Vol II, pp. 151, 260 n., 301). It then relates his defeat by the Chalukya Akalankacharita-Irivabedanga Satyāáraya, and the latter's triumphal progress through the south (11. 3-6). While Satya raya in the course of this campaign was at the ghatta of Tavare (see Dyn Kan. Distr , p. 433), and certain persons, whose names are lost, were acting as gāvundas of the nādu and the town of Pottiyūr respectively, a raid was made by robbers upon the oxen belonging to the betel-traders, and the beadle Gojjiga perished in a valiant attempt to save them. In recognition of his courage the betel-traders made a grant, apparently for a kal. nādu (11. 6-12). The stone was prepared by Máchöja of Indēśvaragēn (1. 12). 
The date is given in 1 1 as Saka 9[2]9, the cyclic year Playanga being current. What is meant is evidently A.D. 1007-8, with which Plavamga coincided; the words pravarttisuttum. ire, " being current,” refer to Playainga, not to saka 929 ; for Plavamga corresponded to Saka 929 lapsed and Saka 930 current. 
The places mentioned are Donavura (1.2), the ghatta of Tavare, or “the Lotus-Ghät" (1. 6), the Pānuigal Five-hundred (11, 7-8), Pottiyur (1, 9), and Indēsvaragērı ( 
112) Dona. yura must be Donūr, in the Bägewädı taluka of Bijāpūr District, in lat. 16° 441 and long. 76° 01'. It is not clear whether the ghatta of Tavare means a monntain-range or pass, as Dr Fleet holds (Dyn. Kanar. Distr, p 433), or a bank or quay, Pánungal is of course the modern Hāngal, and Pottiyur is Hottär. I cannot locate Indēsvaragêri; but there was a sanc. tuary of Indrēśvara at Bankāptir, 
TEXT.2 
I * Saka-yarisha: 0 [2]oneya Plavamga-sam vatsaram pravarttisuttum-ire 
Rājar[7*]ja Nitya-vinoda Rājēndra-vidyadha [ra] 2 Chola-kula-talakam Nürmmadi-Chojan Daya-lakhka (kkha)-balam-berasu bamdu

mãdi Cholan=irppinan | Svasti śrī-rāja 4 raja] paramèsva (bya)ra parama-bhattārakan-Akala(la)mkacharitan-17riya. 
b[e] damga Chalukya-kula(la)-tila (la)ka Tigula (la)-māri sri 5 mat-Satyāśraya-dēva[m] chõlana[m] bem-kondu vastu-vāhana-chayamgala [mm] 
pididu terinka-di. 
There seems to be likewise an inscription running down both sides of the stone. Very little of it is legible ; bot it apparently mentions Satyāáraya's drg-vijaya (cf, our inscription below, lk. 5-6), some of his titles, and the Bame (font) and home (Mülavallı) of the writer.

THREE INSCRIPTIONS FROM HOTTUR.

mēdhada phalan ali 12 dari pancha-maha-pataka Besa-geydan Indēsy&(sva)ragêriya Machoja 1 
TRANSLATION. (Lines 1-3.) The cyclic year Plavamga, (corresponding to the 929th (year) of the saka era, being current when Rājarāja Nitya-vinoda Rajēndra-vidyadhara, ornament of the Chola race, Nürmadi-Chõla, came accompanied by a host of nine-hundred thousand (men), halted at Donavurg, and was ravaging the whole country, perpetrating morders of women, children, and Brāhmaṇs, seizing women, and overthrowing the order of caste, 
(Lunes 3-7.) Hail the auspicious king of kinge, supreme Lord, supreme Master, Akalankacharita Irivabedanga, ornament of the Chalukya race, slayer of Tamils, the auspicious king Satyāśraya, drove away the Chola, captured his trains of baggage-waggone, and made a triumphal progress through the South; 
(Lines 7-11.) And while (in the course thereof), being at the ghatjaof Tavare, he was reigning over the circle of the ocean-sealed earth under the shadow of his single parasol, at what time.., was exercising the office of county-gāvunda over the Pānungal Five-hundred, (and) ... follower of the courses of Mand, servant of Somēśvara, was exercising the office of gāvunda over Pottiyür, the beadle Gojjiga defended the kine of the b robbers were carrying them off ... and rose to honour in paradise. The Thousand of the betel-sellers in assembly granted 1 vīsa for each or in perpetuity. 
(Lines 11-12.) To him who preserves this there shall be the same reward as for en asramédna sacrifice; he who violates it incurs the guilt of the five deadly sins. Möchöja of Indēsvaragēri executed the order. 
B.OF THE REIGN OF JAYASIMHA II : SAKA 959. This record is cut upon a stone which was found somewhere in Survey No.91 ; the exact site I do not know. The slab has a rounded top, with sculptures : in the centre a linga on a stand ; on the proper right a cow (?); above it, the sun (to right) and moon (to left). The inscribed area below this is about 6 ft. 1 in. high and 2 ft 114 in. wide. The character is Kanarese, of a rather irregular band of the period. The letters vary in height from about 1 in. to in ; they are largest at the beginning. The inscription is rather worn, and it is often quite uncertain whether the sonne is written. In the first half of the record the cursive y (above, Vol. XII P. 335) is more usual than the tripartite form; the cursive m appears thrice, the corsive u thrice.com The language, except for the standing formule of verses 3 and 4, is Old Kanarose Tle / is 
» Or neradu: the letter is not clear. 
Pobøbly Marayyan. Bithor “mountain-range," or "quay." 
76 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
NA 
preserved in ilda[m], l. 2, ildu, 1. 41, negald-, l. 19, and irregularly in palum, 1. 42; it is replaced by i in pelavara, 1 16, alid=, l. 43, alıda, l. 44, and perhaps balry=, l. 37. Initial p is kept thronghout Of some lexical interest are , ladda-lāgula, 1. 32, and vadda-lārula, 1 37 
(for the more usual form vadda-rāzula), pannakēni, l. 32, and chatta, 1. 24. 
The record opens with a short statement of a grant made by the three controllers of tases of the county (1l. 1-3). It then refers itself to the reign of Jayasimha (IL) Jagadēkamalla (11. 4-6), and states that at the time of the endowment to be chronicled Akkā-dēvi? (the sister of Vikramaditya V, on whom see Dyn. Kanar. Distr, pp. 435, 437. 439 f) was ruling the Banavāsi Twelve-thousand (11 6-7), the mana-mandalēśtara Mayūravarma-dēva, 65 lord of Banavāsi best of cities” and “a lion for Harikānta," was administering the bame province and the Panungal Five-hundred (ll. 8-12); Māra Gāvunda of Pottiyar, who is described as "a brother-in-law to the lane" (cf. inscription C. below, ll. 16-17) and hence by reason of this service to the physically afflicted as "a tiittha (holy place, where the sick and crippled resort for divine help) in the midst of the county, a Sömanātha (Sömnāth) of the south," was serving as prabhu or sheriff of the Pänungal Five-hundred (il 13-22); the Kannada-sandhivigraha (minister for affairs of peace and war in the Kannada country) and general Chāvanarasa, who is described among other epithets as a chaita to Singa (possibly Jarasimha II), a comet (or fire) to the Konkan, an uprooter of Pannala, a grindstone to Baleyayattans, a sbatterer of the pride of the fortress of Bijavādi, and a drśa-patta to Döra, was rnling the Belvala Three-hundred and the Purigere Three-hundred (1l. 23-29), and the pergade Akalimayya was controlling the taxation of Belvala and Purigere (1) 29-32) Then follows the specification of the endowment (Il. 32-42), by which certain high revenue officials arranged for the division of the tolls on betel-leaves between the various taxation-departments and assigned a proportion for the upkeep of the Kemgere, or “Red Tank,” presumably in or near Pottiyūr. The record ends with a moral verse written by the town-clerk Dāsımayya or Dāsiga. 
It is worthy of note that the Banavāsi province was at this time under the rule of both Akka-dēvi and Mayūravarman The fact suggests that there was some close connection between the two, such as that of husband and wife; and this inference is supported by the in scription 0, below, which shews that Akkı-dēvi's son, the Kādamba mahā-mandalēs ara Toyima dēva, possessed titles very similar to those bome in the present record by Mayoravarman. Both were “lords of Banayāsı best of cities" ; Mayūravarman is Harrh[@*]ntana simga (B., 1 10), Toyima-dēva is Harigana singa (C., l. 13). It seems therefore reasonable to infer that Mayūravarman was married to Akka-dēvi, and that Toyima-dēva was their son. Mayūra varman's title Harikāntana simga," lion of Harikānta," seems to point to some services rendered to a king of that name, who may have been a predecessor (perhaps the grandfather) of the Kādamba Harikësarin or Hariga of Bankāpūr; see above, Vol. XIII, p168 f., and below, inacr. C. 
The date is specified on 1. 34 as : Saka 959, Îśvara ; Mārgasira suddha 11; a Monday. This is regular : the given tithr corresponded to Monday, 21 November, A.D. 1037, on which day it ended at 11 h, 50 m. after mean sunrise (for Ujjain). 
The places mentioned are Pottiyur, .e. Hottür (11. 19, 34); the Banavasi Twelve-thousand (11 7, 12, 32 ; spelt Vanavāse on 1. 7); the town of Banavägi (1. 8); Sõmanātha (1. 17); the Panungal Five-hundred (11. 12, 22, 32, 38); the Konkan (1. 26); Pannāla (1. 26) ; Baleya Yattada (1. 26); Bijavīņi (1. 27); Dora (1. 27), the Belvala Three-hundred (1. 28); the

Purigere or Puligere Three-hundred (1l. 28, 39); the Six-hundred composed of Belyala and Pulligere (11 31, 39); Mälavalli (1 36), Kallavana (1 36); the Ninety-six ( 40). the Ker cere or " Red Tank" (11. 41, 42), and Banarasi, 2.e. Benares (1 43), Soma nátha is of coure the famous sanctuary of Somnath in Junågarh State , and Pänungal is now Hanzal. Palnis elsewhere termed also Pannaleya-kote, Pannāle-durga, Pranālaka-durga, and Parimauāla-iarra, is now Panbalā, about 12 miles NW. of Kolhāpūr (see Dyn Kanar Distr, p 5491. Baleya yattana is mentioned again in Ep. Carn., VOL II (Inscr. of Sratanı Belgola), Vo 50 (cf. 3101. introd., p 41, and Dyn Kanar. Distr, p 496). I venture to identify it with the modern Baia pattam (more correctly written Valapattanam), Ivino in lat. Charakkal taluha of Malabar District, a few miles NW of Cannanore, Baliapattam wa-a place of considerable importance in early times; it is the Balui patna (xrongly mten in die editions as Bultipatna) of Ptolemy's Geography, VII i § 6, and apparently the Palna zim: f the perplus (cf McCrindle, Ancient India as described by Ptolemy, p 45, and id. Commy*** and Narigation of the Erythrean Sea, pp 127, 129, Lassen, Alterthümer, III, pp 181, 183;, iu there is much likelihood in Kern's view that Ptolemy's Balaipatna is the Baladérapattapa ren tioned in Varaba-milira's Dirhat-samhrtā, XIV 16. Bijavādi is uncertain it mar conceivably he the modern village of Bijwädgi near Hungund. TRANSLATION. (Lines 1-3).. The three controllers of taxes of the county in assembly, inspired by piety, graciously assigned in addition to the six loads previously in usage (for the income of the sanctuary) 1 load more, altogether 7 loads. He who fails to make the grant shall incur the guilt of the five deadly sins, as though he destroyed cows and Brāhmaṇs. 
(Lines 4-6.) When the reign of hail !--the asylum of the whole world, favourite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, ornament of Satyāśraya's race, embellishment of the Chālukyas, king Jagadēkamalla-Jayasinga, was advancing in a course of successively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars :--- 
(Lines 6-7) While she who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet, Akkı-dēvi, was ruling the Vanavāse Twelve-thousand with enjoyment of pleasant conversations 
(Lines 8-12.) While-mhail !the Mabā-Mandalēšvara, who has obtained the fire great musical sounds, lord of Banavāsi best of towns, who bears all titles such as "he whose

2 Apparently como names bave been omittad. * Read phalam. * Kead krimin.

(Verse 1) Māra of Pottiyür, zllustrious for his pre-eminence in the goodly qualities of bounty, plulanthropy, knowledge, devotion to Siva, (and) trathfulness, is rich in esteem, noble: 
(Verse 2.) Of Māra Gāyunda it may be said that he knows the meaning of fame, that he is praised by sages, truthful, politic, gracious, comely of person, observant of the courses of Vant, eminent in virtue, a gem of his götra, (than who) what higher thing is there on the whole earth ?--- 
(Line 22) Was thus holding the shrievalty over the Pānungal Five-hundred : 
(Lines 23-29) While hall lathe High Commander for affairs of peace and war, wha has obtained the five great musical sounds, the great august general, wrestler with hosts of fces, chatta for Suðga, tree of desire for dependents, wishing-gem for servants, a Käpina Karnk] in truthfulness, leader in battle, demon to adversaries, lion to the deer his enemies, giving abundantly and forgetting it, displaying enterprise, buffeter of the malignant, wrestler with mountain fastnesses, & comet to the Konkan, an uprooter of Pannāļa, a grindstone to Baleyavattana, a shatterer of the pride of the fortress of Bijavādi, a scatterer of Dora, a bee to the lotus-feet of king Jagadēkamalla, minister for affairs of peace and war in the Kannada (country), the General Chavanaraga, was ruling the Belvala Three-hundred and the Purigere Three-hundred with enjoyment of pleasant conversations : 
(Lines 29-32.) While one who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet,bail he who possesses all titles such as * illustrious in the office of high minister appointed for the administration of the whole kingdom, exalted in dignity, having the three powers of lordship, counsel, and enterprise, teacher of weal for his master, immovable in firmness, a man of Talour in accordance with the name," the superintendent Akalimayya, was administering the taxation of the two (provinces of Belrala and Puligere forming) a Six-hundred, 
(Lines 32-34.) Sangayayya, controller of the taxes of the pannakéni vadda-lāgula, 5 Chāvundamsyys, controller of the taxes of the Banavāsi Twelve-thousand, and Dūdiyanma,

controller of the taxes of the seigniories of the Pānungal Five-hundred, being together in assembly - 
(Lines 34-42) On Monday, the eleventh day of the bright fortnight of Mārgaśıra in the cyclic year Iśvara, the 959th (year) of the Saka era, gave to the Thirty, headed by Māra Gāvunda of Pottiyur, Gakaruva Surimayya, Poleyamma Gētımayya, the superintendent Bühimayya, and the town-clerk Dãsımayya, and to the four towns, namely the towns of Mülavalli and Kallavana, an edictal regulation of the following tenour: granting on each load of betel-leaf eighteen (leares), and excepting the loads of balt-betel,l the controllers of the taxes of the vadda-larula shall diaw ten zisa on each load , the main-tax of the Pānungal Five hundred and the seignional tax thereof jointly shall draw twelve vīsa on each load regularly ; the controllers of the main-tax of the two (p1 Ozunces of Belzala and Pulgere forming) a Six hundred shall draw ffteen līsa on each load, the controllers of taxes of the seigniories in the Puligere county shall draw five risa on each load, the controllers of taxes of the seigniories of the Ninety-six shall draw one rīsa on each load iegularly. The above tax-officers in assembly shall assign to this Kemgere the tax of six loads as annual income The Thousand of betel traders granted to this Kemgere one risa on each load. 
(Lines 42-44 ) So to him who guards this pious foundation, not sufferng it to be injured, there shall be the same fruit as if he performed a horse-sacrifice, to him who violates at there shall be the guilt of the five deadly sins, as though he destroyed at Benares a thousand kine and a thousand Brāhmans versed in the Four Vēdas 
(Verses 3-4: two common Sanskrit verse-formulæ ) 
(Verse 5) . . . . . . be not defeated, on the stage of battle bend not, take not back what has been given ..doly, take now no bribe There is a sevenfold? hell for men. Thus verily saith Dåsiga. 
(Line 48) So the follower in the courses of Manu . . . . . . the town-clerk. Dāsimayya has written. 
C.-OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA I: SAKA 988. This is upon a slab found by the honda or tank in the village. The stone has a rounded top divided vertically into three compartments containing sculptures : in the central one is a linga on a stand ; in that on the proper right is a seated votary facing full front, with the sun and moon above, in that on the left, a cow and sucking calf The inscribed area below this is 3 ft. 101 in. high and 3 ft 6 in. wide. The characters are good Kanarese of the period, but consi derably worn, so that it is often difficult to arrive at certainty in the reading of details such as the sonne The letters are from in to in high The cursive y (above, Vol XII, p. 335) 19 used in Poitiyür= (1 5) --The language is Old Kanarese, except for the formal Sanskrit verses on 11. 40-42. The l appears in wlda, for ilda or irda (1 15), negaldan (1. 18), nalo (1. 22), ildu (11. 22, 32), it is changed to l in Chola (1. 4), pelatamge (1. 17), alid- (1. 39), and to rin bēr kulē (1 17) Initial p is preserved, except in the name Handıyür (1 6). The upadhmānīya is found in the Sanskrit bhāginan=po (1. 41) Words of lexical interest are : kuttumbittr ( 
16), garuli (1. 12 : Kittel has garudr), bamgāra (1 13 apparently to be distinguished from bamgāra), baruhi (1. 28: for Sanskrit barhr), sote (1 32 : possibly connected with Sanskrit sudha), poge-voge (1 34), pada-bara (1. 35), bojanga (1. 37), ugura (1 37). On the nominativally used genutzve Kesi Gāvundana in l. 32 see J. R. A. 8, 1918, p 105. 
The record first refers itself in 11. 1-3 to the reign of Trailökyamalla-dhayamalla (Sõmēśvara I), and then mentions one of his feudatories, the Mabá-Mandalēsvara Jēmarasa, as 
1 I do not know whether ball here means a special kind of betel, or signifies "guft." * This is also the Jain number. Mana speaks of 21.82 
EPIGRAPHIA. INDICA. 
(VOL XTI. 
L. 
M 
WWWWANYM WWW 
ruling over Pottiyür, Elavattı, Nittasingi, Handiyür, and many other towns and kuttumbitta as an anugu-jiinta or "love-fief” (11. 3-6). Jēmarasa among other titles is described as “l submarine fire to the ocean of the Chola's hosts" (see Dyn. Kanar. Distr., p 436) and as “a 
m to Bhoja," namely the Paramāra Bhoja of Malwa (ibid.) The record then introduces Jēmarasa's son, the Mahäsãmanta Jõyiyarasa, as governing Pottiyur as a huunari tritts or “ prince's fief " (11 6-8), and then gives at great length the titles and dignities of the Kādamba Maha-Nandalēśvara Töyıma-dēva, “ lord of Banävasi best of towns," " Warrior for Mēruga," * lion of Hariga," etc., who at this time was administering the Banavāsı Twelve-thousand and the Pānungal Five-hundred (11. 8-14). Of this Toyıma-dēva we bare already spoken (see above, inscr. B., and Dyn. Kan. Distr., pp. 435, 504). His title “lion of Hariga" seems to indicate services rendered to his kinsman the Kadamba Hariga or Harıkösarin of Bankāpür, whose record of Saka 977 has been published by me above, Vol. XIII, p 108 ff. 
Our inscription now introduces Göduvara Māra Gāvunda of Pottiyūr (11. 15-18). Māra's acquaintance we have already made in inscription B; we here learn the reason for the title “ brother-in-law to the lame,” which is given to him there (1 16), for here we are told that to many footless men Tho came to seek his favour he gave feet. What precisely is meant by this is not clear. It may be that Māra furnished them with wooden legs; it may be that he supplied them Tith medical treatment (or perhaps even faith-healing). Be this as it may, he gained a great reputation, and was called “a southern Sāmanātha » (as in inscr B). We next learn that his son Chalukya-Ganga-Vermadi Keśava (Kēsirāja or Kesi) Gāyunda tras at the tine serving as Gävunda of Pottiyur (11. 18-22). Kēsı obtained from the Kadamba king Hariga (Barık sarın of Bankapür, to whom we have referred in the last paragraph) all the emblems of u lty (11 23-21), and receired similar honours from king Chalukya Ganga-Vermāđı (Vikramaditya VI: cf. the Bankäpūr inscription, 1 10, abore, Vol. X111, p. 170), who, regarding hin as a son, gave him his own Dame (11. 24-26). Besides making various bountiful gifts to men of eminence (1l. 27-28), Kësi constructed a temple of Siva with the title of Kēšavēśvara (11. 28-30) For this temple an endowment was granted by Jöyıyarasa, Töyima-dēva, and Mailala-dēvi (11. 30-35) Who this Mailala-dēvi was does not appear, possibly she was Tõyimi-dēva's wife As a supplement to this endowment, Toyima-dēva's mother Akkā-dēvi (on whom see above, inscr B) assigned to the monastery the fee due to her on the occasion of "laying the feet," formally transferring it to the nan Gangikabbe (11 35-37) It is interesting to find a woman holding such a representative position in a community of Saiva ascetics Finally we learn that the inscription was composed by the poet Rājavallabha, and was corrected and amplified by Chandra Bhatta (see J. 
R S, 1920, p. 377 m) and Balabhadra dēva ; the mason was Dasõja (l1, 43-44). 
The date is specified on 11 30-31 as : Saka 988, the cyclic year Parābhaya, the full-moon of Pausbra; Sanday, the nakshatra Hastā; the uttarayana-scńhianti, azyatipāta This is gnerously incorrect, af we reckon according to the Southern cycle. The full-moon of Paushya in the given year accordingly fell on Wednesday, 3 January, A.D. 1067, on which day the full-moon tithe ended 11 L, 16 m. after mean sunrise. This tithi corresponded to the nakshatic Pushyā, not Hastă, and the uttarayana-samkrāiti occurred on Sunday, 24 December, A.D 1066, when the naksutra was Pärya-Phalguni. On the other hand, if we calculate by the Northern crele, the titlul Trould correspond to Sunday, 26 December, A.D. 1084, on which day it ended about 12 h. 21 m. after mean sunnase ; but the uttarayana-sanhiantz of that year took place 21 . 53 m. alter menn sunrise on Thursday, 23 December, and the izrihshatra at mean sunı ise on tha 
3 
Sercial cases of faith-healing for lameness are recorded in the inscriptions of Epidados Bechtel, Saini iwny darle67. Dialekt-Inschriften, III, W., Nos. 3339, 33-10, 
see Collitz 2114 
No. 11] 
THREE INSCRIPTIONS FROM HOTTUR. 
83 
full-moon day of Paushya was Punaryasu. Calculation by mean longitudes and motions will not remove these discrepancies ; for it gives as tithi and week-day the same date (Sunday, 26 December, A.D. 1064), with Friday, 24 December, for the uttarayana-sankranti, and Panarvasu. as nakshatra. 
The places mentioned are: Pottiyur (11. 5, 8, 15, 22, 30, 32 f.), Elavatti (1. 6), Nittasingi (1. 6), Handyür (1. 6), the Male or Highlands (1. 11), Banavāsi (1. 11), the Banavası Twelvem thousand (1. 14), the Pānungal Five-hundred (1. 14), and Kövagere (1. 33 f ) Elavatti is the village called Yelawati in the Bombay Postal Directory and Yalvattı in the Bombay Survey ; it lies in Hangal taluka, in lat. 14° 51% and long. 75o 10%. Nittasingi is now Nidsingi (Nidsangi in the Bombay Survey), in the same täluka, in lat. 14° 52' and long. 75o 101. Handıyūr I cannot locate, unless (which I doubt) it is to be identified with “Handihál" of the Survey, a village 4 miles nearly west of Hāngal town, in lat. 14° 45%' and long. 759 53

TRANSLATION. (Lines 1-3) When the victorious reign of-bail !the asylum of the whole world, favourite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, ornament of Satyaśraya's race, embellishment of the Chāļukyas, king Trailökyamalla-Ahavamalla, was advancing in a course of successively increasing prosperity, (to endure) as long as moon, sun, and stars 
(Lines 3-6) While one who finds sustenance at his lotus-feet, the Mahā-Mlandalēśvara who has obtained the five great musical sounds, possessing all titles of honour such as “ a Mabesvara in the fray, a lion in valour, a Bhairava on the stage of battle, a wishing-gem to servants, a head-jevel of men of valour, a Rådhêya [Karna] in truthfulness, an Aõjanēga in purity, delightful to the world, mighty in boldness, an armour to his lord, giving bounty? to sages, a submarine fire to the ocean of the Chola's host, a flame of doom to Bhöja, a teacher of both forces, 3 having the firmness of Mandara, the tiger of king Ābavamalla,” the Mahā-Mandala. śvara Jemarasa, was ruling over many towns, beginning with Pottiyur, Elavatti, Nittasingi, and Faņdiyür,-and kuttumbrtti, as a love-fief* : 
(Lines 6-8.) While his son, the Mahäsämanta who has obtained the five great musical sounds, bearing all titles such as “ beloved of warriors' Fortune,, wrestler of earth, shaft in foemen's hearts, his father's rutting elephant, causing destruction of enemies, a Nárasinga Vishnu Krishna] to princely Naras," the Mahāsamanta Joyiyarasa, was ruling Pottiyur as a prince's 
fief : 
(Lanes 8-14) While he who is an ornament of the Kādamba race (which is descended] from the hero of the bright frontal eye [Tnlochana Kadamba] who sprang from the grace of tlie supreme Lord Hara, whose lotus-feet are praised by the peoples of all the world, and of the lady Earth; which (race) has established its might on the massive peaks of the King of Moun tains ; which (1 ace) has performed eighteen horse-sacrifices by the manifest quality of its arms; which is resplendent with three flattering white parasols; which has its pure chivalry illa minated by many royal attrbutes of empire such as dignity, etc. he who is (saluted) with the noise of permatți drums and (other) musical instruments, the Mahā-Mandalösyara who has obtained the five great musical sounds, lord of Banavāsi best of cities, bearing all titles of 
might to adversaries, sun to the Highlands, ever active in truth, Añjaneya in purity, Brahman in assemblies, Shanmukha in the front of battle, Thousand-armed 
Kártavirya] with balls,6 Rāhu in the fray, Parasu-Rămâ to the resorts of foes, . . . of titles, bearing the royal stamp (?) of a Bhima, bangāra of title-bearers, warrior to Mēruga, exalted in high spirit, lion of Hariga," the Maha-Mandaleśvara Toyima-dēva, was reigning in the 
1 This reading is rather ancertain. 
2 See above, Vol. XIV, p. 189. - $ Infantry and moanted troops ? [The two opposing troops.-H K. $.] 
4 I anderstand this as mole or less equivalent to the term prīti-godagr in Ep. Cam., XII. (Tamkūr), Ck. 2, see Kittel, p. 1706, 8 v. anugu. 
See above. Vol. XIII, p. 173, and ref. 
| This seems to mean that he tosses about his enemies' beads like balls in such numbers that he appears to have 8 thousand ariik. 
No. 11.] 
THREE INSCRIPTIONS FROM HOTTUR. 
government of the Vanavāsı Twelve-thousand and the Pānungal Five-hundred with enjoy. ment of pleasant conversations - 
(Verse 1) This Pottiyur is a general ghatikā-sthānal in the county, in it Māra, composed of mind, a treasure of becoming speech, has dwelt happily in the office of Gāyuņda. 
(Verse 2) The wealthy, when entreated, may give abundant substance to the needy, (but) they do not give in this wise anything unique and unprecedented in this world, whereas, when footless men came with entreaties, Māra Gavunga by his own power gave feet to many Hence is it needful to tell in this and that wise the high degree of the quality of bus goodness? 
(Verse 3) As the earth spoke of him as a peer of Manu in virtue and power, as a southern Sömanātha? because of his giving feet to the lame, Māra in truth was illustrious, a noble man. 
(Line 18.) While Göduvara Māra Gāvunda, thus combining philanthropy with worldly success, was acting as Gāyunda his son, 
(Verse 4.) As the moon is born from the ocean, the sun from the Eastern Mountain, Kēsi, a worthy son arising in the goodly family of the Göduvas, yon fame as an ornament of his race. 
(Lines 19-22.) While he who bears all titles of honour such as " basis of the series of many yirtues praised by all the world, remote from others' wives, a king Vatsa with horses, 3 a Cupid to public women, a discus of justice to the troop of Māra,+ an ocean of the essence of order, 
varrior of the bodyguard, an incarnation of Vira [Vīrabbadral, a mighty man of valoar in courage, a bherundas to foes, a Pärtha [Arjuna] to hostile armies, a site of salvation in the centre of the country, a wishing-gem of bounty, a protective gem to sages, servant of Somēśyara, brilliant in culture, a Nārāyana to foes," Chalukya-Ganga Vermadı Keśava Gāvunda, was acting as Gāvunda over Pottiyür in the county-shrieralty amem 
(Verse 5 ) He received from king Hariga, the head of the Kādamba race, many tokens of royalty, to wit, a number of yak-tail fans, a flag, a palace, drums, conches, parasols of many peacock-feathers, and a white parasol, (so that he became) radiant with manifested intense lustre : for this reason, oh bravo ! thus was the brilliance of Kēsi's distinction in the abode of this world. 
(Verse 6.) The king Chalukya-Ganga-Vermādı [Vikramaditya), pleased with Kēsi and loving him, said " this man is to me a son, Chāļukya-Ganga-Vermādi," and gave him that name, 
(Verse 7) With supreme generosity the blest king Vikramaditya gave the various royal emblems of the Gangas and Chalukyas, to wit, the honour of the excellent white parasol, a pair of golden yak-tail fans, a flag, warriors' drums, a parasol of peacocks feathers : this distinction comes to the lord Kēsırāja ; does it come to any other man? 
(Verse 8 ) By the merits of gifts of water and a quantity of gold and food, by gifts of kine, by gifts of land,' by gifts of herds of oxen, by gifts of divers kinds of knowledge, by constant gifts, by gifts of excellent sesam, by gifts of all kinds of) maidens Kosava has gratified distinguished men: truly he possesses a right mind.

(Verse 9.) Having consecrated Sankara, the giver of fruits desired by his worshippers, the annihilator of guilt, the wearer of ornaments consisting of snakes, (and) having constructed a great abode perfect in holiness, worshipful, built of stone, and made with brilliant lofty archways, Kēsi has enjoyed the beauty of the goddess of radiant glory. 
(Lines 30-35.) Thus Permadı Kēsı Gāvuņda of Pottiyür and the Thirty being in happy estate,bail lon Sunday, the full-moon day of the bright fortnight of Paushya in the cyclic year Parābhava, the 988th (year of the centuries lapsed since the time of the Saka king, under the constellation Eastā at the uttarayana-sankranti, in the uyatipāta, the Mahā samanta Jõyiyarasa and the Mahamandalesvara Toyima-dēva and Mallala-dēvi jointly granted a religions foundation to the temple of the god Kesavēśvara above the bank of the tank constructed by Permāời Kēsi Gavunda of Pottiyür, as follows:--for plastering of the temple, for an officiant priest, for the god's scents, incense, lamps, and oblations, for drummers, a dancing woman, and flute-players, they granted in the pada-bara with pouring of water to the god Kéśavëśvara after worshipping the god a field of four mattar west of Kõvagere, north of the betel-sheds, and the tax of a pana and a quarter on the ... house belonging to the magistracy of Pottiyur, and the petty (?) tax on houses under seigniorial authority, for as long as moon, sun, and stars. 
(Lines 35-38.) Akka-dēvi, the mother of Toyima-dēva, having laved the feet of the ascetic lady Gangikabbe, who practises austerities, minor disciplines, prayer, and absorption, at the same time granted with pouring of water for the dispensation of teaching at the monastery the tax of two gadyana, the fee for washing the feet, which (hitherto) had accrued to her, This monastery. . . establishment of ascetics, this pious foundation the Gävunda, the Thirty, the hundred and four Bogargas of the betel-gardens, the three-hund sellers of prepared betel, and the three controllers of the taxes of the county shall protect as donors. 
(Lines 38-40 : a prose formula of the usual type.) (Verses 10-12 : three common Sanskrit verses.) 
(Verse 13 ) Rājavallabha, a good poet of clever speech brilliant with bright words, a treasure of discretion, composed . . . . . . wrote it; it was Chandra Bhatta, lord of language, and the Master Balabhadra-dēva who amplified and corrected it Truly this edict has become a teacher to the three worlds. 
(Line 44.) Dasõja executed the order. Happiness ! 
No. 12-THE JAMBUKESVARAM GRANT OF VIJAYARANGA CHOKKANATHA 
NAYAKA: SAKA 1630. 
By $. V. VISWANATHA, M.A., TRICHINOPOLY. This inscription is on a single copper-plate bored at the top It was kindly given for ex amination by the Samkarā hārya of the Kumbhakopam matha. I edit the inscription from inked impressions of the plate prepared by me. 
The plate has a semi-circular curvature at the top, including which it measures 10 in. in height and 6-3 in, in breadth. It is in good preservation. It contains 46 lines in all, including the signature at the bottom and Sri-Chandramaultsvara-svāmi at the top of the first side. The inscription, which runs across the breadth of the plate, is legible and is in prose. The semi circular portion of the plate at the top is worth notice. It contains an illustration which may 
Is yoga in wbich the declination of the sun is equal to that of the moon. 
* See above, Vol. XIII, p. 15 and 1. 
No. 12.] 
JAMBUKESVARAM GRANT OF SAKA 1630. 
www. 
w 
ww 
www. 
wwwwwwwwww 
be taken to convey to us the traditional history regarding the origin of the god Jambukēbvaz 
in Trichinopoly. The illustration itself includes the figures of the sun and the moon, a tree supposed to take its root from the head of a devotee seated below with folded bands (añjali) in 
stare, a linga placed on a pedestal underneath the tree, an elephant with its tronk raised over the linga, a spider-like creatare flying above the liriga and a goddess standing on the right. The figures of the sun and the moo. are perhaps indicative of the overlordship of the Vijayanagara house over the Nāyakas of the south, the sun and the noon being found on the seal and coins of the Vijayanagara kings. There is a belief, as recorded in the Sthala purāna of Jambukēśvaram, that the place was called after Janbūka Muni, from whose bead the jambūku tree had its origin. The elephant and the spider, it is believed, worshipped the liiga representing the God Jambukēśvara and attained salvation. The Irriga on the pedestal is the god of Jambu kēśvaram, and the goddess represented as standing on the right side is probably Akhiländēšvari. 
of the inscription is Telaga and Sanskrit combined. Lines 1-3, which contain the epithets of the donee, are in Sanskrit. Lines 4-35 are in Telugu, and lines 35-44 are in Sanskrit, containing the admonitory verses at the end of the plate. The characters of the inscription are Telagu. 
There are a few orthographical peculiarities worth noticing. There is an unnecessary reduplication of consonauts in @mamddu (1. 15); nadipimchcha' and ajñāpinchcm 
mangalaṁllo (1. 22), puramllo (1.23); Jeñbbukaśvaran (1. 28); viãyinchchi (1, 33) and anubhaviíchchu (1. 34). Instances of dravidianised forms of Sanskrit words are seen in Otaņbrao for "tamrao (1. 21); să mbrājyan instead of osīmrajyan (1.9) and oubhaya in the place of ubhaya (30-1). 
The inscription records the grant of lands in certain villages in the Trichinopoly district and some lands on both sides of the Kåvērı river for the conduct of worship, offerings and charities in the Samkarächārya matha at Jambukēśvaram (Tiruvanaikāval), where even now the head of the Kumbhakopam matha has his residence for a portion of the year. The grant was made by Vijayaranga Chokkanātha Nayaka at the instance of the then presiding guru of the matha. The name of the latter is not explicitly given in the giant. He is styled Lokaguru Srimad Sankaracharya Svāmulavāru. 
The objects for which the grant was made were annadāna kattala (endowment for gift of food) and the naivedya which was to be offered to the god. For the former purpose certain lands wera granted. These were situated in Mahēndramangalam, Krishņā param, Kāraikkādu, Kondayam, ēttai, Mangamāmbūpuran, Angāru and Ariyamangalam. For the naivedya, which was to include foar measures (pado) of cooked rice, daśai, atirasa, sugiya and dipam chamaru (oil for lights), it was ordered that certain tolls collected should also be assigned. 
The grant is dated Śaka 1632, Vikriti, Kārtika, Suddha, full moon, Monday, Robiņi nakshatra. 
Vijayaranga Chokkanātha and his line are said to belong to the Dakshina-sinhāsana, styl ing themselves Dakshina-sinhāsan-adhyakshāh (Lords of the southern throne'). They were Viceroys in the south, acting under the kings of Vijưyanagara. They were lords of the regions of the Påndyas, comprising Madura and Tinnevelly districts. The circumstances under which the Näyakas became rulers of the south are recorded thus. In 1558 " the then Chola ruler 
* [The symbols of san and moon are quite common in all Chalukya inscriptions also. They are not peculiarly the symbols of the Vijayanagara royalty. These in my opinion indicate the a-chandr-ārka-sthayrtā of the gift conveyed by the document over which they are engraved --H. K. S.] 
* Dipam chamaru is the supply of oil for lamps in addition to the offerings which were to be made to the 
god.

invaded the Madara country and dispossessed the Pāņdya king. Whereupon the latter ap pealed to the Court of Vijayanagar, and an expedition under a certain Nägama Nāyakkan was accordingly sent to his aid. Nagama easily suppressed the Chola king and possessed himself of Madara; but he then suddenly threw off his allegiance and, declining to help the Pånd ya, assumed the position of an independent ruler. The Vijayapagar emperor was furious at his defection, suminoped a council, laid the matter before his most faithfal officers, and cried ont to the assemblage, “Wbere anongst you all 18 he who will bring me that rebel's head!'" Visva Dātha, the son of Năgama, promised this, captured his father in battle and placed him in con finement, only to be released later on. The Pandya king nominally held sway over Madura, but the new Nãşaka régime “developed first into a governorsbip, whiob became hereditary, and then into pbat was practically a hereditary monarchy." The Nāyakas “ were content with the position of Leutenants under Vijayanagar ; bat in essentials their sway was practically absolate and the Pandyas disappear in effect henceforih from history." 
The general character of the administration of the Nayaka kingdom of Madara is thus dwelt on by Caldwelll :--Their reigns record little more than & disgraceful catalogue of de haucheries, trcacheries, planderings, oppressions, murders and civil commotions, relieved only by the factitious splendour of gifts to temples, idols and priests, by means of which they appar entir succeeded in getting the Brahmans and poets to speak well of them, and thus in keeping the mass of the people patient ander their misrule." 
The genealogy of the Nāyaka dynasty of Madura, so far as known, may be given thus : - 
). Nägama. 2. Visvanātha I.

1731–1736 Our recoid states the genealogy from Chokkanātba (No 11 of the above list) downwards, and Vijayaranga Chokkanātha is strled a descendant of Vibyanātha (probably I), the real foander of the Nāyaka kingdom of Madara. He was the son of Ranga Krishna Mattu Vilappa Nã,aka, and in his eaily years from 1689 1704 Mangammāl, his grandmother, acted as regent She was an able and charitable woman, and under her " Madura apparently all but regained the proud position it had beld in the days of Tirumal” Vijayaranga Chokkanáthe took charge of the administration from 1704 and ruled till 1731. He was a weak ruler, "was vain and weak-minded ard unfit to govero bimself or others. His reign was distinguished by the ill regulated and extraordinary munificence of his gifts to Brahmans and religious institutions. The injustice of his rule caused a serious riot in Madura, the mutiny of the whole of his troopa and incessant internal commotions.*3

To 125 he entered into a war with Tanjore over the question of succession to the throne of Ramnad, in which the Raja of Tanjore obtained a decisive victory. He died in 1731, and wag sncceeded by an adopted son. Mīnākshi, his queen, acted as regent. It was daring her time that a quarrel broke out between her and Vaögåra Tirumala, the father of the adoptel gon. It was at this time that the Nawab of Arcot sent two of his generals to co lect tribute from Madura. The kingdom divided in itself, fell an easy prey to the inyader, and from 1735 the Nayaka kingdom of Madura ceased to exist as such. 
We are told in the inscription that Vijayaranga Chokkanātha Nayaka Was Toling in the south when a certain Veäkata-dēva Mahārāya, his overlord, was the rajā of Vijayanagara, raling from his capital Ghanagiri. He is styled Rajadhiraja and Virapratā pa and is said to have his seat at Ghanagiri, whioh has been identified with. Penukonda.

Chokkanātha Nayaka, is according to the above table Venkata V, who ruled, with Penukonda as his capital, over the domains of the Vijayanagara house. 
The grant does not mention explicitly the name of the donee. It is merely stated that it was made to the matha at the instance of the then head, who is styled Lokaguru Srimad. Sankaracharya-svāmulavára. 
We find, however, at the top of the first side of the plate, below the figures on the arch, the inscription Sri-Chandramaulīśvara-Svani It may also be noted that there is some blank space between 11. 3 and 4 and a short space between two horizontal strokes in l. 19. Chandra maalīśvara is the name by which the god of the Kumbhakonam matha is known, and the line at the top may possibly refer to the deity We are not in a position to account for the blank spaces between 11. 3 and 4 and in 1. 19. It will be seen that it would be appropriate if the Dame is taken as that of the Samkaráchārya and is inserted between the blank spaces. This is reasonable, as out of respect for the teacher the name of the latter may not be directly mentioned by the disciple or devotee. 
The tradition as regards the names of the Achāryas of the Kumbhakonam matha leads one to hold the above view It is to the effect that for over two centaries the Samkarachăryas of the Conjeeveram braoch have borne alternately the names Mahadēra and Ohandrachada or Chandramauli. Hence it is quite likely that the Samkarăchārya mentioned in our inscription should have had one of these two names. 
The Mēlapäka grant, dated 1608 Saka, 1 of Mahādēvēndra Sarasvati, the disciple of Chandra sökbara Sarasvati, records the fact of the grant of lands in the village of Melupåka by the former to a certain Răma Sāstrin. The present grant is dated Saka 1632, and it is probable that the Samkarāobārga of 1632 Saka was the one who succeeded him of 1608 Saka. 
On the foregoing grounds I hold that the name of the head of the matha at the time of the present grant was Chandramaalīśvara, which name is inserted on the top of the first side. 
The plate records a grant of land to the Samkara, matha at Tiruvanaikaval, and the details of the grant run as follow:

RAHATAREERTANJAR matam 
R$ of the Kämakoti patha for about two centuries pastio The Kamakoti ttof Kumbhakonami most at the time of our grant have been situated at Kāñcht. The migration of the Samkarăcbärga from Conjeeveram to the Kumbhakopam matha must have per med later than 1710 A.C. The tradition current in the Kumbhakonam matha is to the effect that Raja Sarabhoji of Tanjore built it for the Chandramanlīśvara Swamin, the deity Worshipped at the matha. This 18 corroborated by a stone inscription in the matha of the year 1743 Saka-1821 A.C. Thus from the evidence available it would appear that the Kumihar köņam matha was in existence only from the 19th century, while that at Tiruvānaikāyal mast have contioned in the possession of the Swămin at least from between the 13th century and 1720A.C., as the present epigraph shows.

TRANSLATION. Line 1. The Lord whose crest is adorned by the Moon. 
Ll. 2 & 3. To the lord Samkarācbärya, resident in Kanchipura, who is a paramahansa, and the most exalted of those who have renounced the world, 
Ll. 4-6. In the Saka year 1832 of Salivābana, in the year Vikriti, on Kārttika, on the full moon day, on Monday, when the star was Röhini, on this auspicious day, 
Ll. 7-9 When the king of kings, the supreme lord, vīrapratāpa Vēnkata-dēva Mahārāya was ruling over the earth, seated on his jewelled throne in Ghanagiri, 
LI 10-15. The lord of the Pandya eountry, who is enthroned as lord of the southern seat, of the Kassapa götra, the descendant of Viśyanātha Nayaka, the grandson of Chokkanātha Nayaka and the son of Ranga-Kșishna Muttu Virappa Nayaka, Vijayaranga Chokkanáths 
made to the lõkiguru (teacher of the world) Sankaracharyaswami,

Ll. 19-21. For (his) pleasure a perpetua) copper-plate grant for worship, offerings, feeding and general propitiations of Brahmapas as follows: 
Ll 21-28 4 half-mas and 1 tāru of bhattavritti Taad in Mahēndramangalam in Tottiyam sima, Gópāla-swâmin's garden ; 4 half-mās and 2 tõrus in Krishnapuram ; 4half más and 1 tāru in Kärakkādu; 2 seys of wet land in Kondayampēttai ; 8 seys of wet land in Mangamambapuram in Tiruchendorai sima ; 16 seys of wet land in Ariyür in Tinniyam 
fima ; 6 seys of wet land in Ariyamangalam in the South Konādu śāma,

LI, 32-35. Tbe deed having thus been settled and made for the above parpose, you and your line of disciples on the pontifical throne shall enjoy the lands and protect the charities as long as the sun and the moon run their course (i.e for all time) and grant me your blessings.

No. 13] 
THE INSCRIPTIONS ON THE BIMARAN VASE. 
No. 13.-THE INSCRIPTIONS ON THE BIMARAN VASE. 
BY F. E. PARGITER. 
This vase was found by Masson in the village of Bimarãn in the course of his excavations in Afghanistan during the years 1834-7. When excavating “ Tope no. 2" he found in its centre a small apartment containing relics. “They consisted of a good-sized globular vase, of alg or steatite, with a carved cover or hd, both of which were encircled with lines of inscriptions scratched with a stylet or other sbarp-pointed instrument The characters were Bactro-Pali. On removing the cover the vase was found to contain a small quantity of fine mould, in which were mingled a number of small burnt pearls, beads of sapphire, crystal, etc In the centre was standing a casket of pure gold; ...."-that is, apparently, not inside the vase, but in the centre of the small apartmenti Bimarān appears to be in the neighbourhood of Jallalabad. The vase is now in the British Museum. 
Two early attempts to decipher the inscriptions were made, and Dowson reconsidered them in 1863.3 M. Senart published some notes upon them.Dr Fleet had three photographs taken of the vase and its inscriptions, satisfactory ink-impressions being hardly possible, because the letters are scratched in the stone and the vase has suffered sundry scratches besides, which tend to interfere with the appearance of the letters. The photographs are reproduced in the annexed plate. Fig III shows the inscription on the cover, and figs. I and II give side views of the vase and together display the whole of the side inscription, which runs a little more than three quarters round it I have inspected the vase and compared the photographs carefully with the original inscriptions. 
The vase is carved out of brownish-grey stone Its height is 5 3 inches (15 7 cm.), and its greatest width 5 4 inches (15 9 cm.). It consists of a body and a separate lid or cover. In the underside of its base an oblong mortice has been cut, 1 inch (26 mm.) long, inch (16 mm.) wide and į inch (5 mm.) deep, which was evidently meant to receive a tenon to hold the vase. In the mortice are remains of vermilion colour. 
The two inscriptions are in Kharoshthi characters, which are not well made because the scratching tool seems to have slipped in places and distorted some of them. I call the inscrip tion on the lid (fig. III) inscription A, and that around the vase B. The latter begins at the ex treme right of fig. I and is continued into fig. II, where the first two letters are a repetition of the last two in fig. I. 
The main feature that requires notice is the sign for subscript r, a rightward stroke or curve at the bottom of the main letler. It is applied to g in bhagavata in A and B, but is not a real r. It is also applied to t, not only in putasa in A and B, but also in rachhrtasa in A and B, and bhagarata in B (though not apparently in A), and in these two words there can be no tr. Further, it is applied to me itself in rachhitasa in B, where of course it is impossible. It is clear therefore that the stroke or curve has no significance as a letter in these two inscriptions, and is a mere peculiarity or flourish. Hence it means nothing when applied to t in niyatide in B. 
1 Ariana Antiqua, pp 69, 70. The vase and both its inscriptions are figured there on plate II, after p. 54. The gold casket as described pp. 41, 71. 
2 By Edwurd Thomas in his edition of Prinsep’s Indian Antiqurties, vol I, pp. 105-8. By General Cunningham in JASB, XXIII, p 707. 
IRAS, vol. XX, p. 241, with a transcript of both inscriptions in plate III, opposite p 222. * Journ. Asiat , sér. VIII, vol. XV (1890), p 133: sér. IX, vol. IV (1894), p. 514. 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL. XVI. 
TEXT. 
A- On the lid. Bhagavata sarirehi Sivarachhitana Mam janamda-putasa dana-muhe 
B.-Around the vase. Sivarachhitasa Mum javada-patasa dana-muhe niyatide Bhagavata sarirehi sarva 
Budhana puyae 
TRANSLATION. 
._On the lid. With relics of the Lord, of Sivarachhita, son of Murjanamda, the head of gifts. 
B. 
Around the vase. 
The head of gifts of Sivarachhita, son of Mumjavada, is bestowed; with relics of the Lord, for the veneration of all Buddhas. 
NOTES. 
The father's name is written differently in the two inscriptions. N in A seems to be a u with the top omitted, and the proper form would seem to be Iluñjavanda. 
Noyatide. The last letter is not well formed, but seems to be de. This word plainly agrees with dana-muhe, and its termination therefore should also he e. Noyatide no doubt=niyatite, i.e. niyyatitē, "bestowed." Niyyatita-Sansknt miryatrta, 1 which occurs in the Divyavadana and appears in Palı in the verb niyyādēti. 
Dand-muhe. This is clearly a nominative, and the question that arises is, what does mune represent and mean? I have had the great benefit of discussing this expression with Dr. F. W. Thomas and Professor Macdonell, and offer the following explanations of it. 
As regards its form, h in Prakrit 18 often a degenerate kh; kh may represent either an origin al Sanskrit kh or a weakened Prakrit kkh; and Prakrit kich may represent Sanskrit ksh and Sanskrit khy. Pischel gives instances of the full change from ksh to h in his Prakrit Grammar, $ 323, but none, so far as I have seen, of that from thy to heThe want may be due to the fact that the latter process is much rarer than the former; stall analogy would indicate that there would be no difficulty in the modifications khy kkħ > khel, and Dr Thomas agrees in this view. Hence mula might represent mukhaor mukhya, and dana-muha would = dana-mukha or dana-mukhya. 
Dana-muhe is obviously a substantive and not an adjective, and so must be a tatpurusha compound and not a bahuvrīhi. Hence the question for decision is, what is the meaning of dana-mukha and dana-mukhya as tatpurushas, that is, what meanings have muhha and mukhya as the final members of a tatpurusha. 
M. Senart discussed dana-mukha with reference to the inscriptions in which it occurs and, while rendering it “moyen, objet d'aumône," doubted whether it had any difference in 
UTY 
1 So M. Senait took it, Journ, asiat., sér VIII, vol. XV (1820), p. 133. ? So M. Senart has taken it, Journ. Åsiat, sér. VIII, vol. XV (1890), p. 133. 
The Inscriptions on the Bimaran Vase

SCALE FIVE-SIXTHSwww.

No. 13.) 
THE INSCRIPTIONS ON THE BIMARAN VASE. 
99 
meaning from simple dāna. Dr. Thomas also discussed the word (J. B. 4. 8., 1915, pp. 97 sqq.) in connexion with some instances of the words mukha and mukhya at the end of compounds in the Kautiliya-Arthaśāstra, where mukha means “head, heading, sum ' in administrative arrange ments and accounts, and came to the conclusion " Hence it seems best to accept it [dāna mukha] as a mere synonym for lāna, a misapplication of a technical term, gift department, 
gift heading,' gift account, under which the donation would be recorded in the accounts of the institution benefited. Or is it, after all, the inscription itself ? " 
It is well however to consider also more popular illustrations of the use of mukha and mukhya final; and here the langnage of the Parāņas, which corresponds better than other Sanskrit compositions to that of Prakrit inscriptions, throws fresh light; for both words occur abundantly there as the last member of a compound. 
I will deal with mukhya first, citing instances out of the many that occur. 
(1) “Chief, foremost," and so implying the meaning of adi: thus--Sūry-ēndu-Harica naukhyah, "of whom the sun, the moon and Marici were chief," "the sun, the moon, Marici and others" (Matsya-P, 245, 20): Vriddha-Kausrka-mukhyarh, with Vriddha-Kausika and others” (Brahma-P., 170, 88). 
2) “Chief, pre-eminent (in)”: thugavamsa-muhhyan, " pre-eminent men in the family" (D[atsya-P., 201, 40): déijābhyo Vēda-mukhyėbhyah, "to brahmans pre-eminent in (knowledge of) the Vēda" (Brahma-P.,1218, 18). 
(3) “Chief (of or among)"; thus-Brahmanā dēva-mukhyērza, “ by Brahmă chief of the gods” (Matsya-P., 104, 1). 
(4) Then virtually an adjective qualifying the preceding noun, “chief, foremost, pre-emi nent": thugurishi-mukhya, “ foremost among rishis," and so “a pre-eminent rishi" (Brahma P., 73, 23, 25; 127, 6): vipra-rukhya, “a pre-eminent brahman" (Brahma-P., 220, 126 ; Padma-P., vi, 268, 77, 80): tirtha-muhhya, "a very distingaished tirtha " (Brahma-P., 132, 9) This use is very common. 
(5) And so virtually coming to mean “choice, superfine," as qualifying the noun to which it is added : thus-turaga-mukhya, "a very fine horse” (Padma-P., iv, 112, Puratana Ramayana, 6); ratha-muhhya, “a specially fine chariot " (Vāyu-P., 90, 14; 93, 19: Brahma P., 216, 55) : sara-mukhya, "a choice arrow" (Padma-P., vi, 269, 166). Accordingly dāra mukhya would mean " a choice gift." 
As regards mukha, it is used similarly to mukhya in the first sense, "the chief, the fore most'; tbussarva-devatah, I Mad-Bhava-mukhāh, all the gods having me (Brahmā) and Siya as their chiefs" (Padma-P., V1, 203, 37): Rakshasah Kumbhakarna-mukhan, “the Rák shasas, of whom Kumbhakarna was the chief" (Padma-P., iv, 112, 204). So it virtually implies the meaning of adi; thus- dēva-daitya-mukhin sarvan, " gods, Daityas and all others" (Linga-P., i, 58, 1): Vishnu-mukhair dēvaih, " by Vishnu and the other gods," all except Brahma (Padma-P., V, 40, 31) : Puruhuta-mukhah......vizitah, “ Indra and the other gods were conquered" (ibid, 32). 
Of the other meanings I have found no definite instances; yet possibly Varāhas tu sruti mukhah pradurbhāvos might be taken to yield the second meaning; and Tad=itri-putro *12 mukhach samētos might give the fourth meaning 
? Equivalent to dvira Veda-vriddha in verse 23. But it might also mean * to Brahnians who hold the reda as suprome," equivalent to vipra Veda-puaskrite in verse 16. 
2 Brahna-P., 213, 82; Padina-Pu, v, 16, 53. cf. Harit , 42, 2226. Sruti in tbe Porānas vften incans "ordi nary tradition."

Dana-muhe then, if it represents dănd-nrukhya, would certainly mean "a choice gift." If it represents dana-mukha, that meaning cannot definitely be given to it I cannot but think that dāna-mukha denotes something more particular than simple dana. It can be a tatparusha compound, for nukha occurs as the final member of such compounds, as in the word aya 721hha, that Dr. Thomas cites from the Kautılīya-49 thaśāstra, and also in the words divasa. mukha, ritu-mukha, and yajsa-mukha Since muhha means "beginnug, commencement," in these three expressions, and has also the meaning "the chief, principal, best," as well as “bead heading," dana-mukha can literally mean “ the commencement of gifts” (implying perhaps that it was the first gift made), or "the chief or best of gifts” (implying perhaps that it was the best gift made), or again what Dr Thomas has suggested, as already noticed. At present its exact sense is uncertain, and it may be best to render it provisionally by some general expression that combines the above meanings without attempting precision, and so I have translated it as "the head of gifts." 
No. 14. THE FIRST ARYA-SIDDHANTA 
THE “ARTABHATIYA," OR "LAGHU-ARYA-SIDDHANTA” OF ARYABHATA, A D. 499 
CRI 
WORKING TABLES FOR CALCULATION BY THE TRUE, OR APPARENT, 
MOTIONS OF SUN AND MOON. 
By ROBERT SLWELL (I.C S, Retired) ("Indian Chronography," continued from Vol, YV ubore, p 245 ) 286. My last article (Epig. Ind., Vol XT, PP 159-245) protuled working Tables for verify ing dates according to the requirements of the Siddhantu-sri inanı; the present que provides similar Tables for the First Arya-Sudhantu These Tables are framed so as to correspond to those published in the Indian Calendar, which, for luni-solar computation, generally followed the Sürya-Suddhānta. 
Since amongst the ancient historical records yet discovered in India by far the larger num ber comes from Southern India, where the Irya-Siddhänta has retained its place in popular favour throughout the centuries, it is plainly necessary to provide Epigraphists with information which will allow them to test with scientific accuracy, and according to the requirements of that authority alone, the details of documentary dates. It is probable, as I have already more than once insisted, that a number of records whose dates might have been found correct had they been computed by the Arya-Siddhanta have been set aside as irregular or of doubtful accuracy because their examination was conducted solely by Surya-Siddhanta Tables 
No pains have been spared to render the information that follows scientifically correct. But we do not yet know how far, or in what tracts or in what periods, the by-gone framers of local almanacs adhered strictly to rule, or used other sets of Tables for their guidance, or worked by whole numbers alone, discarding fractions, or made their calculations in true or apparent time instead of, as in these Tables, in mean or clock time. We have, moreover, as yet no definite information as to at how late a date calculations were made by the sun's and moon's mean move neols as opposed to their true or apparent movements, nor do we know with any certainty the boundaries of the tracts within which the different rules governing the civil beginnings of solar 
1 Tbis peeing to me the most probable meaning. 
No 14] 
THE FIRST ARYA-SIDDHANTA. : "TRUE" SYSTEM. 
101 
www 
months were adhered to (Ind. Calendar, § 28) These remarks apply, of course, to all Tables or ephemeres yet, or to be, published, which can only confine themselves to the actual require ments of the Siddhānta concerned Such matters are problems of the future, only to be solved after protracted enquiry and investigation. Dewan Bahadur L. D Swamikannu Pillai gives it as his opinion (Indrar Chronology, p. 70, $ 169) that, while the Ārya-Siddhanta was used for solar computation, the author of South Indian pañchångs in some cases carried out their lunar calculations, for the tithi, nakshatra, etc, by Surya-Siddhanta rale. This remains to be proved. 
287 It is easy to understand how dates of documents, the details of which dates depend on the position of sun and moon, must often differ when calculated by different authorities. Taking only the Ārya and Surya Sudulantas into consideration, it will be seen by Table A below that in 114 years out of the 850 with which the main Table LXI is concerned there were radical differ ences In 66 of these years the samvatsara cycle-name of the whole year was different, in 33 years the intercalation and suppression of lunar months were different, and the day on which the luni-solar year began was different in 15 years. 
Cousider the year A D 1418-19, for instance, or Saka 13-10 expired. This year was, accord ing to the northern system of nomenclature, called - Višti vasu ” by the followers of the Arya. but “ Kiodhin" by those of the Sürya-Suddhänt. In the same year there was, by the Arya Siddhānta, a suppression of the lunar month Magha and an intercalation of Phālguna, while by the Sürya-Siddhānta there was none such; so that a date correctly reckoning in that year would seem entirely inaccurate when tested by Surya-Siddhānta Tables, 
LI 
ARRANGEDIENTS OF THE TABLES. 
288 The principal working-Tables for computation of dates expressed in First Anya-Sid dhanta reckoning are Tables LXI to LXXI below. Tables LXI to LXX are disposed so as to correspond in rotation with Tables I to X of the “Indian Calendar," and have been framed in similar manner This arrangement is adopted for the convenience of those who, during the last twenty years, have become accustomed to the processes of that publica 
Table LXI corresponds to Table I, - Indian Calendar,"51 
LXII

Table LXXI is taken from Tables XLI A and B, “ Indian Chronography" (pp. 176, 177). It enables the week-day corresponding to the Hindu date under examination to be determined according to European computation. 
Then follow three Tables by which the details given in the main Table LXI have been calculated. These are Table LXXII, which fixes the values of a, b, c (mean distance of moon 
moon's mean anom, sun's mean anom.) at the beginning of the centuries concerned ; Table LXXIII, which gives the same information for the beginnings of odd years of centuries; and Table LXXIV, which provides, in combination with Tables LXXII and LXXIII, an easy method of arriving at the values of a, b, c, or the mean positions of sun and moon at mean sunrise on the first ciyıl day of each luni-solar year. The system of work is the same as that of Prof Jacobi 
Fall particulars of the moon's equation of the centre will be found in the last Table LXXV. 
ELEMENTS OF THE FIRST ARYA-SIDDEANTA. 289. This work was composed by Aryabhata at Kusumapura in A D. 499, or the year 3600 (expired) of the Kaliyuga. About A.D. 638 a treatise called the Dhë-rriddhi-da was written by Lalla, who introduced a bīja, or correction, affecting three of the principal elements of the Sid dhậnta. He seems to have reduced by about 10' in a century the moon's increase in her mean distance from mean sun (our "a"); and he added about 36' in a century to the moon's mean anomaly (our "b"); bis third correction had reference to the planet Jupiter, with which at present we are not concerned. He did not make any change in the sun's mean anomaly (our "C"). The Karana-prakāśa, of date A D. 1092, an authority largely used in Southern India, is based on Āryabhata's Siddhanta as amended by Lalla. 
The Tables given below, which deal with the period A.D. 899-900 (K.Y. 4000 expired) to A.D. 1750-51 (K.Y 4851 expired) include Lalla's corrections. 
290. (1) The length of the sidereal solar year, according to the Arya-Siddhanta, is 365-2586805 days, or 3650 6h 12m 30s. 
(1) Sines of angles are the same as those of the Surya-Siddhānta, based on a radius of (sin 90°= 3438'. The 24 base sines and equations of the sun's centre are given in my Table XLVII, Vol. XIV above. Those of the moon's centre in Table LXXV below. 
(iii) For the san's mean motion per day, hour, minute and second, see Table XLIV, Vol. XIV. 
(10) The circumference of the sun's epicycle is 13° 30'; that of the moon 31° 30'. There is no contraction of the epicycle in either case. (Jacobi, Vol. I above, p. 441 ) 
(v) There is no shift of the sun's apsis. The longitude of his perigee-point is always 258°; apogee 78°. In ten-thousandths of the circle the perigee is 7166 6. 
(vi) The sun's equation of the centre at the moment of true Mösha-samkrānti in every year, i.e. the moment when the true sun reaches celestial longitude 0°, is, according to Dr. Schram's calculation, 2° 6' 57"-323494885, or, in ten-thousandths of cir 
2° 6' 57"-323494885, or, in ten-thousandths of circle, 58-7756441701 ; the sun's mean longitude at the same moment being 357° 53' 24.676505115, or, in ten-thousandths of circle, 9941 224355830; and his mean anomaly 99° 53' 2 676505115, or, in ten-thousandths of circle, 2774-557689163.

(x) The sodhya, or time-equivalent of the equation of the centre in other words the interval of time between the moments of the true san reaching long 00 (true Mēsha-san krānta) and mean sun reaching the same point (mean Mēsha-samkrāntı)-is calculated by Dr Schram às 2 146831 days, or 2d 3h 31m 26-1984. This differs a little from the accepted Hindu valuation 2d 3h 32m 30%. As the latter is believed to have been always taken in India as the sodhya value according to the First Arya-Siddhanta, it is the value adopted in the present work 
(II) According to this Siddhanta the Kaliyuga era began, or in other words K.Y O expired or KY I current began, with a conjunction at celestial longitude 0° of mean moon, mean sun, and the principal planets at the moment of mean sunrise at Lanka on Friday, 18 February, BC 3102 That was the moment of mean Mēsha-sankranti in that year It was on ou Lanka time on that morning. 
(mu) At that moment, and the same in every succeeding year, the sun's apsis (periges being at long. 258°, his mean anom. (our "c") is (360°-2589) 102°, or, in thousandths of circle (our notation), 283-3. 
(211) The moon's mean anom (our "5") was 90°, or, in thousandths of circle, 250. 
(XIV) Since mean moon and mean sun were at that moment in conjunction, the distance between them was ml. CONSTROCTION OF THE TABLES 
291 No special remarks are necessary except with reference to Tables LXIII B (lengths of solar months), LXVI A and LXVII A. (Detailed * Equation b” and “ Equation c"), LXVIII (Indices of tathis, etc), and the three Tables LXXII, LXXIII, LXIV. The l'emainder are only duplicates of the similar Tables in the “ Indian Calendar " (See - Arrange ment of Tables," abole, $ 288.) 
Table LXIII B ---Lengths of the true solar months. 292 M. Louis de Ries has been repeatedly quoted in these pages as a most careful calculator Several years ago he kindly worked out for me an estimate of the lengths of the true solar months according to the First Alya-Siddhanta, but did not inform me of the process by which he obtained his results. An entirely independent calculation has now been carried 
able of the sun's true longitude for each 24-hour period of the solar year (abore, Vol XIV, Tuble XLVIII A- Table, let it be understood, prepared some years subsequent to M. de Ries' communication and to which he has never had access! Compari son of results proves the accuracy of M de Ries' figures, and these have been adopted without alteration in my Table The complete agreement of our respective fixtures is really remarkable. 
For esample, M. de Ries found that the true sun, according to ryabhata as corrected by Lalla, reaches 180° of celestial long, the moment of the Tula-sankranti, 1800 215 21m 3782 after the moment of true Mēsha-samkräntı, the astronomical beginning of the true solar gear 
Nr Orn work for solution of this problem is as folloirs.--It will be seen from Table XLVIII A (above, Vol. XIV) that on that 186th day, 1.e. after 186 periods of 21 hours each from the moment of true Mēsha-samkrāntı, the true sun has to travel (180°-179° 6' 55' 21 ) 53' 4" 79 before reaching the Tula-samkrānti point, 180o Calculating by his actual velocity on day 186 (Table XLIX, VOZ XIV), the time required for him to accomplish this journey (using his true, not mean, velocity in minutes and seconds as well as in hours) is found to be 21h 21m 378.82,--precisely M. de Ries' fixture. All the details given by M de Ries have been similarly examined, and found correct, 
Dewan Bahadar L D. Swamikannu Pillai's estimate of the lengths of these months (Indian Chronology, Table II) differs somewhat from ours, the sun according to him arriving at each samkrāntı always a little later than it does by our determination. The greatest difference between us is at the Tulā-samkrānti, which his Table shews to occur 3m 345 18 later than the time yielded by our Table. Adding together the lengths of the twelve solar months as given by him, the length of the Arya-Siddhanta year appears to be 365d 6h 12m 378, or 7 seconds longer than its accepted length.

294 It is advisable to explain clearly my reason for differing from Prof. Jacobi as to the amount of the greatest equation of the moon, which he values, in ten-thousandths of the circle, at 139 0 as against my 139 4 
"Eqr. l" The general formula ($ 290, 1x) for the equation of the moon's centre is, a being the angle of mean anom., sin. eqn. =ón sin a To obtain the equation from the 
sine of the equation-angle the proportion eqn , sin egn " diff in angle : diff. in sine 18 used The Hindu astronomer's always worked by sections of anomaly-arc, each measuring 3° 45', or 225. Reference to the Equation-Table LXXV will shew that in the case of the first group anom 0° to 3° 45' the diff in anom. is 225' and the cuff in sine is also 225'. Hence, in the case of all anom angles between 0 and 3° 45' eqn.sin. eqn. But in the case of all anom. angles between 3° 45' and 7° 30'—and no equation angle of the moon's anom, exceeds the latter quantity the diff in angle is 225' and the diff in sine is 224', so that the formula to be used for all angles 
223 coming into this second group is eqn.=553 sin. eqn. This applies only to the excess in the angle 
1 
over 3° 45' The working rule, therefore, for finding the equation of angles lying between 3° 45' and 7° 30' is as follows 
With the formula 
sin a, find the sin. eqn. From the sin. eqn deduct 225' 
Multiply 
the remainder by 225' and divide the product by 224 Add 225' to the result. 
Or, a little more simply.-- From the sin, eqn. deduct 225' Divide the remainder by 224' Add the result + 225' to the sin eqn. 
For an example let us suppose that it is required to find the moon's eqn. for anom.

Table LXVIII.-Indices of tithis, etc. 296-A. In this Table the indices are given with decimal points for guidance in close cases. Otherwise they correspond exactly to those in Table VIII, “ Indian Oalendar." The indices of yogas (col 6) are the same as those of nakshatras (col. 8). 
Tables LXXII, LXXIII, LXIV. 297. Prof. Jacobi (above, Vol. 1, p. 450) has provided a Table, XIII, shewing for four of the Indian astronomical authorities the places of the sun and moon at the beginning of centuries, and another, XV, sbewing their increases through the years of a century according to the Arya-Siddhānta with Lalla's corrections. It is plain from Table XIII that in Prof. Jacobi's opinion Lalla did not interfere with Aryabhata's fixtures previons to the year KY. 3600, the date of the latter's work, but introduced his corrections for all later years. 
If, therefore, we establish by Aryabhata alone the values of a, b, c for 36 centuries of the Kaliyaga and add to these their values at the beginning of that era as given above, we shall arrive at their values (positions of sun and moon) at the beginning of KY. 3600-values, 
zed by Lala; and Tables giving Lalla's estimate of the periodio changes in position of the sun and moon for centuries, years, and days will enable us to ascertain their posi tion at ang later date when computed by the Arya-Siddhānta with the bija. 
298. (i) First to find the century increase of a, b, c respectively according to Aryabhata uncorrected. We work for mean sunrise values only, not for values at moments of Mesha samkrānti. We require, that is, the several increases in a common century of 36526 civil days and in a defective century of 36525 such days. In the 36 Kaliyuga centuries concerned there were 31 of the former and 5 of the latter. 
(ii) As regards the time-interval between the moments of mean Mesha-samkrānti and the nearest mean sunrises at the beginning of each century, Prof. Jacobi's column headed “Cor." io Table XIII states these clearly in ghatikās and palas. Mean Megha-samkrānti always occurs 2d 3h 32m 30$ after true Mésha-samkrānti, and the moment of the latter's occurrence every year is given in hours and minutes in col. 17, Table I, “ Indian Calendar." There is no difference between us in this respect.
