THE NAKSHATRA. 
302 A special note must be made regarding the working of the " Indian Calendar " rule ($ 156, p 97) for obtaining approximately the index of the nakshatra. 
It will be observed there that part of the process (see $ 133, Ind. Cal.) consists of the addi tion to the value of c, the sun's mean long., of a constant, viz. 7207, as stated in 10,000ths of circle This is the Sürya-Siddhanta quantity. For work by the Arya-Siddhanta we require the Arya-Siddhanta quantity. 
The Sürya-Siddhānta figure is made up of (i) long. of sun's perigeo-point (257° 15' 55'73) 7146 3 and (ii) 60 4, the greatest equation of the sun's centre. 
Now (1) the long of the sun's perigee-point according to the Arya-Siddhanta is always 2589, or, in 10,000ths of circle, 71666 ($ 290, v, above); and (ii) the greatest equation of the sun's centre (S$ 295, 296) is 59.6875. Hence the Arya-Siddhanta constant for calculating the nakshatra is (7166 6+59-6875 ) 7226-3542; and for approximate calculation is 7226, not 7207. 
There appear to be two misprints in Prof. Jacobi's Table VI (above, Vol. XI, p. 165), in which he given similar annual increages. Against year 3, under «C, “61" should be “6”; and against year 52, under * a, €16312" should be "16352."" 
110 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
www. 
wwwww 
w 
wwwwwwww 
Thus the rules for finding the nakshatra by the Arya-Siddhānta are as follows: 
A. Roughly. Find a, b, c and t in whole numbers; multiply c by 10 ; add 7226 to the result; from this subtract “ equation c" The result 18 s, the sun's true longitude. 
B. More closely. Find a, b, c and t with the fractions in decimals, to the value of c multiplied by 10, or, with the decimal point one place to the right, add t from the result deduct (including decimals) the amount of “ equation c" The result is & in full detail. $+t=n, the index of the nakshatra, with which turn to Table LXVIII for yalue of the nakshatra, 
The work is shewn in Example 7 below. 
EXAMPLES. Example 1. To find the a, b, c values for mean sunrise on the first crurl day of the luni-solar year. 
Rule. Add together the entries in Tables LXXII and LXXIII for the corresponding expired year of the Kaliyugau, and those in Table LXXIV for the number of days' interval from true Mēsha-samkranti (Table LXI, col 13, bracket-number) to the first ayıl day of the luni solar year, called " Chaitra sukla 1" (col. 19, bracket-number). Note specially the week-day of Chaitra sukla 1, and work for that day.* Decimals need not be used except in close cases.

Computation of a date. Example 3 We will now take a suppositious Record-date, and in the following examples explain the complete method of work for proving the accuracy of all its details, and for settling some other matters. 
The date is “ Saka 1148 expired, KY 4327, Vraya, Saturday, Bhadrapada sukla 5, Kanyā 1, Bāva karana, nakshatia Visāklā, joga Vaudhuiti, Kanyā lagna 
Table LXI shens that the year corresponded to AC 1226-27, that in that year true Mêsha-samkrānti took place 3h 55m after mean sunrise 0 Wed, 23 March (Dur 84 from 1 Jan); that the civil day Chaitra sukla 1 was Sunday, 1 March (Day 60 from 1 Jan); and that (col. 8) the lunar month Ashādha was ntercalated in that year. The year was called “ Vyaya" in South India, “ Vikrita" in the North. 
The interval of days between the initial days of the solar and luni-solar year was (84-60) 24. 
ve work for the values of a, b, c aud t at mean sunrise of the day Chaitra sukla 1, which is stated in Table LXI to have been (col 20) a Sunday We work by the first process shewn above, and with full decimals In using Table LXXIV for the interval of days 24 as alreally stated -t is observed that the week-day number (col 3) for that number of days' interval (col. 1) is 2, and that, since the week-days obtained for the year from Tables LXXII, LXXIII are respectively 6 and 6, total 12, the addition of 2 will make total 14, or 0, or a Saturday, whereas the day we are working for has Sunday. Hence we use the figures for 23 days' interval, week-day 3, which gives us the correct a, b, c for 1 Sunday (See note to Example 1 )

For either equation 6 or equation c Ilute the difference between the values of b or c thus found and the nearest value respectively in Table LXVI A Or LXVII A, cols 24, 26 Multiply this difference by the group-difference (col. 4). Divide the result roughly by 2 or exactly by 2 083; and add or subtract the result to or from the standard equation-value given in the Table (col. 3) as necessity demands. 
[This is the complete process, but it almost always suffices to arrive very near to the truth merely by the exercise of common sense, using Tables LXVI A, LXVII A. as Eye-Tables.] 
Here the moon's anom. b is 783 6045, and the nearest amount of Argument b in Table LXVI A. 15 7833, whose exact equation is 3 1006 (col 3). As the difference in anom. is only about 0:3, viz. 0.2712, and the group-difference only 0 4150, we may take 3 1006 as the required equation of the given anom. Or we may work roughly by a multiplication of the first two decimals of the anom. diff. (0-27) by those of the group-diff (0-42) and a division of the result by 2-yielding 0.0567, which, added to 3 1006, makes “equation b' 3 1573; or we may work completely with all four decimals, arriving at the absolutely correct result 3-1546.

The karana. Example 6. The karana is half a tithi See Table LXVIII, cols. 4, 5. For the date we are examining (Examples 3, 4, 5), viz sukla 5 (Table, col 2), the two karadas and Bāva and Bälava. The tithi began (end of Example 4) She go before and ended 15h 31m after mean sunrise on 29 Aug. A.D. 1226. Its length was 23h 40m Half of this is 11h 50m. Thus Bāva was the karana from 8h 9m before to 3h 41 m after mean sunrise on 29 Aug., and Balava was the karana from 3h 410 to 154 31m on that day. Since the karapa mentioned in the given date was Bāva, the action referred to in the record must have taken place between mean suprise and 3h 41" later on 29 Aug 1226, i.e. roughly between 6.0 and 9-41 A.M. on that day. 
The nakshatra. Example 7. Required the nakshatra of the same day, month and year as in Examples 3, 4, 5,6. 
A nakshatra, or lunar mansion, is, in the equal-space system, a 27th part of the complete journey of the moon in a lunar month through the circle of the stars. Our nakshatra-index shews in which of these parts the moon was at any given moment. In these examples we are working for the true, not mean, moon's place. Each of these 27 parts has its own nakshatra name and yoga-name (see Example 8). In the systems of Garga and the Brahma-Siddhanta the divisions of the constellation-circle are unequal, being designed more nearly to suit the positions of the principal starsl; but the names of the divisions are the same as in the equal-space system. 
The indices of the beginning and ending points of the nakshatras are stated, in 10,000ths of the circle, in Table LXVIII. The same in degrees are given, together with those of the zodiacal solar signs, in " Indian Chronography," Table XXII. 
(A) The rule for finding the nakshatra roughly, when working with only whole numbers, is as follows:-Take the c of the date; multiply it by 10, add the constant 7226 (see $ 302 above); and deduct the amount of “equation c." This gives 8, the sun's true longitude at menn sunrise of the given day. Add s to # and the result is rh, the nakshatra-index. Reference with this index to Table LXVIII (col. 8, or 9, or 10) shews the nakshatra required, i.e. the 
Mr. G. E. Kaye, in his "Astronomical Observatones of Jaj Singh" (p. 117), gives the actual let. and long of the stars after which the nakshatras were named.

If, for eren greater accuracy, instead of using the value of the sun's mean motion in 55m, ve had worked by his true motion on that 157th day, viz. by dividing by 60 bis true motion in 1 hour (Table XLIX, p54) and multiplying the result by 55, we should have found 72 5625 8092

The yoga. 
The nakshatra (Example 7), as quoted in the given date, shews in which of the 27 sidereal divisions the moon stood at the moment in question, or the extent of the moon's joumey from celestial long. 0° The yoga deals with the combined journeys of both sun and moon. 
To find, therefore, the index of the yoga at mean sunrise of the given day we have to add the long of the true sun to the long of the true moon at that moment But the long of the true moon is the index n, ie, the nakshatra-index already found. And the long. of the sun is the index s, also already found (Example 7). 
Hence the yoga-index (y) $ +92; or, since 1 8 of t (Example 7), y = 2s to t. The latter formula makes it easy to find the yoga when it 18 unnecessary to find the nakshatra 
At mean sunrise of 29 Aug. A.D. 1226 we have found that s - 4177 5653 and that 12 = 5625 7925, hence the Foga-index (y) = 9803 3578, and (Table LXVIII) the yoga of the day was 27 Vardhriti. 
The seleral sankrāntis. 
Erample 9 To find the values of a, b, cand t at the moments of the several solar samkrāntis in the grzer year, and thereby to find whether a lunar month was common, intercalary (adhika), or suppressed (kshaya) 
A samkrāntz takes place when the sun touches the point of a zodiacal sign, 1e. when he reaches long. 30°, 60°, etc When, at the first of two such successive occurrences, the true 
waning and at the second is also waning, or at the first is waxing and at the second is also vaxing, the lunar month is common. If the moon is waning at the first and waxing at the second, the lunar month is repeated. It is intercalary adhika) When the moon is waxing at the first and waning at the second, the lunar month is altogether suppressed (hshaya). 
Thus it is necessary to find the a, b, c for the moment of the astronomical beginning of the solar year, the actual moment, that is, of the true Mēsha-samkrānti, and add to their values their respective increases during the several true solar months, thus obtaining the a, b, c for the moments of the true samkrāntis concerned. Adding to the value of a at the moment of a samkrānta the values of “equation 5" and "equation o" (as in the former examples), we find the index of the tithi t, which shews whether the true moon was waxing or waning at the moment. 
The date and time of the true Mesha-samkranti is given in Table LXI, cols. 13, 14, 17. The intervals in time to each subsequent samkrānti, and the collective intervals to each, are given in Table LXIII B, cols 8 and 3; and the corresponding increases in the values of a, b, c are given in the same Table, cols. 9, 10, 11 and 4, 5, 6. 
We will consider the conditions for the first few sarakrintis of the same year as in Examples 3-8, viz. AD. 1226-27, K.Y 4327, Saka 1148.

Interval between the two, whole days, (84-60 ) 24 Taking down the a, b, c for 25 March and adding their increase for 244 zł 55m from Tables LXIV, LXV, we find the values of a, 0, c at the moment of true Mēsha-samkrānti, as required 
Table LXIII B gives us the exact interval in time and the amount of increase of a, b, c, during that interval, up to the moment of every subsequent samkrānti in the year. In close cases, of course, full decimals can be used and the equation-values very carefully examined, but in general it is only necessary to use whole pumbers, as in this example. Days of the solar year. Example 10. To find the day and week-day of the solar year corresponding to any given day in the luni-solar year. 
The moment of true Mesha-sakrānti, as given in Table LXI, cols. 13, 14, 17, marks th astronomical beginning of the solar year. In different parts of India (see Indian Calendar, $ 28, p. 12, and Indian Chronography, $ 43, pp. 18, 19) there are different rules for fixing the first day of the solar month, which is sometimes the same day, sometimes the next day, sometimes (in Bengal) the third day. In the present case we imagine the record to have come from the Tamil county and we work by the Tamil rule. 
In the given Fear (Example 3), A.D. 1226, true Mēsha-sarnkrānti took place on Day 84 (measured t.om Jan. 1), Wednesday, 25 March, at 3h 55m after mean sunrise, and that Wednesday was the day "1 Mosha" since the samkrānti occurred before sunset. 
The days in Měsha follow regularly. But to find the first civil day of each successive month in the year we must establish the moment when each samkrānti took place. This information is obtained from Table LXIII B. 
We har determined the given date to be (see Examples 4, 5) the serial day 241 measured from Jan. 1, and the 157th day after the day on which Misha-sankranti occurred, which was Day 84. Turn to Table LXIII B. Kanya began 156 days after true Mosha-samkrānti ; SO OILI date will be in the solar month Kanyā Calculate the moment of occurrence of the Kanya samkrāntı in the given year from the same Table. 
d u-d. hom . S. (Table LXI) True Mesha-sankranti . (Tavie LXIII B) Interral to Kany.T-sa iisk. (156) (2) 10 24 25 Woment of Kunya-sankrānti . . (240) (6) 14 19 2 5 
By Tamil rule, since the samkrānti took place after sunset, or 12h Lanka time, viz. at 145 19m 25 after mean suurise, the civil day “1 Kanya 
mean suurise, the civil day “1 Kanya " was not (6) Friday (Day 240). 28 August, the day of the samkranti, but was Saturday (Day 241), 29 August 
And this Saturday happens to have been the very day of our record, which day was in solar-year reckoning "1 Kanya." 
(Observe that, if the record had come from Bengal, its solar date would have been the sane, sauce the sankranti occurred before midnight on Friday and the Saturday was therefore " 1 Kanya." Had it come from Orissa, the Saturday would have been “2 Kanyā," since the first day of the solar month is, in that country, always the day of the samkrānti, and so "1 Langå " was the Friday. By the Malabar Rule “1 Kanya” was Saturday.)

The lagna. Example 11. On the day in question (Example) it has been established that at mean $ud ise the sun's true long, s, in 10,000ths of the circle, was 4177 5653 To calculate the lagna we must have s in degrees, etc., which can be calculated by Table XLV B, Vol. XIV above, or by Tables XLVIII A, XLIX, L, in the same volume. We work by the latter. 
The day of the record was the 157th after true Mösha-samkrānti, which took place 31 55m after mean sunrise on the day of its occurrence. Table XLVIII A. (p. 32) shews that 31 3h 55m after mean sunrise 157 days later the sun's true long., s, was 150° 33' 7":84. Deduct his motion (true) for 3h by Table XLIX (p. 54), viz. 7' 18" 72, and (mean) for 55m by Table L, viz. 2' 15'-)2, total 9' 34" 24. Then sat mean sunrise was 150° 23' 33"-60. 
The long. of the point of rising of Kapya is (Indian Chronography, Table XXID 150°, and that siga erds at 180o. Take the ending-point and calculate the distance between it and the son at Inean sunrise, 180°-150° 23' 33"-60=29° 36' 26"-40. There is no need here forNo. 14.1 
THE FIRST ARYA SIDDHANTA : * TRUE" SYSTEM. 
11:0 
great accuracy, and we take this as 29° 36'. Turn this into time by multiplying the degrees by 4m, and the minutes by 4s. Result 1b 584 248. 
Thus on the given day Kanyā was lagna from very shortly before till about 1h 58mn after mean sunrise. 
In examining the given date in the matter of the karana (Example 6) we found that the action referred to in the record must have taken place between mean sunrise and 3h 41 m later or between 60 and 9.41 4. M. on Sat, 29 Aug, A D. 1226. The mention of the lagna still further reduces the time and shews that the action referred to inst have taken place between mean bunrise and a time 1h 58m later; or between 60 and 7.58 A.M. on that day. 
NOTE. The above examples may, perhaps, strike the uninitiated as involving an immense amount of complicated work in order to obtain the desired result. But such is by no means the case. Every date can be calculated in whole numbers at first, and it is very seldom that the decimals need be resorted to. They are provided for the purpose of deciding doubtful cases where very great accuracy is required. 
For all the details of the given date-and it is very seldom that so many are stated in an inscription or grant,--the following exemplifies all the work necessary to be done to put us in full possession of the facts In about a quarter of an hour we learn everything that has to be learned, and, when less details are given, their accuracy can be proved or disproyed in a few minutes. What follows shews the ordinary work to be done for the date given in Examples 3-10. 
Given year = Saka 1148, K.Y 4327, Vyaya, A.D. 1226-27.

TABLE A. DIFFERENCES IN THE CALENDAR BETWEEN ARYA AND SORYA SIDDHANTA FIXTURES. Cols. 1, 2.-The number of the year here given is the one generally used in records of the year 
A.D. noted in column 3, and is stated here so as to catoh the eye readily. In referring to the main Table LXXI the number of the year in columns 1, 2 therein is the present number 
advanced by 1, being the corresponding concurrent year. Col. 4, Class A.-Different samvatsara-names given to solar and luni-solar years. Col. 4, Class B-Intercalations and suppressions of different lunar months. "adh."=an intor 
calated (adhika) months ; " ksh," a suppressed (kshaya) month. Col. 4, Class C. Differences in the civil day called “ Chaitra Sukla 1," the civil beginning of the 
luni-solar year. The figure in brackets in columns 5, 6 is the number of the civil day measured from January 1st.

TABLE LXI. 
774-The present Tab and in that respelly quoted in insetog-900 corresponde 
NOTES Cols. 1 to 4 The present Table states the concurrent years so as exactly to correspond with Table I of the “ Indian Calendar " and in that respect to save trouble for those who have become accustomed to use that publication The year usually quoted in inscriptions is the expired year, though sometimes the concurrent year 18 given, eg, the year AD 899-900 corresponds to the concurrent years K Y 4001, Saka €22, but to the expired years K, Y 4000, Saka 821 
Col. 8 --All the entries are of intercalated (adhika) months, except those in italics, which are suppressed (Kshaya) months. 
A List of instances where in important details the Arya and Sürya differ is given in Table A at end of text. 
It has not been thought necessary to include in this Table the years between AD. 499 and 899. This paper concerns computation by the true motions of sun and moon, and it is practi cally certain that prior, at least, to the latter date all calculations for almanacs in India fere made by mean planetary motions.

TABLE LXIX. 
SERIAL NUMBER OF DAYS IN A YEAR A.D. FOR TWO CONSECUTIVE YEARS. 
N. B. The numbers given are those in a common year. In Leap-years, after February 29, the day of the month must be reduced by 1. Thus Day 153, in a Leap-year, is not June 2, but June 1. 
The Table is the same as Table IX, “ Indian Calendar."

To find the initial day of a given year A.D. take the day marked in Section A, perpendicular under the given century and horizontal opposite the given year Note this initial day in column 2 of the heading of Section B Find the given day of month in the body of Section B Run up to the week-day in horizontal line with the initial day in the heading The day so found in the week-day of the given day of month and ycar. 
Eng Wanted week-day of 23rd March, AD. 645. At junction of century 600 (perpendicular) and 45 (horizontal) in Section A 18 Saturday. This was the initial day of AD. 645. The year was common. The week-day noted in the heading of Section B at the junction of 23rd March (perpendicular) and of " Sa." in column 2 of heading (horizontal) is “ W," Wednesday. Therefore 23rd March, A.D. 645, was a Wednesday. 
In common years work with the month on left, in leap years with that on right. 
N. B-In the New Style the years 1600 and 2000 are leap-years, but 1700, 1800, 1900 are common years. The initial week-day of the first year of each New Style century is given above it in heading of Section A. For the initial woek-day of other years of the century look for the day in the junction of columns as mentioned abore; e., A.D 1900 began (top) on Monday. 1901 began Qunction of columns) on Tuesday. 1928 begins on Sunday. 1919 began on Wednesday.

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI 
No 15.-SRIRANGAM PLATES OF HARIHARA-RAYA UDAIYAR (III): 
SAKA 1336. 
BY TEE LATE T. A. GOPINATHA RAO, M, A., TRIVANDRAM, AND VARAKHEDI BAPU ACHARYA, B.4, 
MADRAS. 
This set of copper-plates belongs to the Sriranganātha Temple at Srīrangam. The temple authorities kindly allowed us a loan, for a few days, of the original copper-plates, from which ink-impressions, on which the accompanying facsimile plates are lased, were taken uuder oor supervision, 
The set consists of five plates, which are engraved on both sides and are 7" X 4.2" in size. In the middle of the left margin of each plate there is a hole to take in the binding ring. which, when the plates were leut to us, pas not found with the set. Most probably the binding ring has been lost. The inscription is in an excellent state of preservation. The plates are marked serially with Teluga-Kannada numerals-one to five-near the ring-holes. The alphabet is Telugu and the language Kannada. But the first five lines, which cuutain au 
ocation to Vishnu in his Boar incarnation, are written in Sanskrit verse; similarly, lines 92-98 contain the usual imprecatory verses in Sanskrit. The Kannada employed in the record is far from literary and is distinctly faulty; it sounds more like the dialect spoken in the Coimbatore, Salem and Trichinopoly Districts than the pure Kannada of Mysore. 
A pamber of orthographical and graphical peculiarities are worth noting. The chief among them is the aniversal use of the anusvāra before a sonsonant in the place af nasals : it would be impossible to correct them all, and they are therefoi e left as found in the inscription. The necessary doubling of consonants is in many instances omitted : e.g., in kota in ll. 23, 24 and 27, in grāmavanů in 1 17 (the accusative termination anū is correct, see Kittel's Kannada Grammar, p. 43.-H. K S.], in hotina in l. 32, in oba in ll. 40 and 77, etc. The use of vowels at the end and in the middle of words, where there ought to be sonant consonants, is also a common feature of this document: e.g., näii for nāvu in 11, 13, 18, 57 and 89; nii for nīvu in 11. 48, 58 and 87: koteü for koţtovu id l. 24;o dvadeset for dvādasiyū in 1, 19; mādusuvadakkeü. for madisuvadakku in ll. 35-6; Naruuru for Naruvuru in Il. 15, 26 and 60-1; Ohédrakote for Ohëvūrakote in I. 20. The consonant nau is used in some instances for navā, eg., pratidinau for pratidinavi in 11. 28 and 67; similarly dan is used for dalo dravyadindalo in IL 62 and 63. The secondary e-symbol is in many instances added at the bottom instead of the top as in other insoriptions and in modern Telugu: e.g., in le in "kalebarah in 1. 2; in Khe in Osakheya in ll. 11 and 17; lê in kalē in l. 95. Tbe consonants with secondary i are hardly distinguishable from those with the secondary e. Two different forms of the consonant va is employed, one resembling the English letter & and the other the common one. The former type occurs also in conjunctiona, 6.9., vo in vomdu in l. 32. 
The record belongs to the reign of Vira-Harihara-Rāya Udaiyar (III), son of Vira, Pratapa-dõva-RĀya II of the first Vijanayagara Dynasty. That Vira-Pratapa-dēva-Raya had & son named Vira-Harihara-Raya is known from a solitary record of the latter at Vijaya. mangalam.No. 596 of the Madras Epigraphist's collection for 1905,-dated Saka 1334. Hari hara-Raya seems to have ruled as & viceroy over the country lying on the banks of the Bhavani river? (that is, a portion of the Coimbatore District, as it is at present constituted). Ho appears to have ended his life only as a governor and never to have occupied the position of king of Vijayanagars. 
[They have been already noticed by the Madras Epigraphist in his Annual Report for 1905-6, Appendix Ag No. 27.Ed.] 
* (See Arch Suro. Rep. for 1907-8, P. 246.Ed.] 
No. 15.7 
SRIRANGAM PLATES OF HARIHARA-RAYA UDAIYAR (III). 
223 
The subject matter of the record is the grant of the village of Naruvūru, situated in Kilang made of the Rāyarāpura-zēntheya (distinct), to Uttamanambi, son of Uttamanambi. of the Ranganatha temple at Srirangam, on Friday, the first day of the dark fortnight of the month Bhadrapada in the cyclic year Jaya, which corresponded to the Saka year 1336. The inscription further states that the same village was originally granted to one Appannan galu, son of Ichappa, by Vira-Harihari-Rāya Udaiyar, on Monday, the twelfth day (SraFana Dvadasi) of the bright fortnight of the month of Bhadrapada of the same year, i e, 
yg earlier than the previous date, at Chēvūrakote, in the presence of the god Madhara, on the banks of the Bhavani river, for the propitiation of the god Tryambaka. It is also understood that Uttaruanambi, who received the gift from Appaņpangala, was to buid 22 Authordinate position (droid u to the latter with reference to the grant It is not possitle to explain why in such a short period as four days the gift shonld h.ve changed hands It was perhaps that Appannangalu could not at a distance manage the charity as effectively as de native of the place, and therefore handed over the management of the same to the charge of Uttamanambi. 
The deed of gift to Uttamanambi stipulated - 
1. that the village of Naruvaru should thenceforvard be designated Ranganāthapura; 2 that a daily service with every detail of offerings to the god Ranganathe should be 
maintained; 3 thata flower-gardeo should be kept up for the special service kaown as Padisettimpadi 
Śērvai (?); 4, that a Satira, or feeding house for Brāhmanas, should be constructed within the walls 
of the Ranganātha temple, and twelve Brāhinanas fed daily; and 5. that four nrā of land should be granted to each of eight Brāhmanas residing at 
Naruvūru, free of taxes The prince Harihara-Rāya Udaiyar expresses his desire that, since this was a chanty primarily by him, it should be conducted without remissness and diminution. Who tbe person called Appapnangalu was, is not patent from the inscription; he appears to have been a highly placed man, wielding some influence with the prince Haribara-Raya Udaiyar, and to have induced the princo to grant the village with the distinct intention of giving it over to Cttama nambi. The family of the Uttamannmbis is an ancient one in Srirangam; the Uttanadambis were very influential, and there is still a cartent proverb, ur priđu Uttamanambi padi, “ the town is one-half and Uttamanambi the other half," meaning that the members of the family were as good as the whole town put together. These are Brāhmaṇas of the Pūrca-śthhñ sect and have done very much towards the enriching of the temple of the god Raðganātha of Siiravgan. A detailed account of these will be found in an article on the Srirangam Plates of Dērarāra II. to be edited by one of us in this journal. The Uttamanambis are one of the hereditary trustees of the temple of Rangadātha and enjoy certain rights and duties in it 
The places, etc., mentioned in this record are: Rāyarāpura-zēnthe, Kelanga or Kilanga nadu, Kāvēri, Naru vůru, Chēvūra köte, Bhayānī and Srirangam Of these the Kävirs and the Bhayāni are two rivers, the latter a tributary of the former. Nariyūru is evidently the morern Nerūr, situated on the bank of the iiver Kāvērī in the Karar tāluha of the Coimbatore Disnct It is famous as the place where the great Sadasiva Parabrahmam, a modern Yögis of great powers and devotion, died and is interred. Chēvūruköte may be identified with Sörür in the Palladanı trīluka of the same district. There are three places called Rärarpālayan, Rāvanapuram and Rāyapuram, in the Frode, the Udamalpēt, and the Karür taruhus all of them sound like Rāyaräpuram; but since Nertr, the village granted, is in the same tāluhı as Karür, we may perhaps identify Råyarā pura of the vēnthe of the same name with Rāyapuram in the Karür täluka. Whether Kılangu-1ādu takes its name from Kilāögundal in the Dharapuram talrehu would bo bard to say. 
22 
224 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[Voz XVI.

ABSTRACT OF CONTENTS. (LI. 1-5.) Adoration to Vishnu in his Boar incarnation. 
(LI.5-13.) In the Salivahana Saka. year 1386, corresponding to the cyclic year Taya on the first tithi of the dark fortnight of the month Bhadrapada, on a Friday, Mahe mandalesvara Vira-Harihara-Raya Odeya, son of Vira-Pratapa-deva-Raya Mahārāya, who possessed the titles Maharajadhiraja and Rajaparanēsvara, gave to Uttamanambi, son of Uttamanambi, of the Kāśyapa götra and the Rik sākha, (a servant) of the temple18 of Sri Ranganatha, a deed of a charitable gift, the terms of which are as follows: 
(LI. 14-24.) "In the presence of the god Madhavadēva of Chēvürakõte in our kingdom, which is situated on the river Bhavani, We, for the propitiation of the god Tryambaka, granted to Appannagalu, 8op of Ichappagaļu, of the Bharadväja götra and the Yajus fākha, on the Sravana-Dvadasi tithi of the bright fortnight of the month Bhadrapada of the year Jaya, the village of Naruvöru, situated on the bank of the river Kāvērī, in Kelangu nādu of the Rāyaräpura vēntheya (circuit or district) with all its appartenances (?) (kõluvali) 
- village which yields at present fourteen hons, as an ēkabhöga (village) by the of gift-water (on the hands of the donee) together with gold. 
(ul. 244-28) This Appannagaln, having received. it from our handa, gave the village of Narlyūru the name of Sriranganāthapura and established a course of offerings, eto., to be made daily to the god Sriranganātha, which is as follows:

(L1, 49-57.) - With these objects in view he, Appanna, granted the village (to son) by the pouring of water, together with gold, as a freehold, and, having executed this dred of in charitable grant, fixed on the boundaries of this village stones bean ng the sankha and the rishni (the emblems of Vishno, to whom the village is granted), so that you might enjoy the village with the eight kinds of enjoyment (enumerated), all income and all tases and conduct the charitable acts towards the god and the Bräbmapas. 
(L) 57-89.) " And, since this is an act of charity which We (i e, prince Haribara) bare (first) instituted, you (Utta manambi) should conduct the charities (which are once agarı repeated completely, as in 11. 28-56) according to the bond (edirēds) you have given in your turn to Appannagalu with your consent ; (besides this), you should dig tanks, Tells azi1 canals in the village of Naruvurus either from the money given to you by Appannagalu or from your own pocket, convert the land into gardens and paddy fields, improve the agricultur! prospects in it and conduct the charity from the said first tithr of the dark fortnight of the month of Bhădra pada of the year Jaya. 
(L1. 89-93.) - This is the charity deed given (to you) by Us with the firm faith that you (Uttamanambi) will conduct the charities as long as the moon and the sun exist." 
(L1. 93-98 contain the usual imprecatory verses.) (LI. 98 99 bear the signature of the king Vira-déva-Raya)

No or three year, age. This record throws some light on the hitherto obscure personality of tle anreate of the third dynasty of the Satraps of Saurashtra. The inscription is in a very imperfect size cf preservation and consists of six lines of writing The language of the recoml 1 S inskrit, and it is partly in prose and partly in terseThe inscribed surface INLASICA 2 LTE and the trerage length of letters is 11" The record opens with a number of lject 03 721 the first line ends with the name of Jiyadāman. The object of the rest of the 111*11701 15 10 record the excaration of well by the Judge or General (Ju7a-Deens nayaha) Sridharavarman the Scythian (faha), who was the son of Nanda the Sejthian, 22 the kingrom-increasing year 13. The middle of the record has suffered consider ably lr fk.no anil it is impossible to inake out any sense at all. The last two lines contain two prats of a verse in the Särdalarıkridita metre, which records the purpose of the inscription, 17 the escavation uf a well br Sridharararman The verse is followed by two numerical symbols and ly threc or four syllables which are illegible. The adjectives in the first line cannot refer to Jitalimau, as they begin with the ord Bhagaratah It is probable that some amp 1119011 Was nie between the lord who was the commander of the heavenly hosts, whose armies und dieser bean vanquisbed. the lord labāsēna (Shandu or Karttıheya), and Jiradivan, 1712- the fragmentary state of the first line prevents us from making any guesses. It 19 quite certail hometer, that the line ends with the word Jiradāman, the case-ending being illegible It 18 also quite certain that the word JTradāman is a proper name, and not an adjunct of any other name The connection between the first line and the second line cannot be made out. It begins with the word dharmma-Izjayana, which is an adjunct of the subject Sridizrazarınmana. It contains & phrase the exact m

812-taju-abhivriddhi-karê vaijayike sa vatsarê means "in the kingdom-incrcasing victorious year." This phrase is quite intelligible, if it is used in connection with reigning sovereign , but its meaning becomes du bious when it is used in the case of a royal oficer In this record it is used in the case of a Maha-Dandanayaka, a judge or at best a commander of forces. Now what can be the kingdom of a judge or a general Yet the prefis sla shows clearly that the adjective must refer to the subject immediately preceding it, ie 
Sridhar avarnımanã. It is quite possible that in the troublesome times which saft the end of the first dynasty of Satraps in Western India a judge or a general may have practically obtained independence, but the use of regnal years in the case of a prince who for some reason or other bad refrained from openly proclaiming his royalty is very unusual Sridharavarman does not claim any royal titles : therefore it is extremely improbable that the year 13 mentioned in line 2 was a year of his reign Most probably it is a regnal year of the reign ol llis luastur or suzerain who is mentioned in the previous line 
The other interesting feature of this record is the numerical symbols which have been incised after the last verse The reason for putting the numerical figures at the end of the record without an explanatory word is not apparent They are two in number. There a no doubt about the reading of the second symbol It is a symbol for the unit and is used commonly in Kushan records and Western Satrap records and coins The other symbol is less tasily recognisable It resemlles to some extent the Kushan symbol for 70 But it secms that it is the Western Kshatrapa symbol for 200 written at one stroke. It is a modiher form of the symbol for 100 commonly used on Kshatrapa coins, wlich consists of two semicircles placed horizontally side by side, with the right end produced downwards and then macle tu curve Lotards the lett The symbol for two hundred has a short horizontal line attached to middle of the right vertical limh, to its right In the Siñchi record we have a mollified forin of this symbol, vhich resembles the English letter Y written in the current band The symbol for 200, as used on the coins, Las been modified in the inscrption, because in this case the sonte attempted to wote it, and in fact wrote it, at one stroke of the pen IIcre ve bare ti o pomen equivalents for the first numerical symbol, i e. 70 and 200 We do not Imnow u12+ this 71 or 201, indicates. It is not preceded by any such word tarslē or $1*11+tarle Yet its but one way of explaining the presence of the symbuls, let'. It is a date Tlie quidfying muid seems to have been omitted through negligence. The Saka era is almost universally used in the inscriptions and on the coins of the Western Satrans, and the prelix Stämn and the affi, lãnran indicate that the master or suzerain of the Maha-Daudanayaka Sridharavarman was descended from some youugor branch of the family of Cbāshtana. Therefore it is extremely probable that the date useil in the Saūgli inscription is a Saka date. Now, considerng the form of the characters used in the record, at 18 absolutely impossible to admit that the numerical symbols acte 
erence in the forins of the characters used in the Junávarlb inscription of Rudradã man, which was incised shortly after the year 72 of the Saka dia, and those of this from Säñchi is very great, and therefore it is quite certain that the Sanchi inscription 
could not have been incised in the Saka year 71 On the other hand, the alternative suyganiel gives a titting explanation to all the points raised by the newly discovered 1711;'On Th record meations Svänin Jivadāman in the first line. We know from coins that the Kshatrat Rudrasımla II had acuared the country of Saurāshtra in S. 227-305 A.D Thurufavit 1 qute possible that his father was alive and was ruling in S. 201279 A D. 
The Sanchi inscription, therefore, furnishes us with three different items on britto unknown informaruu about Svāmın Jivadāman; it furnishes us with (1) his date. (2).' min alimy of Ila scien, and (3) the locality of his principality. 
It is now almost certain that the date of the record is $. 201—279 A.D.; and the associat:on of Jiradaman's pane with it shows that he was reigning in that year. It is also exturiy

probable that the kingdom-increasing and victorious reign of the Maha-Dandanāyaka Sridhara BirIran is really the 13th year of Jivadaman's reign. The accession of Jīva dāman can therefore be placed tentatively in Ś 201-13=188=266 A.D Jivadaman could not have been the ruler of Saurashtra in S 188=266 A D., because we find an almost unbroken series of dated coins of the Malā-Kshatrapa Rudrasēna II and his sons the Mahā-Kshatrapas Visvasi ha and Bhartridáman from $ 187 to Š 201 It is therefore almost certain that Svāmin Jivadaman 
ad nu control over Saurashtra during this period. The conclusion is, therefore, that he had ingur. his career as the ruler of Malaya, in which country the first record of his reign has been n scoiered.

No. 17.---THREE KSHATRAPA INSCRIPTIONS 
BY RAKHALDAS BANERJI AND VISHNO S SCETHANKAR 
These three Kshatrapa inscriptions, which are now exhibited in the Watson Bluseum of Antiquities at Rājkot, have been published before, at different times and different places, but ale here re-edited in order to have them properly illustrated and render them easily accessible A comparison of the originals with the facsimiles of the same inscriptions published in the Bhay. nagar Collection of Prakrit and Sanskrit Inscriptions made us feel the special need of placing before scholars reliable facsimiles obtained by purely mechanical means. These, it is hoped, will enable even those scholars who are not in a position to examine the stones personally to reconsider the previous readings, which, in our opinion, are in many respects defective. Our transcripts, which were in the first instance prepared from ink-impressions and squeezes, fere subsequently compared with the originals 
I.Gunda Inscription of the time of the Kshatrapa Rudrasimha : the year 103. 
The inscription was first edited, with a translation, in 1881, by Georg Bühler in Ind. Ant., Vol. X, pp 157 f from an eye-copy and a transcript prepared by Pandit Vallabhacharya Hari. datta of Kathiävād and submitted to Buhler by Major Watson for publication. Nine years later Bühler published some corrections in Sitzungsber. Wen. Akad W788, Phil. Hist Kl, Vol. CXXII, No XI, p 46, note 2, which publication was unfortunately not accessible to the writers of this article The posthumous papers of Bhagvanlal Indraji edited by Rapson in the Jour. Roy. 48. Sor. (1890) contain a short note (pp. 650 f.) on this inscription. In 1895 the text and a translation of this epigraph were republished in the Collection of Prakint and Sanskrit Inscrip tions, Bhavnagar, pp. 21 f., No. 3 and Plate XVII. In 1896 appeared in the Bombay Gazetteer, Vol. I, Part I, p. 42, some corrections proposed by Bhagvanlal Indran himself in his earlier readings and interpretation, Rapson, in Jour Roy As. Soc, 1899, p 375, also published some fresh corrections. The Catalogue of the Coins of the Andhra Dynasty, etc (1908), of Rapson includes (p Ixi) a short note on this record, which gives reference to the literature on the sub ject and briefly summarizes the contents of the inscription. In 1912 Prof Luders in his List of Brahmt Inscriptions (Appendix to Dpigraphia Indica, Vol X, No 963) gave a complete biblio graphy of the inscription, a reading of the date (it cannot be said whether from the rab.bed facsimile or directly from an impression of the stone), and a summary of its contents 2nd finally, in 1915, Prof. D. R. Bhandarkar pablished some corrections of previous readings and interpretations in Prog Rep Arch. Suru of India, TV Circle, 1914-15, p. 67 
The inscription was discovered in 1880 by Major Watson in an old unused well at Gunda in #bo Elálär District of North Kathāvād It was subsequently removed to the temple of Dvára kānitza at Jamnagar, where, apparently, it was kept until its transference to the Watson Museum of Antiquities at Rājkot

(VOL. XVI.

THREE KSHATRAPA INSCRIPTIONS. 
233 
expressed both in words and numerical ideograms. There can be little doubt that the era to which the year in this inscription is to be referred in the Saka era Accorclingly the inscription may be taken to be dated roughly in the year A.D. 181. It will be remembered that the erudence afforded by the dates and the legends on the coins of Ruchasımlıa learl us to mier that he ruled first as Kshatrapa in the year 1012-3, then as Maha-Kshatrapa from 103 to 110), then again as Kshatrapa from 110 to 112, and lastly as Maha-Kshatrapa from 113 to 118 (or 119). According to this scheme the present inscription must be taken to refer to the period when he was reigning as Kshatrapa for the first time The earliest date we have for bis leigu is the year 102 on a coin belonging to the Cunningham collection. 
The object of the inscription was to record the digging and constructing, at the village of Rasõpadra, of a well by the general (senāputi) Rudrabhūti, son of the general (wend pati) Bãpaka, the Abhira. 
The village of Rasõpadra, which is the only locality mentioned in this record, remains unidentifieil.

TRANSLATION, 
HarlOn the auspicious)] fifth tithi of the bright fortnight of Varšākha during the auspicious perzod of the constellation of Rohini, in the year one hundred and three2_100 3 (during the reiện) of the king, the Kshatrapa Lord Rudrasiha (Rudrasinha), the SOD of the king, the Bahı-Kshatrapa Lord Rudradāman (and) son's son of the king, the Kshatrapa Lord Jayedáman, (and) grandson's son of the king, the Maha-Kshatrapa Lord Chashtana, the well was caused to be dug and embanked by the general (sēnāpati) Rudrabhấtı, the son of the general (seiripatı) Băpaka,3 the Abhira,+ at the village (grāma) of Rasõpadra, for the welfare and comfort of all living beings. 
II.--Gadhā (Jasdan) Inscription of the time of the Mahā-Kshatrapa Rudrasēna: the 
year 127 (or 126). 
The inscription was first edited, with a translation and lithograph, prepared probably from an eye-copy, in 1868, by Dr Bhau Daji in Jour Bo Br Roy As Soc, Vol. VIII, pp. 234 f., and Plate. After that it remained unnoticed till 1883, when Hoernle published a revised transcript and translation of it in Ind. Ant , Vol. XII, pp. 32 f. The posthumous papers of Bhagvanlal Indraji, edited by Rapson in Jour. Roy. As Soc, 1890, p 652, cuntain a short note on it. In 1885 the text and a translation, based upon the editio princeps of Dr. Bhau Daji, were repablished in the Collection of Prakrit and Sanskrit Inscriptions, Bhavnagar, pp. 22 No 4, and Plate XVIII The Bombay Gazetteer, Vol. I, Part I, p 43, contains a very short note on iting originating from the pen of Bhagvanlal Indraji. Rapson's Catalogue of the Coins of the Andhra Dynasty, etc. (p. lai, No 42), includes a short suinmary of its contents, and a reference to the literature of the subject. Prof. Luders in his List of Brahmi Inscriptions (Appendıı to Dpigraphia Indica, Vol X), No. 967, gives a complete bibliography of the inscrip tion, a reading of the date (it cannot be said whether from the published facsimiles or directly from au impression of the stone), and a summary of its contents. Prof. DR. Bhandarkar refers to the inscription in Prog. Rep Arch Surv of India, W. Circle, 1914-15, pp 67-68, and suggests certain corrections. 
The inscription is said to have been found at Gadha, about two miles north of Jascian, Käthjāvad, engraved on a thick irregular slab standing upright on the margin of & lake. Subsequently the inscribed stone was transferred to the Watson Museum of Antiquities, Rajkot, where it is now exhibited

THREE KSHATRAPÅ INSCRIPTIONS. 
237 
WA 
The inscription contains six irregular lines of varying length and uncouth writing, covering a rhomboidal space of about 3 ft. 7 in in width by about 1 ft 10 in. in height. The engraving, which is shallow, is on the whole in a fair state of preservation. The average size of such letters as n, nz, p, and b is about 11". 
The characters of the inscription are of the same general type as those of other Kshatrapa inscriptions, and the above remarks on the palæography of the Gundā inscription are, with a few exceptions, applicable to this one also The letters of this epigraph lack, however, all regularity and finish, they have a decidedly cursive character. Observe, for instance, the form 
bined my wbich is sometimes denoted by the older X-shaped form of the earlier inscriptions and sometimes by a more advanced form which is met with, regularly, only in the records of the Gupta dynasty The letter t appears to have been drawn with prongs of unequal length, both curved, one of them berug slightly longer than the other. In tra the subscript r is marked by drawing the free end of the right prong to a little distance to tae left, thus this ligature and the uncombined t are indistinguishable from each other when either of them is badly drawn. Of initial vowels the inscription contains 2 (1 5) and a (1 6) Subscript consonants, excluding r and y, are expressed by the ordinary full signs of the letters, as in the Gundă inscrip tion described above. No final consonants appear in this record. Sporadically one notices the flattening out of the serif of the letters into a thin horizontal top line, so that in some cases it becomes extremely difficult to say whether the top-stroke is only a seref or the sign of a, ē or , which is marked by a slight prolongation of the serif The length in st (1. 5) is denoted by a distinct spiral, which is a further development of the form which was met with in the Gunda inscription To judge by the instance of bhātrabhih (for bhrätribhra) in line 6, no distinction was made in writing between the subscript r and the medial ri The diphthong au ig marked by the addition of an upward stroke, slanting to the right, to the sign of o. On two occasions the engraver has omitted the syllable tra in writing Kshatrapasya Lastly it may be observed that the first line of the inscription contains four numerical symbols, 100, 20, 5 and another about the reading of which there is some doubt; it may be either 6 or 7. 
The language of the inscription is a mixed dialect. In this specimen the Prakritisms are slightly more numerous than in the Gundā inscription One may notice the frequent use of sa for the termination of the genitive singular in 1l 1 and 2 in addition to the verbal form ufthavita[m] in 1. 6, The sense of the record, as it stands, is incomplete, and, to judge by the two final syllables sva[rga] in l. 6, it should seem that a few syllables or words, in an additional line which is now lost, are missing. [Regarding the irregular genitives (eg. maha Fshat[r]a pasa, 1.1) see remarks on Inscription No. I --Ed] -As regards orthography the only point worth drawing attention to is the sporadic doubling of the consonant before r in papar [+]trasya in l. 2; but it should be added that the reading of the ligature is not absolutely certain. Of words not found in dictionaries the inscription contains one, viz. satra, of which, moreover, the meaning is not known. Prof Lüders hesitatingly identifies it with the Prakrit word sata in an inscription from the Kaphēri caves (Lüders' List, No. 985), for which he, also doubtfully, suggests the meaning 'seat.' 
The inscription refers itself to the reign of the king (and) Maba-Kshatrapa Lord Rudrasena and records the erection of a satra (meaning ?) by the brothers of Kharar) pattha, the son of Pratāśaka of the Manasa gotra. Previous editors of the inscription have read in l. 6 Pranāthaka instead of Pratabaka and Khara-pautra instead of Khara[r]pattha. OIL. reasons for adopting the reading which we have will be found in the remarks on the transcript, below, p 238 The inscription gives the following pedigree: king and Mabi-Kshatrapa bhadra mukha Lord Chashtans; his son, king (and) Kshatrapa Lord Jayadāman; hie son, king and 
26 
238 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
LAW 
M 
uhu 
Mabi-Kshatrapa bhadra-mutha Lord Rudradāman; his son, king and Mabā-Kshatrapa lhadra mukha Lord Rudrasīha (Rudiasınha); his son, king and Mahā-Kshatrapa Lord Rudrasēna. This 19 the longest pedigree of the Kshatrapas of Sarashtra, and Mälava contained in a single record. It will be noticed that the title bhadra-ukha, 'of gracious appearance,' is added before the names of some of the Maha-Kshatra pas, but not before the name of the only Kshatrapa meri tioned in the record, or before that the last Maha-Kshatrapa named here, uz Rudrasēna, in whose reign the inscription was engraved The reason for the omission in the last case is not apparent; it would seen, however, that the title was used with the names of Mahā-Kshatrapa only The names of Damassada I. and Jivadāman, who had reigned before Radrasēna, but who were not in the direct line of descent, are not included in this list, which is purely genea. logical. 
The inscription is dated in the year 127 (or 126) on the fifth tithi of the dark half of the month of Bhadrapada. The era to which the date is to be referred is undoubtedly the Saka era, accordingly the date of the record may be taken to correspond to 127 (or 126) to 78 AD 205 (or 204). 
The record contains no geographical name.

TRANSLATION. 
On the fifth (titbı) of the dark fortnight of Bhadrapada in the year 100, 20 173. (during the reign) of the king, the Maha-Ksbatrapa Lord Rudrasēna, (son*] of the king, the Maha-Kshatrapa Lord Rudrasīha (Rudrasımha) of auspicious appearance (bhadra-mukhi); (and) son's son of the king, the Maha-Kshatrapa Lord Rudradāman of a uspicious appearance (bhadra-mukha), (and) grandson of the son of the king, the Kshatrapa Lord Jayadāman; (and) great-grandson of the son of the king, the Mabi-Kshatrapa Lord Chāshtana of auspicious appearance (bhadra-mukha);this satra? was erected by the brothers of Khara[2]pattha, the son of Pratāśaka of the Mānasa götra . . . . .. . heaven . 
III.-Junāgadh Inscription of the time of the grandson of the Kshatrapa Jayadāman. 
This inscription was first edited, with a translation and a photograph, in 1876, by Buhler in Arch Surv. West Ind, Vol II, pp. 140 f, and Plate XX; the block 18 rather small and almost useless for purposes of study. In 1895 Buhler's text was republished, with a few minor alterations, accompanied by a facsimile of an inked impression, and a translation of the text in the Collection of Prakrit and Sanskrit Inscriptrons, Bhavnagar, p. 17, No 1, and Plate XV Rapson gives an abridged bibliography of the inscription, and summarizes briefly its contents in his Catalogue of the Coins of the Andhra Dynasty, etc., p Ixr, No 40 The most recent notice is by Prof. Luders in his Inst of Brahmi Inscriptions (Appendix to Epigraphia Indica, Vol X (1912), No. 966), where we find a complete bibliography of the inscrip date (probably from the facsimile in the Bhavnagar Collection of Prakrit and Sanskrit Inscrip t10n8) and a summary of its contents. 
The inscription was discovered, during excavation, in front of one of the cells of an exten 
ho na sive complex of caves situated to the east of Junāgadh, close to a modern monastery known as Bāvā Pyāra's Math Regarding the mischances that fell to its lot after its discovery we have the following account by Burgoss. While extricating it, he writes, “the workmen damaged one end of it, but, to add to the misfortune, some one carried it off to the palace in the city, and in doing 80 seriously injured it at one corner When I went to photograph it, I had a difficulty 
1 Bhadra-wukha literally means 'locky-faced, bat is here used specifically as the title of some of the Mah Kshatrapas. 
9 This word has not been met with elsewhere and its meaning is uncertain Bhau Daf renders it with "tank" without assigning any reason for doing so, the dictionaries do not support this meaning. Hoernle saggests that it is & Prakrit forin of satra, which denotes * kind of expensive Söma sacrifice extending over many days*, to fatra of our text be assigns accordingly the derivative meaning of “liberality, munificence, which does not convince ar. It was remarked above that Prof Luders refors in this connection to tbe word sata ( seat) occurring in a Buddhist Cave inscription. Mr R D. Banerji looks upon the word as a Prakrit form of satra and would translate it as 
Imsbonse,' which ineaning that word has in most of the inodern dialoots of North India Mr DR Bhandarkar reads the word as Savarr and, connecting at with the following mmānasa-, regards Sakribānasa as the götra-name, an explanation which does not commend itselt to us. It may be noted that uttharsta clearly implies that we bara here to deal with a structure that was raised, elevated, erected, and not dog or sank

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI.

with 
wwwwwwwwwwwww

wwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww 
in tracing it; at length, however, it was found lying in a verandah in the circle in front of the palace,"?! For some time previous to its transference to the Museum the stone used to be kept in the State Printing Press at Junagadh. The misfortunes which have fallen to the lot of this stone since its recovery did not end with those described by Burgess. As a result of some fresh accident, it is now in two halves, probably having split along the fissure which is noticeable in the facsimile published in the Bhavnagar Collection of Sanskrit and Prakrit In. scriptions, and referred to in the letterpress accompanying the facsimile. 
The inscription is engraved on one of the faces of a dressed slab of soft calcareous stone about 2 feet each way and 8 inches thick. The epigraph contains four lines of writing, covering & space of about 1 ft. 9 in, in width by about 6 in in height. The average size of such letters as ng m, P. and b is about ". Much of the writing is seriously damaged. The two middle lines are in a fair state of preservation; but the greater part of line 1 and a good bit of line 4 are illegible. Moreover the inscription is fragmentary. The slab has lost a large fraction of its length : how much it is not possible to say Bühler assumes that lines 2-4, at their left ends, are almost intact, only a couple of syllables being necessary in each to complete them. This is, however, far from being certain. As far as we can judge, there is nothing to show how much is missing on either side of the preserved portion. We can only say that the lost portion of 11. 2 and 3 must have contained, at least, the names of the son and grandson of Jayadâman as well as the year in which the record was dated, expressed possibly both in words and numercal ideograms. 
The characters closely resemble those of the Gunda inscription of the time of the Kshatrapa Rudrasimha, which have already been minutely described above. It will, therefore, sufice to draw attention here only to a few outstanding features of the alphabet of this inscription. The syllable mê in l. 3, it will be noticed, shows that the sign of è in mi was attached to the con, stricted part of the letter. The same line offers & specimen of the numerical figure 5. The sign of the medial u in su (1.1) is seen to open towards the left; in sri (1. 3), on the other hand, 'it opens towards the right; of the medial u marked by a short horizontal stroke appended to the long Vertical of a letter this inscription contains no specimen. We have here only one initial vowel, mamely i (1. 3); it is denoted by three dots, of which two are placed in a vertical line on the left side of the remaining one. In the middle bar, which is attached only at one end, is almost vertical. The letter y shows the simple bipartite form. [In regard to the language we may note the irregular genitives (e.g kahastrapa]sya, 1. 2) as in Inscriptions Nos. I and II. Ed] - As regards orthography the only point worth noting is that the ingcription offers na instance of the phonetic dog bling of consonants, 
The inscription must belong to the reign of a Kshatrapa or Mahā-Kshatrapa who was the grandson (or rather son's son) of the king, Kshatrapa Lord Jayadāman, and great-grandson of Chashtana ; the name of the ruling prince is lost with the portion of the record which 18 missing. This Satrap to whose reign the record referred itself was therefore exther Dămaysade I or Rudrasimha I (the brother and successor of the former). The purport of this fragments ary inscription cannot be determined, as the portion containing the object of the record is losta It may be added that from the occurrence of the expression kevabz-jñāna-sam(prāpta] (who had arrived at the knowledge of the kēvalins') in l. 4 it may be surmised that the inscription probably had something to do with the Jainas, since the word kēvalin occurs most frequently in Jaina literature. 
The ingcription is dated on the fifth (5th) day of the light half of Chaitra in a year which, like the purport of the record, cannot be ascertained, as it is lost in a lacuna of the text.

No. 18-THE PENUGULURU GRANT OF TIRUMALA I; SAKA 1493. 
By C. R. KRISHNAMACHARLO, B.A., MADRAS. 
The subjoined inscription is engraved on seven copper-plates which were forwarded," in 1913, by A. H. A. Toda, Esq, I.C.S., then Special Settlement Officer, Badanapalli, Chitoor district, Madras Presidency, for examination, to the Assistant Archæological Superintendent for Epigraphy, Southern Circle. It has been briefly reviewed by the latter officer in his Annual Report for 1912-13 (No. 1 of Appendix A. and page 24. para. 61). I bow edit it for the first time from a set of unk-impressions kindly placed by him at my disposal. 
From a set of estain pages. 
2 This as very probubly the set of copper-plates noticed by Mr. Sewell in his Lists of Antiquittes, Tol 1, P. 131, as being in the posscasion of one Pidatala Chellanbhatlu in the village Pedagzlara in the Pullarret tūluka of the Cuddapah district The on ner is evidently a descendant of the first in the list of the donees mee tioned in the grant. See p. 258 bulow.

242 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[Vol. XVI. 
mv 
The plates measure 73" by 72", and have, like other Vijayanagara ones, a curved top portico, which is provided with a hole, through which passes the ring holding the plates together, 
om of which, shaped like a signet-ring, slides on the main ring. The seal is circular and has a diameter of 1". It beals the following emblems out on its countersunk surface comme 
(c) the sun and the crescent (with a star in it) in a line at the top, from the proper 
right to the proper left, (b) a ranning boar, facing the proper left, with a dagger in front pointing downwards, 
below (a), and (c) a floral device helow (b), separated from it by a double line, which is probably meant 
to represent the stand for the boar. All the plates, except the first and the last, are engraved on both he sides, and all, except the last plate, are numbered in Telugu-Kannada numerical figures on their first sides, at the left margin. In the last plate, at the top, a space for five lines is left uninscribed, though it has been ruled for writing, as in the case of a few other Vijayanagara coppar-plates. The plates bear slightly-raised rims, as a result of which the ink-impressions from which the accompanying facsimile plates are inade have not come out very well. At the bottom of the written face of the last plate is engraved the colophon Sri-Virüpāksha' in the Telugu-Kannada script, representing, perhaps, the sign-manual of king Tirumala. Most of his predecessors on the Vijayanagara throne adopted the same form of signature. 
The inscription is engraved in the Nandi-Nāgari characters of the period to which the record belongs. The language emplıyed is Sanskrit prose and verse, the former occnrring only in the portion describing the details of the boundaries, marked by trees, tanks, wells, etc. (11 274 to 278). The engraving seems to have been done rather carelessly. There are many omissions of letters, eg Hētrio tor Hēnādrio (1.3), Vijayöbhinyuo for Vijayobhimanyuso (l. 9), Prabhadra" for rabhavadrā" (1 10), and repetitions of letters and of worrls, e g. sadguna-sadguna for sadguna (11. 54 f.), anukalamayamayamavao for anukalamayamāva“ (. 40), and mantra 
mantra-purassaran pipro (1.62), Wrong forms of words like Orhchhritaṁ for 'chrhhrutan (1.21), srita for śruta (1 83), sritē for śrutē (l. 103), sa inprīpaiya for samprā payya (1. 63), drima for drumat (1 66), "hridah for Chradan (l. 277), bahurija. (II. 177, 191, 193) and bamhurja (11. 180 and 197) for bahimcha, dvadasyam for dradaśyāin (1 104), "Käsyapao for Kasyapa" (1 120), samasuutë for samašnute (11. 186, 193), svēchchh-d dana for svērhchh-ādāna (1. 122) seem to be the result of mis pronunciation of the classical words by people accustomed to the vernacular tongue. The forms karinyā for "kanyū (1. 18), kamnyako for kanyaka (1. 20), odhaminya for 'dhanya (1. 73), and pumnya for punya (. 11841) are due to the unnecessary, but intentional, stressing of the nasal sound wbich occasionally appears in the South-Indian pronunciation of Sanskrit words pronunciation of Sanskrit words 
Besides 
Besides, the Dravidian la appears in Sanskrit words in place of the correct la: lalatan for lälitam (1.5), Surabhi-a for Surabhı/-a (1 19), kamdalad-abhyu for kardalad-abhyu" (1. 25) and jala" for jala (l. 93). Examples of wrong forms due to local peculiarities of indifferent fronunciation are found in haram durgāni for har an durgānu (11. 13 and 14) and nirasyar Nrigao for nirasyan Naga (1 99), yēkayā for ēkaya (11. 16 & 171).171), yekavrityā for ēkavrttyä (1. 240), vuttai asyām tor uttarasyain and ayıśānyan for aršinyan (1 277). The sound of the intensive (sakata. répha) peculiar to the South Indian Ternaculars is in this inscription represented by the con junot consonant yra, and no with virāma (1. 230) and ru (11 233 and 276) is often employed to denotă the vowel grund ri, just as vu oocasionally appeals, as noted above, for the As dhe 
I The average South-Indian generally unispronounces the ri sound of Sanskrit words as ghz Qr ru, eso Krishnt is almost always pronounced as Krishna or Krushna7

The use of vzkriti forms like Châlikka for Chalukya (1. 67, and rriūriukiu for 4 isihy (1. 87) is noteworthy. 
The inscription is one of Tirumala I, the first crowned Vijayanagara king of the Araviti lice of the third Vijayanagara dynasty, which traced its descent from the Moon aud nas of the Atréva gotra It is dated in the Saka year 1493, Prajāpati, Māgha, sukla-dvadesi (8., the 12th day of the bright fortnight). According to Dewan Bahadur L. D. Swamikannu Pilar Ephemeris this corresponds to Saturday, 26ta January, 1572 AD. The gevealogy of tie king furnished by the record and the mention made in at of some other meinbors of this familr agree with what we find in otber published inscriptions of this dynasty. The Telugu poetica) work Vasz-charrtramu of Rāmarājabbūshana, the court-poet of our bing, also gives at me length an account of the meinbers of this family. The Arariti line appears from literature and inscriptions to have played an important part during the sovereignty of the kings of the second Vijayanagara dynasty and even for sometime previous. Bukka of Aravīdu is stated (.8) to have helped sāluva Nrisimha to put his rule on a firm basis. This probably refers to the help rendered by Bukka to tho first usurpation of the Vijayanagara CIOXD by the Sāluvas. About Rämarāja, the son of Bukka, the inscription says Sahasrals=$aptarna sahitam api yas=sundhu-janusham Sapadasyzanīkan samrtı bhuja-sauryēna mahatā ty= adatte sm=ādavanigirir durgam. Dr. Hultzsch, 5 and others after bin, have taken this passage to mean that he conquered Sapada, and captured from him the fort of Avanigiri-durga. But it is evident tbat we bave to separate the compound differently as ādattē sv=Aluvani. 
The position and the form of the anusvāra in these plates are similar to those in the Värēdapalli grant of Ranga II (see Plete opposite page 330 of Epigraphia Indica, Vol. XI). In the earlier Vijayanagara grants the form of the anusvära was a complete circle (Epigraphia Indica, Vol. III, Plate opposite page 38, and Epigrapkin Indica, Vol. VII, Plate opposite page 82), while the visarga was composed of tho sach circles ore abute the other. The position of the anusrära in the last but one of the references quoted ia era tly as in the mouern Dërs-Nagari, + e. right above the letter to which it belongs. In the Dendapalle plates of Vijaya-Bhüpatı (-. 1382), edited by Mr. G. Venkobo Roo (Epigraphra Indica, Vol. XIT, pp. 68 ff.), the anunlara is a loop, is in the earlier plates, but placed at the left-hand top corner, as in the plates under notice

giri-durgain and translate the passage 'he took from him the hill-fort of Adavani. In agroe ment with this it is also clearly mentioned in the Telugu poem Rāmarājiyarnu, or Narapati. vijayamu, of Andugula Venkayya that Rāma crushed Kāśappudaya, who had hid himself in Ādavani-durga. Ada yani is the modern Adoni in the Bellary district. Kāšappudaya (=Käsappa-Udaiyar.-F.W.T), from whom Rāmarāja took this hill-fort, has not been identified. Râmnaraja conquered also Kamdanavõlu (modern Kurnool); and the Vasu-charitramu informs as that he had his residence at that historic town. Ramarãja had according to this latter poem three sons, viz. Timmarāja, Konda and Sriranga, of whom the inscription mentions only the last. 
Tirumala's appearance in epigraphical records ranges from about Saka 1465 to Saka 1493.4 In Śaka 1465-(A.D. 1543) Tirumala was governing the Udayagiri-durga, perhaps as a deputy of his elder brother Rämarāja, under the name Rämarāja-Timmayya-dēva-Mahārāja.5 Subsequently too be governed the province Udayagiri-rājya till Saka 1473. In this year it is stated that he was enjoying the nayarkaram (lordship) of this province, governing it through his agent Bayacharājayya, and that he was succeeded in that office by Timmayya dēva-Mahāraja, son of Könētayya-dēva-Mahārāja.? 
From Saka 1473 to 1477.Tirumala seems to have remained at the capital as the minister of Sadasiva. From Saka 1477 to Saka 1481 he filled the office of the minister. It may be observed that Cæsar Frederio states that during the regency of Rāmaraja his younger brothers, Tirumala and Venkatādri, were respectively minister and commander-in-ebiet In Saka 1488 Tirumala was raling over the Kondavidu-rajya 10 After the battle of Talikota (25-1-1565 A.D.)11 he became the most important person in the court and kingdom of Vijayanagara owing to the death of Rämarāja in that battle. The period Saka 1489 to Saka 1493 (the date of this iosoription) is a rather doubtful one, for which we do not find any inscriptions which definitely describe the position of Tirumala. In the first of these years Tirumala made a gift in his own name, and in the last, we are told that he was ruling the earth. We know also that the latest year for Sadāśiva was Saka 1492 14 Tirumala thus could only haveruled for three years, 
1 These facts are also mentioned in the Vasu-chartramu.

No. 18.) 
THE PENU GULURU GRANT OF TIRUMALA I: SAKA 1493. 
245 
w 
ee from about 1-11-1571 A.D. to about A.D. 1574, since the inscriptions of his son and succes sor Sriraiga (II) begin to date from Saka 1496, Tirumala appointed his four sons to the several governorships in the kingdora. And in the last days of his life be sought the company of the wise and the learned, leaving the burden of government to his song.” 
Tirumala was a lover of learning and even aspired to the fame of authorship. He figures as the writer of a commentary called Sruti-rañjini on Jayadēva's Gita-Govinda (Annual Report on Epigraphy for 1899, p. 9). From the colophon to this work we learn that Tirumala's favourite deity was Rāma. Probably it was on account of this devotion that he is often praised in the present record as a repository of nectar-like devotion to Hari (Hari-bhakti-sudha-ridhi 
(1. 95) and Hari-gochara-mānasa (1. 82)). 
The object of the inscription is to register the grant of the village Penugulāru (1. 115) (called also Penalūr, perhaps by mistake for Pengalör in l. 130) alias Yollama-raja-samudram (Ellama-rājēndra-samudram, 11. 113, 130, and Yellamarājasamudra, 1.274), together with the two hamlets Yelammapadu-Chennapalli and Kondūru-Chonnapalli, made by king Tirumala at the request (vijñapti) of the Matla chief Timmarāja, to a number of Brahmaps. Penuguluru is said to be situated on the eastern bank of the river Mahābāhu in Pottapa-rządu, a division of the Siddhavara-sund. The entire village was divided into 128 vrittis (1. 129) and given to (115) Brāhmanas who were highly learned in the sāstras and were masters of the Vedanta. But the actnal number of vrittis granted comes to 1281. Among the beneficiaries two were poets. Besides these, one vritti was granted for the study (?) of the Rog- Véda, one for that of the Yajur Vēda, and one each to the local shrines of Vishnu and Hara (1. 273). Penuguluru is the modero Penagalūru in the Pullampet taluka of the Cuddapah district in the Madras Presidency. Of the villages Pottapi, Srīvaram, Kondūru, Sinkamāla, Tirumalarā: mentioned among the boundaries of Penuguluru, the first, second, fifth and the sixth are 
identical with the modern Pottapi, Sirivaram, Indlūru and Tirumalarāzupēta in the same taluka. The river Mahābõhu is the Telugu Cheyyēru, which separates Penagaläru from Pottapi. The village Kondūru-Chennapalli of the inscription is identical with Kondüru Chennarāya-samudram, about 2 miles north-east of Penagalūru. Yelammapadu-Chennapalli seems to have changed its name sabsequently and to have been attached to Singanamála (Sinkamála of our inscription), being now called Singanamāla-Chennarāya-samudram. My thanks are due to E. A.. Davis, Esq., Acting Collector of Cuddapah (1914), who very kindly obliged me by furnishing a tracing showing the localities mentioned in the inscription. 
Timmarāja, who made to king Tirumala the request for the grant, belonged to the family of Matlas • They were of the Sürya-vamsa (1. 119), the Kaśyapa götra (1. 120) and the Chola lineage (I. 122). The family was known also as the Dēve-Choda family. It must have taken 
1 Epigraphia Carnatica, Vol XII, Ck. 8, and abzd., Vol. VII, Sb 55. 
% 7a8r-charitramu, Asmāsa I, verses 67-82 · Raghonātba, the eldest son, was ruling over the northern part of the kingdom, fighting against the Malakas (Mallicks, 1 e. Mohainmadan chieftains) ; Siiranga, the second son, was crowned as Yuvarāja and remained at the capital. Raunarāja, the third son, was ruling over the Šri. rangapattana province, wbile Venkata ruled over the Chandragiri province. 
& The actual form used in the inscription is Cbita-Pottapa-rādu. Evidently Pottapa-nādu is a mistaka for Pottapi-nādu. The division Siddhavara-sīmā, in which Penugulūru was situated, could not bave been called after the village Siddhavaram in the Pullampet taluka only 2 miles from Penagalūru, but imust be identified with Siddhavata-sīmã in which according to No 436 of the Madras Epigraphical Collection for 1911 Pottapi-nādu vas situated. According to tho same inscription Siddhavata-simā was a subdivision of the Urlayagiri- ágya. 
In Telugu literary works the family name is given indifferently as Matla and Matil. This inscription uniformly has the foimer, 
5 No. 564 of 1915. 
2 12 
246 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL. XVI. 
wwwwwwwww 
wwwwwwwwwwwww 
its name from Matli, & village in the Rẫyachoti taluka of the Cuddapah district This family seems to have been in power during the time of the second and third Vijayanagara dynasties. Inscriptions relating to the chiefs of the family, found in the Madras Epigraphical Reports, show that they were in power till the end of the 17th century A.D. Ananta, the younger brother of Timmarāja, was the author of the well-known Telugu poem Kākustha-vijayamu. The genealogy given in the prologue to this work mentions & Bomma as the founder of the family. Varadarāja, the great-grundson of Bomma, 18 said to have been the son-in-lapy of the great Vijayanagara emperor Krishga-Rāya. Tirumala (I) is stated to bave granted the country of Pottapi-nādu ab anara-nayaka to this Varadaraja (called Varadayya-Dēvachoda Maharāja). The Matli chiefs were dependants and adherents of Tirumala from the time of his local governorship and ministry. An unpublished Telugu inscription' in the huge tower of the Govindarāja-Perumal temple at Lower Tirupati (Cbitoor district, Madras Presidency) states that the tower was built by the Mahamandalēśvara Matla Anantarājayya Dēvachoda-Mah - rāja, son of Tirüvengalanatharājayye-Dēvachoda-Mahārāja. This Anantarāja must evi. dently be a grandson of the poet Ananta, since from No. 564 of the Madras Epigraphical Collection, 1915, we learn that the poet had a sou called Tiruvengalanátha. 
The members of the Matla family must have been staunch Vaishnavas. The poet Ananta, in the prologue to his work, invokes the blessings of the god (Vishnu) of Tirupati and his Bymbols. In the colophon to this same work Ananta calls himself a disciple of the Vaishnava teacher Tirumala Tolappa-acharya. 
The grant was composed by the poet (kavi) Svayambhū, the son of Sabhāpati. The latter 988 B poet at the court of Achyata-Raya and composed his Unanäñjęli grant. Likewise Gana peya-áchārya was the engraver of our inscription, while his father Virana incised the Unamáñ jēri plates. The offices of composer and engraver seena to have gone by heredity in the Vijaya Dagara court. 
The grant was made in the presence of (the god) Rāmachandra, evidently the god of that namo in s temple at Penugonda. It is to be observed that, though the grant was made in the presence of Rāma and on that account one would expect the sign-manual of the king to consist of the name of that deity, we nevertheless find both in these and in the Tumkur plates of this king that the sign-manual continues to be Sri-Virüpāksha, the name of the tutelary deity of the earlier Vijayanagars kings. In the grants of Sriranga (II), the son and successor of Tirumala, the same sign-manual still continues. But subsequent to him 'Sri-Virüpāksha' gives place to 'Sii-Terkutöśa.? This marks a transition in the devotion and creed of the later Vijayanagara kungs.

बुझाव 18 नीपतिलको बुधकल्पशाखौ । कल्याणिनों कमलनाम इवाधिकन्या' 19 बझांबिकासुदवहहहुमान्यशीला [*] अतेव कलशांबुधैश्सुरभिका 20 शुगं माधवाकुमारमिष शंकराल्कुलमहीभृतः कन्यका । जयंतमम 21 रप्रभोरपि शचीव बुलाधिपात जगति बलमालभत रामराज 22 सुतं ॥१.*] सहत्रैश्सप्तत्या' सहितमपि यधिस धुजनुषां सपादस्था

Second Plate; First Side. 25 कंदनवोलिदुर्गमुरुकंदकदभ्युदयो बाहुबलेन यो 26 बहुतरेण विजित्य हरेः । सविहितस्य तत्र चरणांबुषु भ 27 तातया ज्ञातिभिरपितं सुधयति स्म निशेव्य विषं [१२] श्रीराम. 28 राजक्षितिपस्य तस्य चिंतामणेरर्थिकदंबकानां । लक्ष्मीरि 29 वांभोडहलोचनस्य लकांबिकामुष्ट महिष्यलासीत् [१३] त 30 स्याधिकैरसमभ[व]त्तमयस्तपोभिश्रीरंगराजनृपतिशशि 31 वंशदीपः । आसन्ममुझसति धामनि यस्य चित्रं नेत्राणि वैरि 32 सुदृशां च निरंजनानि [१४] सती तिरुमलांबिकां चरितलीलया 33 संधतीप्रथामपि तितिक्षया वसुमतीयशो कंधतीं । हिमांशु 84 रिव रोहिणी हृदयहारिणी सद्गुणैरमोदत सधर्मिणीमयम 35 वाप्य वीराग्रणी: १५*] रचितनयविचारं रामराजं च धीरं वरति 86 समलरायं वेंकटाद्रिक्षितीश । अजनयन स एतानानुपूर्खा कुमा

38 तीन्ममिति निहत्य स रामराजवीरः । भरतमनुभगीरथादिराज 39 प्रथितयशाः प्रशशास चक्रमाः ।[१७*] वितरणपरिपाटी यस्य विद्याधु 40 रीणां मखरमुखरवीणानादगीतानिशम्य [1] अनुकलमयमयमावा 41 लांबबिंबापदेशादमरनगरशाखो लब्जया मज्जतीव [१८*] व्यराजत 42 श्रीवरवेंकटादिराज[:*] श्रिया निर्जितराजराजः । ज्याघोषदूरी 43 कृतमेघनादः कुर्वन्मुमित्राशयहर्षपोषं [१८*] त्रिषु श्रीरंगमाप 44 रिबृढकुमारेष्वधिरणं विजित्यारिमापांस्तिरुमलमहाराय 45 नृपतिः । महौजासाम्राज्ये सुमेतिर भिषिक्तो निरुपमे प्रशास्त्युर्वी 46 सर्वामपि तिसषु मूर्तिष्विव हरिः ।।२०*] यशस्विनामग्रसरस्य यस्य 47 पट्टाभिषेके सति पार्थिवें दोः । दानांबुपूरैरभिषियमाना देवीप 48 दं भूमिरियं दधाति ।[१२१*] यस्यातिप्रौडतेजश्सवितर' विमतध्वांत

Second Plate ; Second Srde. 49 भैदिन्युदीत' कीर्तिचीराणवांत[:*] स्फुटतरविकसत्पुंडरी 50 कोपमस्य । श्रेतश्छन स्य*] मध्ये कनककलशिका भासते कर्णिका 61 भा() तस्योपति मराकइयमिव विचलचामरहमास्ते । [१२२*] B2 भोगित्वे विदितेपि जिह्वर्ग' इति व्याकाधिराजं लसदृत्त 53 त्वे(पि) जळसंश्रयीति कमठं दानपि मंदा इति। दिब्रागा-10 64 न्भृशमुबतौ च कठिमा इत्येव हित्वा गिरीस्तत्तत्महुण (स bb हुण)संपदेकशरणं भूरेति हर्षेण यं [१२३*] स्वैरं संकृतकंट 56 कीथ मुक्कतोत्कृष्टां1 विधायाखिलं माकेदारमुदारदान 57 सलिलासारै समापूर्य च [*] संवद्ध्यानधकीर्तिसस्यनिव 68 हं तत्पालिकां विक्रमश्रीकांतां भुजकायमानशिखर धत्ते 59 हि यस्तेजसा ।[१२४*] जिष्णुत्वं शुचितां प्रजासु समतावर्तित्वमप्या. 60 [श्रितो वृत्तिं पुण्यजनप्रियामधिगतः ख्यातः प्रचेता इति ।(1) 61 प्राप्तस्यर्थनबिनमी धनपतिश्साविज्ञभावांचितः प्रायो यः प्रकटी

86 जामुदारयशाः । अतिबिरुदतुरगध'हो मतिगुरुरारहम 86 गधमान्यपदः [३५*] शल्यारिनीतिशाली कल्याणपुराधिपः 87 कलाचतुरः । चालिकचक्रवर्ती माणिक्कमहाकिरीटमहनी 88 यः [३६ *] एबिरुदरायराहुतवेश्यकभुजंगबिरुदभरितसी । 89 रम्यतरकीतिरोड्डिय*] रायदिशापट्टबिरुदघोषण [३७*] ओषधि[पत्य *] 90 पमाईतगंडस्तोषणरूपजितासमकांडः । भाष'गेत 21 प्युवरायरगड: पोषणनिर्भरभूनवखंडः [३८*] राजाधिरा. 92 जस्तेजस्वी श्रीराजपरमेश्वरः । मुरुरायरगंडांको मे 93 कलंधियशोभरः [३८*] परदारेषु विमुखः पररायभयंक 94 र:[*] शिष्टसंरक्षणपरो दुष्टशार्दूलमईनः । अरीभगंडभे 95 रंडो हरिभक्तिसुधानिधिः [18.*] इत्यादिबिरुदैवैदितत्या नित्य 96 मभिष्टुतः । जय जीवेति वादिन्या जनितांजलिबंदया ।[1४१*] कांभी 97 जभोजकाळिंगकरहाटादिपार्थिवैः । प्रतीहार 98 पदं प्राप्त [*] प्रस्तुत*]स्तुतिघोषणः ।[१४२*] सोयं सिंहासनस्थ: सुगुण

Third Plate; Second Srde. 99 श्रीमहारायवर्यः () कीर्त्या नीत्या निरस्यं नृगनकन 100 हुषानप्यन्यामथान्यान् । आ सेतोरा सुमेरोरवनि 101 सुरनुत[:*] खैरमा चोदयाद्रेरा पाश्चात्याचलांतादखिल 102 हृदयमावर्ज राज्यं प्रशास्ति ॥[४३*]11 रामग्रहपयोधीदुगणि 103 ते शकवत्सरे । प्रजापत्यभिधे वर्षे मासि माघ इति शुते [1४४*] 104 पने वळते पण्यायां हादस्यां च महातिथौ । श्रीरामचंद्र 
* Read q. [In other inscriptions too the word occurs only as Y Perhaps it is the same as the Kanarese dattama mass, an army.-H.KS.]

* Read m and its This verse consists of three half-verses in the anushtubh metre. * The last half-verse is preceded in the Taukur plates by fe&TTEETAT TEYTIST* :. 7 Read free

* Read . 10 Read जय. 11 In place of this verse the Tumkur plates have the following two verses. 
(a) परिकुर्वन् कर्नाटककनकसिहासनमसौ 
महामक कल्पद्रुम व बुधानंदननिधिः। महीं सी शासन तिरुमलमहारायन्टपति.

THE PENUGULURU GRANT OF TIRUMALA I SAKA 1493.
