127 तपुरोगमैः । विविधैविबुधै[:*] श्रौतपधिरधिकैर्षिरा।। ६१*] म. 128 हाभुजस्तिरमलमहारायो मनस्विना' । महिरण्यपाधा 129 रापूर्वकं दत्तवान्मुदा ॥[६२*] अष्टाविंशतिमंयुक्तशतवृत्तिममन्वि 130 ते । श्रीमदेनमराजेंद्रसमुद्रप्रतिनामके ।[६३*] [प]नल राख्यसदा 131 मे तिमराजार्पितक्रमात् । नानाशाखाभिधागोत्रसूत्राशास्त्र 132 विशारदाः । वृत्तिमंती विलिख्यते विप्रा वेदांतपारगा: ।[1६४ *] याजुय 132 to 272 consist of the names of the donees given on pp 25s ff 
___Sarth Plute , Second Side 273 दावेड्डयधीमणीः । रेग्य जुर्वेदयोवृत्ती हे विषुहरयोस्तथा ॥ १७६ *]. 274 अस्य येल्लमराजसमुद्रेग्रामस्य दिक्षु मर्यादा[:] प्राच्या कुजरन]दप 276 विमभागे वटवृक्षः कूपश्च अज्ञेयां चेन्नारड्डिवन दक्षिणस्य अस्वत्य'त 276 टाकः नेरुल्यां अपवोरयतटाक: प्रतीयां रामलिगदेवालयः वायव्या 27 शमीक्ष: वुत्तरस्यां ताटिपतॊहृद: अयिशान्यां पुन्नागहृदः ताम 278 रसहदश्च ॥ 
Seventh Plate. 279 तदिदं नयधुर्य्यस्य श्रीतिरुमलरायवयस्य । शामनमातिवलशा 280 सनतरकरदानस्य गुणनिदानस्य ।[१७७*] तिहमलरायमहोपतिशा 281 सनतस्ताम्रशासनश्लोकान् [*] कविशासनस्वयंभूत्मरसमभाणीसभा 282 पतेश्स"नुः ।[१७८*] तिर्मलश्रीमहारायशासन, होरणात्मजोश्रोमहणपया 283 चार्यो व्यलिखत्ताम्रशासनं ।।१७ *] दानपाननयोमध्ये दानाच्छ्रेयो. 2844 नुपालनं । दानास्वर्गमवाप्नोति पालनादच्युतं पदं १८० *] खदत्ता 285 हि"गुणं पुण्यं परदत्तानुपालनं । परदत्तापहारण स्वदत्तं निष्फ 286 लं भवेत् ।[१८१*] स्वदत्तां परदत्तां वा यो त वसुंधरा । षष्टिवर्ष 287 सहयाणि विष्टायां जायते क्रिमिः ।[१८२*] एकेव भगिनौ लोके सर्वे 288 पामेव भूभुजां [*] न भोग्या न करग्राह्या विप्रदत्ता वसुंधरा ॥[१८३*] सा. 289 मान्योयं धर्मसेतुंनृपाणां काले काले पालनोयो भवद्भिश्मा 290 नेतान् भाविनः पार्थिवेट्रान् भूयो भूयो याचते राम 291 चंद्रः [१८४*] श्री ॥ ॥ 292 श्रीविरूपाक्ष

ABRIDGED TRANSLATION, Line 1. Prostration to the blessed Ganādhipati (ie. Gaña prti). 
Verses 1-3. Invocations to Sambha (ie. Siya), Varaha (the Boar incarnatiou of Vishna) and Ganapati. 
V9.4.6 2 The ancestors of the family, viz. the Moon ; his son, Budha ; his son, Pará ravas ; his son, Ayuh ; his son, Nahusha , his son, Yayāti ; his son, Pūra ; in bis family, Bhe 
atanı, fourth from him, Vijaya (i.e. Arjuna) ; bis son, Abhimanya; his son, Parikshit, eighth from him, Nandas ; pinth from him, Chalikka; seventh from him, Rājanarēndre; tenth from him, Bijjalandra ; third from him, Vira-Hammāli-Rāya, the lord of Māyāpuri. 
Vv. 7-21.4 Fourth from him (i.e. Vīra-Hemmāli-Raya) was Tāta-Pinnama; his son, Somi-dēva, who captured seven forts in a day ; his son, Rāghava-dēvarāt i.e. Rāghavendra ?); his son, Pianama, the lord of Āravidus ; his son, Bukka, who helped & putting his rale on a firm basis, and married Ballāmbikā or Ballamā; his son, Rāma-Raja (I), who captured the hill-fort of Āda vani from Sapāda after having driven away from it the chief Kasappudaya (Kasappa-Udaiyar) and took the fort of Kandanavõlu. His wife was Lakkımbikā, and their son was Srirangarāja (I), who married Tirumalāmbikā ; his three sons were Räma-Rája (II), Tirumala-Rāya (I) and Venkatādri. 
V 22. When the son of whose proud valour, that dispels the darkness, viz. (his) enemies, has risen, his white parasol looks like the full-blown lotas (growing) in the milk-ocean of his fame; the golden knob (kalasa) at its centre shines like the pericarp (of that lotus), and the pair of fly-whisks like a couple of swans in its vicinity. 
V, 23 Deserting the serpent-king for the reason that he moves with crookednega, though famed for being possessed of happiness or serpent's body), the tortoise (for the rea son) that he takes shelter in laziness (oh water), though brilliantly well-behaved (or perfectly round), the elephants of the quarters that they are dull (in walkivg), though they possess charity (or rut), and the mouutains (supporting the earth) that they are cruel (i e. hard), though they are high-minded (or lofty), the earth seeks earnestly with delight this (king), who is the sole repository of the collection of the good qualities of every one of them. 
V. 24 W bo, having completely weeded out the thorns (i.e. destroyed the enemies), having well ploughed and prepared the entire field, the earth (it improved, it by good deeds), having filled it with profuse waters of (1.e. poured during) his liberal gifts, and having raised thereon the collection of crops, (his) spotless fane, bears with splendour, on the field-watch scaffold (kāyamāna) of his shoulder, the lady, vie. the goddess of victory, to guard this (field of fame). 
V. 25. Who practically exhibits, on earth, the parts of the lords of the different quarters (of which he is made up) by possessing conquering capacity (the characteristic of Indra), purity (nature of fire), by adopting equal treatment of all people (the quality of Samavartin, i.e. 
1 These verses are the same as in the Hampi inscription of Krishna-Räga (Epigraphia Indica, Vol. I, pp. 881 ff ). 
* These verses are the same as in the Künigür plates of Venkata II (Epigraphia Indrca, Vol. III, p. 241). 
* The Telugu work Rāmarāzīyamu, which also supplies the ancestry of the kings of the Vijayanagara dynasty, gives interesting and sometimes historically important details concerning Nanda, Chalikya and othere. This mutates against the supposition that these were fanciful names, poetically introduced into the genealogy with the object of establishing connection with some of the ruling families of ancient India. 
4 Tiese verres are the same as in the Künigūr plates. Verses 11-21. occur also in the Mārēdapalle grant of Sriranga II (Epigraphia indica, Vol. XI, pp. 326 #.) 
$ This is popsibly identical with the village Äravēda in the Tädapatri tālakū of the Anantapur district.

the God of death?) and conduct pleasing to righteous people (like that of Nirriti pleasing to the punya-hanas, demons), reputed as a broad-minded one (or Prachētas, 6.8. Varuna), having acquired the art of making gifts (or 'of touching and wandering,' as the god of wind), being the lord of wealth (or Dhanapati, 1 e. Kubēra), and distinguished by the quality of the Omniscient (or Sarvajña, i.e Siva). 
V. 26 Who having sacrificed in the fire of (his) valour the fried grain (laja) of (His) enemies' reputation, in accordance with the incantations of counsel, married with pleasure the 
es the pleasure of the good (or is brilliant with her marriage wrist band), taking her through the seven steps (sapta-pada) of the seven worlds and helping her to ascend the stone of the Meru (mountain), and victoriously occupies the throne, receiving the blessings of holy Brahmans.3 
V, 27. Desiring to achieve equality with whose fame of (making) perpetual charities the celestial trees are performing penance on the bank of t] Ganges), having assumed the ochre robe (of their red) tendrils, and the plaited hair of their) hanging roots. 
V. 28 [This is the same as verse 24 in the Hampi inscription of Krishna-Raya, except that turguture and get of the latter are replaced in our inscription by the and @aztat] 
V. 29. This is the same as verse 34 of the Kūpiyūr plates of Venkata II and verse 35 of the Märēdapalle grant of Ranga II.5] 
V.30. (The) destroyer of (his) enemies, a (very) celestial tree to supplicants, the chastizer of chiefs who take new titles (hosa-birudara-ganda), the excellent cavalier of kings (rāya-yahutta-minda), happy in (his) honoured deeds (mahita-charita-dharya), whose wealth of titles consists of Manniyan-sömul, etc., and who has destroyed (his) enemies. 
V 31. The grandfather of the two (opposing) armies (ubhaya-dala-pitāmaha),& one that is (ever) ready in giving protection to surrendering enemies and whose glory is praised by all people, in the words: this is the crusher of the prestige of Avahalu-Rāya."? 
V. 32. Whose prosperity dances (in mirth), who, being the lord of title-bearing chiefs, possesses a powerful army and is surrounded by heroes expert in the conquest of the king of Utkala (i.e. Orissa), who is fierce in battle), who chastizes the boats of enemies with the strength of (his) arm, and who is possessed of lofty and respectable titles like gandara-güli and manya-puli,8 
2 Yama, ar the god of death, is known as Sama-vartin, 1 6. one who treats all beings alike. 
The idea seems to be based upon the saying : 
अध्याभिश्च सुरेन्द्राणां मानाभिनिर्मिती नृपः। * The reference is to a ceremony observed in Brabmanical marriages. In this the bride is led by the bride groom by the hand round the sacrificial fire, tieading seven steps, and finally her right big toe is placed by him upon * stone which is called Mēru. The pret here draws a comparison between the king's heroic career and glorious coronation on the one hand and the scene of a marriage performed according to Vedic rites, whers läja-homa, sapta. padi, etc, are important ceremonies 
4 The Ganges is called Tripatha-gå for the reason that she flows in the Heaven, on the earth, and in the nother regions. 
5 Epigraphra Indica, Vol. XI, p. 333. 
# The exact import of this title is not apparent. (Possibly it refers to the position of Vyāsa in relation to the Kauravas and Pandavas in the Mahābhārafa war.-F.W.T.] Elsewhere pitämaha occurs in the title 'Andhra Kavita-prtāmaha' (1.e. the Brahma or Creator of the Andhra poetry), borne by the great poet Allasāni Peddana of Krishna-dēra-Rāga's court. 
7 This expression must be taken to signify the lord of Ayahalu", Arabuļu-Räve is not known to be a proper aame Avahalu is perhaps the modern Anhole'. 
* These titles denote comparison with the proud breeding-bull (ü!) and the tiger (pult), as in classical Sanskrit poetry, which romperes heroes to the upishabha (ball) and the vyāghra (tiger).

V. 33. The charming lord of the town of Aravidu, shining with the goddess of heroism and assuming the position of the Boar in raising the earth of the feudatory chiefs (dharani varaha), and having shoulders as huge as the lord of serpente. 
V. 34. Vērgi-Tribhuvanimalla, & (very) Arjuna in the art of (fighting on) the battle. field, the Sultan (Suratrāna) of Urigola (2.e. Orugallu),3 who sees Har (in his) heart, the best 
Rāmabhadra (2.6. Räma) in the front of the battle, who possesses the title - the lord of the illustrious chiefs of several classes, 
V. 35. The foremost of those born in the Atrēga gotra, of great fame among kings and possessing a cavalry of horses bearing high titles (atz-brruda-turaga-dhatta), who is high-minded. and holds a position respected by the Aratta and the Magadha (kings), 
V. 36. Possessed of the righteous conduct of the Enemy of Salya (i.6. Yudhishthira), the lord of Kalyāņapura, an expert in (all) arts, the Châlikka (i.e. Chalukya) emperor, glorious in (his) lofty crown of gems, 
Vy. 37-40. Who possesses the glory (conveyed by) the epithet e-biruda-raya-rõhuta-vēsy= aika-bhujanga,'4 whose fame is rendered more magnificent by the proclamation of the title Oddiya rāya-isā patta, 5 xbo is a lord comparable to the moon, who has surpassed even Him of tha odd number of arrows6 (2.0. Manmatha, the God of Love) by his pleasing form, who is the chastizer of the kings that fail to keep their word (of allegiance), under whose protection the nine divisions of the earth feel happy, who is the glorious suzerain of kings (rijādhiraja), the illustrious Paramēśvara among kings (raja-paramēsvara), is entitled the 'lord of the three kings (miru-rāyara-ganda),'7 one whose great fame strides across (even) thé Mēru (mountain), who turns away his face from the wives of others, who is a terror to hostile kings, one given to supporting the good, the destroyer of the tigers, viz. the wicked (men), (the monster-bırd) ganda-blērunda to the elephants, viz. (his) enemies, and the repository of the nectar of devotion to Hari, 
Vp. 41-42. Who is constantly praised with titles such as these by crowds of bards (vandi) that proclaim with clasped hands * Be victorious,' 'Live (long),' and whnse praisa is loudly sung by the kings of Kāṁb(h)oja, Bhoja, Kālinga, Karabāta, etc., who have assumed the position of door-keepers to him, 
V. 43. The thus excellent and glorious Tiramala-Mahārāja (I), of good qualities, praised by the Brāhmaņas, being seated on (his) throne, rules the kingdom extending from the Sētu (1.8. Râmēsyaram) to the Sumēru, and from the hill of sunrise in the east to the other) end of the western mountain (in the west), eclipsing in fame and righteousness even (kings like) Nriga, Nala, Nabusha and sach others on earth, and drawing (anto himself) the minds of all (nis subjects). 
Vy 44-62. In the sake year, counted by Rāmas (3), planets (9), oceans (4) and moon (1)-(i.e. 1403)-in the (cyclıc) year called Prejāpati, in the month known as Māgha, in the bright fortnight, on the great and auspicious tithi of Dvadasi, in the presence of the glorious god Ramachandra, the treasure-house of all prosperity, complying with the request of the illustrious Tirumala-Rāja, of matchless beanty and of reputed prowess, the grandson of 
1 The word nayaka also means the chief pendant of a necklace. 
* This title appears elsewhere in earlier times. See Noa. 254 and 507 of the Madras Ejigrapicol Collection for 1906. 
This is now called Warangal. The sole paramour of the prostitutes of kings, the caraliers of any (sort of) title. 
* Canning (his enemy) the Oddiya (i.e. Odhra) king to fly in all directions. In the next attribula (ganda may also mean the cheel's H. K. S.] 
. Kānda in the sense of an arrow' is found in the Nänärtha-ratnamälä; see Kittel's Ka mada-Englis Dictionary. 
The three kings, so far as the South is concerned, are gonerally supposed to be the Chört, Chole and Pándy be The Asya-pati, Nara-pati and the Gaja-pati kings may also be meant.

earth) with the camphor, ulz, volumes of (bis) pure fame, tbe foren.ost of the Chola fernily and the prosperous abode of unrestrained charities--the great (king) Tirumala Maharana of powerful arm, (highly) esteemed of wise kings, being surrounded by pious and loving puests (purohwa) and attendants and by various wise men who follow the ways laid down in the Vedas (Śruta) and are highly educated, gave, with pleasure, with libations of gold and water as a saiva-manya to Brahmanas of soveral sākhās, names, võtias andi sūras, the rich yıllage named Penuguluru with the two (villages called) Yalammapadu-Chenpapalli and Kondūru-Chennapalli, beautiful with gardens, bearing the happy second nano of the prosperous Ellama-rājēndra-samudra, supplemented by tbe khanda-kshetra obtained from the village of Kottari, and sitnati d in Pottapi-nādu, (a sub-division) of the prosperous Siddha vara-simā, lying on the eastern side of the great Bābu river, to the south-east of Pottapi, the ornament of villages, to the south of this (ie the neighbouring) Riri-sarörata (tank), to the south-west of the great village Srivara, to the west of the village wamed Kondūru, to the north-west of the village Indalü, to the north of the village called Sinkamāla, and to the north-east of the village Tirumalarāja-pēta, with its boundaries on all the four sides (marked out), with its resources (rudhr), hidden treasures (mikslēpu), stone, realised (suha) and real isable (sādhya) (income), water, together with ahshını, ägāme, and trees, to be enjoyed in con munity (by all the donee Brahmans), with its) desccnt-wells, draw-wclls, tanks, marshes and gardens, enjoyable successively by sons, grandsong and so on, as long as the moon and the stars remain, (and) (if necessary) to be disposed of in charity, mortgage (adhamana), sale, or transfer (crnimaya) 
Vv. 63 & 64 The (names of the Brabmans of the several sākhās, names, gotras and $utras, who are wcll-versed in (all) the sciences (sāstras) and have mastered the Vedanta, that owa sbares (Urıttıs) in the excellent village of Penalöru (ie Penugulāru), which consists of one hundred and twenty-eight shares (urittis) and is otherwise called the piosperous Ellama-rājēn dra-samudra, are tbus enumerated in the order (in which they were given by Timma-Rāja :

Vy. 177-178. This 18 the edict of the great and illustrious Tirumala-Raya, distin guished for (his) pradence, the gifts from whose hands excelled (even thosc) of the tree of Indra (26 the celestial tree), and who was a very) fountain of (good) qualities Under the orders of king Tirumala-Rāya, Kavi-süsana Svayambhū, the son of Sabhậpati, composed beb utifully the verses of (this) copper (-plate) edict 
V. 379 By the order of the glorious Tirumala-Mahārāya the illustrious Ganapaya noharya, the sou of Virana, engraved (this) copper (-plate) edict

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL. XVI. 
No 19.-TWO KADAMBA GRANTS FROM SIRSI. 
BY V. S SUKTHANKAR, PA.D., Poona. The copper-plates bearing the subjoined inscriptions, which are now edited for the first time, belong to Mr Subbaya Nagappa Hegde of Ajjibal in the Sirsi Talaka of the North Kanara District. They have been in the possession of Mr. Hegde's family for a very long time; so long, in fact, that nothing is now known as to when and under what circumstances the plates came into the possession of the family. I obtained them on loan through the good offices of Mr Shankarrao Karnad, Higa Court Pleader, Bombay, who, at my request, kindly induced his colleague Mr. V. G. Hegde, BA, LLB., Sirsi (a son-in law of the owner), to send the plates to me for inspection and to allow me to take impressions from them. I am thus editing the grants froin the original plates, which were on loan wit] six months doring 1918, and from a set of inked impressions prepared from them in the office of the Superintendent, Archeological Survey, Western Circle. The annexed facsimiles were subsequently prepared under the supervision of the Government Epigraphist from the inpres sions supplied by me. The transcript given below has been carefully compared (in manuscript) 
re the latter were returned to the owner. My sincere thanks are due to Messrs. Karnad and Hegde for this opportunity of offering here a description of these interesting records of the reigns of the Kadamba kings Ravivarman and Kșishnavarman of Vaijayapti (Bana väsī). Their chlef claim to our attention lies in the regnal years in which they are dated. The grant of Ravivarman was made (if my reading of the date is correct) in the thirty-fifth year of his reign, and that of Krishnavarman in the nineteenth year. 
APLATES OF RAVIVARMAN: THE [3]5TH YEAR. These are three copper-plates, the first and last of which are inscribed on one side only, and each of which measures roughly 5%" long by 3" broad. They are quite smooth, their edges being neither fashioned thicker nor raised as rims. Although the plates are fairly thin, the engraving, not being very deep, does not show through on the reverse sides. show evident traces of the working of the engraver's tool. The entire inscribed surface of the first plate is more or less corroded, but only at a few places has the engraving thereby been so far affected as to have become quito illegible. The second plate is, 10 & sense, in a worse con dition, as three of its edges are eaton away; and with them the greater part of 1. 6, abort am third of 1 17, and sonne syllables in 11 11 and 16 are completely lost. The third plate is fortunately quite uutouched, and the engraving on it is in an almost perfect state of preserta tion. The most deplorable part of the havoc wrought on these plates by the destructive agency is that in line 11 some of the letters comprising the words expressing the date are damaged in such a manner that the reading of the date (which is by far the most important element of the record) has to be based on a conjectural restoration from which the element of uncertainty capaot entirely be eliminated. Of no great consequence is, on the other hand, the damage to line 6; for from the preserved fragments of letters we may, I think, safely conclude that the line contained nothing more than a eulogistic phrase or two, which, even if restored, would lave added nothing of importance to our stock of knowledge concerning the history of the Kadambas. The plates are pierced by a circular hole so as to receive the ring and seal which are attached. The weight, including the ring and seal, is 381 tolas The ends of the ring are securely soldered on to the back of the senl. About an eighth of an inch of the edge of the latter is raised so as to form a rim; the recessed space, which is oblong in shape, is devoid of legend or emblematic design. 
The characters, which show great uniformity throughout, belong to the southern variety, and have close affinities with those of other grants of tho Kadamba kings, especially with the 
No. 19] 
TWO KADAMBA GRANTS FROM SIRSI, 
200 
sa pe nane. 
Halail plates of the Kadamba Ravivarman, published by the late Dr. Fleet The letters and 1, alike whether used singly or in conjunction with other cousouauts, are devoid of loops never theless they are olearly distinguishable from each other. For iu n the right limb of the letter is regularly drawn in continuation of the slaoting (or vortigal) stroke; whereas in t the upright stroke is much shorter and distinct from the lower part of the letter, which forms a horse-shoo (sometimes wit'ı unequal arms), and to which the short vertical stroke is attached at the top. It may be added that owing to this characteristic even the upper half of the letter & is sbirply distinguished from the corresponding portion of v, in which the vertical stroke is regularly drawn iu continuation of the right limb (as in n), a fact whore importance will be apparent when we shall turn our attention to the subject of the reading of the date of the record. The difterence between the forms of t and v may be studied in the following examples. Häritz and pratikritzo in line 3, patt-pratimah 1 7, tithaz 1 12, "rakshatr 1. 19, bhavati 1. 20; and vijayao 1. 1, "vipulao 1 8, and ournayao and visar ada 1. 9. Iu Il. 7 and 10 occurs an initiala; in ll 10, 12 a; in l. 20 W; in 1, 19 final k; 10 1 14 fiualt, and in 1l 17, 21 final m. For final consonants, as is usual in these records, the full forms are used in reduced size, witten on & sliglitly lower 
tters of the line The medial vowel in LT 18 Witti n. by bending back tho last downward stroke in an upward direction, e.g. in lines 2, 3, etc -The language of the inscription is Sanskrit, and, with the exception of the imprecators and admoutory verses at the end (11. 20-23), the text 18 in prose. The document, it may be added, begins and ends somewhat abruptly. The grant proper is couched in very terse language The preamble does not mention any of Ravivarman's ancestors, and the epithets coupled with the name of Raviyarman himself, which are of the stereotyped form, are, relatively speaking, few in number, They contain no new historical information regarding the royal donor In its brevity the record resembles closely the Nilambur plates of the Kadamba king of the same name. The orthography does not call for any particular remarks, 
The inscription is one of the Dharma-Mahārāja Ravivarman of the Kadamba family. We have already the Halsi and Nilambur plates of a Kadamba Ravivarman. The bighest regnal year recorded in these grants is the eleventh. The present grant records (II. 10-19) that ou the filfth tithi of the bright half of the month of Kārttika in a specified regnal year (the reading of which is uncertain and will be discussed later on) Ravivarman granted to the Ilahādēva temple of his beloved physician, the dës-ümātya Nilkantha,four nivar tanas of land in the village of Särz (or Sāra), of which further specifications will be found in the appended transla tion. In this portion of the record (11. 16, 17) there is a lacunn, in which some further details of the donation are lost. 
The genealogy of Ravivarman is not given Bat, as the writing of the present record dors not differ in aay essential points from that of the Halsi and Nilambur grants of tlie Kidan bu hing of the same name, we may on palæographic grounds tentatively identify hin with Raviyarman, the son of Mrigośavarman and grandson of Santıyarman. 
The reading of the regnal year is, as stated above, uncertaia. The year is expressed in 
of this dynasty that have come under my notice), which I read as pañcha-strim]śatstamēl 'in the thirty-fifth. The compound indubitably contains the ele ment pañcha-, which is clear, and another word, expressing a multiple of ten, which is obliterated. The second syllable of this partly defaced word ooutarus again unquestiouably a $. The chuice, therefore, lies between -vinse and -uensatitirmp, T - trumnýē and -trimsattama ås, moreover, the sign of a does not appear to have been added to the intended akshard must be taken to be on. This circumstance further reduces the possible alternatives at our disposal to -vinka titain 
1 Ind. Ant., Vol. VI, PP 25 ff. 
2 Abore, Vol. VIII, p. 147, and Plate, See below, p. 268, foot-note 10, 
266 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
SV 
L 
um 
_ 
L 
. 
N 
and triñsattam. Further, the remnant of the akshara after śa appears most to resemble a deformed t, very falat, indeed, but still distinguishable on the plate, a conclusion which is in bar.niony with the above supposition that the longer form of the ordinal (vinsatitamo or trim sattana) has been used here, and pot the shorter (nrisa, trimsa). Let us now turn our atten tion to the syllable preceding su. The preserved portion appears to consist of the medial i and a short vertical stroke added at the top of a mutilated horse-shoe. Therefore, from what I have said above regarding the shapes of v and f, at follows that this defaced alshara can only repre sente uŹ and not ti. This result also hity in with our former observation that the third missing syllable is a deformed ta (and not tı), for an initial requires the restoration -trinsattame (containing to in the third syllable), while an initial v would necessitate the reconstruction, -Plisatitamê (with th in the third syllable). I have, thereford, for my part, no hesitation in reading the preserved portion of the first damaged akshara as the and supplementing the lost Bobscript under it. The second syllable 15, as already remarkeci, sa beyond doubt. Then I read t[t]a, after which there is just sufficient space for the inclasion of mē, which syllable, however, is compl-tely obliterated. The complete restored regnal year would, therefore, be pancha-trisattame, in the thirty-fifth year. It may be added that, if the reading proposed by me is not accepted, the only possible alternative is puñcha-vimsatitanē, which in my opinion is extremely doubtful. 
The village Sārē (or Sāra), »hich is the object of the grant and which is mentioned without any specification of its whereabouts, l'emains unidentified.

B.-PLATES OF KRISHNAVARMAN II: THE 19TH YEAR. 
These plates, which are in a moch better state of preservation than the foregoing, are also three in number. They measure roughly 6" long by 23" broad They are quite smooth, their edges being neither fashioned thicker nor raised into rims. The plates are thin ; but the engraving being shallow, though otherwise quite good, the letters do not sbow tbrough on the reverse sides at all. The letters show the characteristic marks of the working

* The rest of the sentence is lost 
* Coinpare the epithet Kadamba-sênäni-brihod-envaya-vyloma-chandramah (the full moon in the firmament of the great lineage of the Kadamba leader of armies '), applied to Käkusthavarman in the Talagunda pillar inscription of Kākusthavarman, ed. Kielhorn, Ep Ind, Vol VIII, P 31. 
$ I suppose we have to supplement here some such words as these. * See above, p. 267, note 3.

TWO KADAMBA GRANTS FROM SIRSI

he 
navor's tool. The grant is engraved on the inner sides of tbe first ani last pates and on both sides of the middle one The plates are pierced by a Cicilar nole in order to receive the ring and seal, which are attached The ends of the ring are, as in the case if the 
rivarman, soldered on to the back of a seal, which, in this instance, s cval in s bapt auch T orsdavice The seal has a raised rim, and inside this there is shown in low relief the ögure of a quadruped perhaps a borse) facing left The weight of the platea noudate the ye and seal, is 52 tolas. Each engraved side contains four lines of writing, there are thus uuteen lines in all. Excepting isolated letters which are worn away and now become partly 1.leg.ble, the record is in a perfect state of preservation, and can be deciphered without any uncertliuty. 
The characters belong to the southern variety, and have close affinities with those cf other Grants of the Kadamba kings They differ palpably from the characters of the grant of Ravi varman described above and appear to belong to a later palæographic epocb The Towel a iu nã is written by bending back the last dowoward stroke in an apward direction; eg in 11 
3. etc. One notices the tendency of the vertical lines to slope, a feature which later develups into the spiral formation of Hala-Kannada letters Noteworthy is also the doubling of the left limb of g (11. 1, 2, 6, 8, etc.) and § (11. 4, 7, etc.). This record contains the earliest specimen hitherto known, in a southern alphabet, of the voitial rt (1 8) Initial a occars in 1.5 ; initial & in 11. 4, 6, initial u in 11 11, 13; initial é ml 7; the sign of final t in 1 7, and final 3 in 1 11. One ligature, with the word containing it, has remained uodeciphered in l. 10; I have never come across the sign anywhere before and can suggest no reading for it -The language of the insciiption is Sanskrit, and, with the exception of the imprecatory and admonitory stanzas at the end, the text is in prose. The main part of the text (11. 1-11) formos a single sentence and states, like the foregoing grant of Ravivarman, without much circumlocution the object of the record The attributes qualifying the donor are of the stereotyped form In its brevity this record resembles the grant of Ravivarnan described above. 
The inscription is one of the Dharma-A[aharaja Krishnavarman of the Kadamba fam ls. The hitherto known records of the Kadamba dynasty have rerealed the existence of two Krishna varmans in the family. And, as the present record neither gives the genealogy of this king nor mentions any circumstance which would help to establisb his identity, it is difficult tu affirm with certainty whether he is to be identified with either the one or the other Krishna vorman already known, or whether he is a new king altogether, but on palæographic consulera tions this king may tentatively be identified with the second Kadamba king of that name. Whose Bannahalli (now Halēbid) grant, dated in the seventh yeur of his reign, bas alıeady been publisbed. The grant proper records (11 6-11) that on the full moon day in the month of Kārttika, in the nineteenth year of his reign, Krishnavarman granted Kamakapalli in the Girigada village (grāma) of the Karvannāda dı-triot (vishaya) to a Brāhmaną of the Vārānı götra, named Sõma-svāmin, who was a student of the Rig-vēda, and a performer of the Sona sacrifice, making the village free from all taxes and dues. 
To the proposed identification of the Krishnavarman of our record with the Krishnararnan oť tbe Bannahalli grant it may be objected that the title Dharna-Vahirīja, which is here use: along with the name of the donor, is not found coupled with the name of Krishnararman II in any other record ; thus, for instance, in the Bannahallı grant itself, which is dated in the seventh year of the reign, only the shorter title Dahārāja is prefised to Krishtayai nia's Dame On the other land, the earlier Krishnavarman is invariably styled Dlack n I. Mahārāja in the preambles of the later Kadambd grants. The objection is put Tilid, for 10 bhould be noted that Krishnayarman I was, according to 211 ac 
Krishnayarman I was, according to all accounts, performer of a 
Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p 18 and plate 
270 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL XVI. 
AL 
L 
AH 
AMMAL 
horse-sacrifice. If our Krishnavarman is to be identified with this king, how are we to erplun the silence of the record regarding the sacrifice said to have been performed by him, On the other hand the expression aśva-nıēdh-abhishekta, herein applied to the Kadambas as a class, shows that in the time of our Krishnavarman the epithet asza-mēdha-yanin had become a hereditary title of the Kadanıba family, a fact which can be explained only on the assump tion that some prolonged interval of time separates the actual performer of the sacrifice from our Krishnavarman. Moreover, there is at least one other instance of the indiscriminate use of the titles Mahārija and Dharma-Mahārā), namely, in the case of Mrigēśavarman. Both titles are found used in connection with this king in his epigraphic records. 
A word may be added regarding the localities mentioned in the record. The object of the grant is stated to be Kamakapalli, situated in the Girigada village (grãma) of the Karvan nādga district (vishaya). None of these places can be identified with certainty. Mr Hegde, owing to whose good offices the plates were made available for publication, 18 a resident of Sirsi and has favoured me with the following topographical details, which throw some light on the question He mites - Sirsi tālula (which used to be called Sundă taluka) was formerly divided into a number of mayane, each of which consisted of a number of villages. One of such māyane went by the name of Karür mägane, deriving its name from Karür, a village included in the magang Anuther such village was called Girigadde Both these villages still bear the same names" The proximity of Guigadde to Sirsi favours the identification of the former with the Guigada of the plates, whicli, as stated above, come from Sirsi itself Also, in regard to the great and often inexplicable changes whicb many place-names have undergone, the ident fication of Karvaunūdga with Karûr is not an ima possible proposition.

No 20 --GARRA PLATES OF THE CHANDELLA TRAILOKYAVARMAN 
[VIKRAMA)-SAMVAT 1261. 
BY K 
N. DIKSHIT, M.A, CALCUTTA. 
These plates Fere found in a tank near the village of Garra, to the south-east of Chhatar pur, capital of the Indian state of the same name in Bundelkhand, and were subsequently sent to me for decipherment and publication thiough the kindness of Pandit Shukdeo Bihari Misra, BA, Dewan, Chhatarpur State Being considerably corroded when first received by me, the plates were thoroughly cleaned, and impressions were taken from them, which are published in the accompanying plate They are now exhibited on loan in the Provincial Museum, Lucknow. 
The plates are two in number. Each is a complete record by itself, engraved on only one side They measure 131" by 81" and 12" by 7" respectively A small hole (dia ") at the top shows that at one time a mng must have been attached to the plates Below the ring-hole, and dividing the first four lines of the inscription just in the centre of each plate, is engraved a sealed figure of the goddess Lakshmi, with four arms, the upper two holding lotuses. On hoth the copper-plates the writing has beeu protected by means of copper bands," in breadth and from " to " in thickness. rivetted along the edges. The letters are generally well pre 
ed, but here and there a few lettere are concealed by the protecting band, and at the bottom of plate II a portion has been damaged and lost, though the lacunæ can be easily supplied. The plates weigh 124 and 122 tolas respectively. 
The alphabet is Nāgarī, iegular for the period and locality to which the record belongs. The sharp angular forms of letters found in many inscriptions of the twelfth century, give place bere to more rounded ones The identity of the signs for ia and ba, the similarity of the forms of 20, cha, ala and ra and similar palæographical peculiarities have been noticed before in documents of this period (cf Semid plates of Paramardi-deva, Ep. Ind , IV, 153 ff ).? 
The language is Sanskrit Both the inscriptions are in prose throughout, excepting a rerse each at the legioning and the end Regarding orthography there is little to note. The influence of the vulgar pronunciation is reflected in the promiscuous use of sa and sa, ia and la Most of the consonants following , are donbled. Rules of Samalir are often yolated, and a final consonant is not inarked with the iriama, as † in sa izzat (I 9 f.). 
1 Tha full-moon day of Kirttika, ay a day on which donations were made by the Kadamba kugs, is men. tioned also in the Nilambur plates of Raziyarmin (Ep. Ind, Vol VIII, P 146) and the Halsī plates of Mrigöśavarman (Ind Ant, Yol VI, p. 21) 
2 [The form of 2 deserves notice as pointed out by Mr. Y. R Gupte It differs from that of the era plateu, line 1, 4ud is more progressive, pzvirg us thua the earliest form of the moderu Dëvenīguit Ed) 
No 20.1 
GARRA PLATES OF THE CHANDELLA TRAILOKYAVARMAN. 
273 
The records belong to the well-known Chandella dynasty of Bundelkhand, called Chandra trêya in the inscriptions Opening with a panegyric of the family, they next refer to Jayasakti and Vijayasaktı, two early heroes of the family, and proceed to describe the grant of two villages by the Parama-bhattāraka Mahārāj-adhiraja Paramëśvara, the glorious Trailõkye varma-dēva, who meditated on the feet of the P. M P Paramardi-dēva, who meditated on the feet of the P. M P Madanavarma-dēva. Encamped at a place called Vadayāda, the king Trailokyayarma-dēva granted the village of Kādõhã in the Pāniulı territory (vishaya) on Friday the second tithi) of the bright fortnight of Vaisakha in Samvat 1261 by the first copper-plate and the village of Lõhasıhāṇi in the Vikraunil territory (vishaya) on Friday the second (tithi) of the dark fortnight of Vaišākha in Samvat 1281 by the second copper-plate. In both grants the donee was the Rauta Samanta or Sãvanta of the Bhāradvāja gotra, son of Raita Pāpē, who was killed at Kakadādaha in a battle with the Turushka (Turks), grandson of Rauta Sahana pala and great-grandson of Räuta Ranapāla. The object of the grants is unusually interesting, being the bestowal of villages by way of maintenance for death, unquestionably that of the father of the donee, on the field of battle. 
As regards the equivalents of the dates given in the records, we find 
(1) Samvat 1261, Vaisakha Sudı 2, Sukra 
Northern Vikrama current. Tuesday, 15th April, 1203 Northern Vikrama expired Saturday, 3rd April, 1204. 
Southern Vikrama expired. Friday, 22nd April, 1205. (2) Samvat 1261, Vaisakha Vadı 2, Sukra 
Northern Vikrama current 
Paurnimânta : Monday, 31st March, 1203 
Amănta. Tuesday, 29th April, 1203. Northern Vikrama expired: 
Panrnimānta Friday, 19th March, 1204, 
Amanta Sunday, 18th April, 1204. Southern Vikrama expired. 
Paurnimânta : Tuesday, 7th April, 1205. 
Amânta : Friday, 8th May, 1205, The first date is thus Friday, 22nd April, 1205 A.D.; the second may be either Friday, 19th March 1204, or Friday, 6th May, 1205. But, as all our evidence points to the fact that the two grants must have been recorded almost aimaltaneously, we are justified in believing that the former solution must be rejected and Friday, 6th May, 1205 A.D., must be the true equivalent of the second date We thus have here instances (which are comparatively rare) of North Indian epigraphical dates calculated as southern expired Vikrama years, with amanta months (vide Ind Ant, Vol XIX, pp 181-2). 
The present records give us the earliest known dates for Trailokyavarman, the only certain inscription of his so far known being dated eight or nine years later. On the other land, our dates bring us within two years of the date of the death of Paramardı, Trailokyavarman's pre decessor, and the fall of Kälanjar and Mahoba (Apnl 1203 AD.). Let us see whether the present records throw any light on the fortunes of the Chandellas after the disaster which overtook them in 1203 
Mr. Vincent Smith observes in his paper on the History and Coinage of the Chandel Dynasty (Ind Ant, 1908, p 146) that the history of the Chandel dynasty, as one of the powers of 
1 [The reading does not seem quite clear. should it be Viāunr ---F. W. T.] 2 Canningham, ds. Reports, Yol XXI, p 50. 
NA 
274 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA 
[VOL. XVI. 
Northern India, ends in 1203 A.D., and that Trailokyavarman succeeded his father as a mere local chieftain, holding the eastern part of the ancestral kingdom of Jejaka-bhakti. As we gather from the present inscription, however, Trailokyavarman must shortly after the catastrophe at Kalanjar have mustered his forces, followed the Muhammadans into the western part of Bundelkhand, fought with and possibly defeated them there, l'e-established his power in at least the western and central parts of his dominions, and probably recovered his ancestral strong hold of Kälanjara (as appears from his assumption of the epithet Kalajar-dhipati, 1 5). It is possible that the latter epithet is merely an empty claim to the lost fortress, similar in nature to the same title as held by Vijjala, Kalachurı king of Kalyānī, or to the utle Diarāzati-pwa-zar adhtsvura, as assumed by the Yadavas of Dāvagul. But in the present case it is rather signi ficant that a claim should be asserted over the place within two years of its loss. Besides, as General Cunningham remarks, we know for certain that Trailökyavarman recovered Kälanjara some time before 1233 AD Nothing prevents us, therefore, from assuming that he did so just at the outset of his career. Other inscriptions tell us that he was in possession of Ajaygarh Fort in 1212 A.D, that he was the paramount ruler in Băghelkhand in 1240-41 A D.. and that he was eulogized in his successor's timea as a very creator in providing strong places' and as 'a veritable Vishnu in lifting up the earth, immersed in the ocean formed by the stream of Turushkas' All this evidence warrants us in assuming that Trailokyavarman was not a dere local chief, that he retrieved the waning fortunes of his dynasty to a considerable extent by stemming the tide of the Moslemn invasion, and that during his pretty lon; reign vi lexoss foly forty years he succeeded in establishing his sovereignty over inost-If not all-uf his patternal domain. 
Of the localities mentioned in the records the following can be identified Vadavāda, the place of encampment, is most probably the saine as Yadavārı of another Chandella inscription, to be identified with Bedwāda in the Lalitpur subdivision of the Jhansı district, the 'Berwara," of the maps in N L 24° 30' and E. L 78° 41' Kakadādaha, the scene of the battle with the Turk, must in all probability be the Kakaradaha mentioned elsewlieres as situated in the Vadavāri region, and as such I propose to identify it with Kakaduā, a little to the south-east of Bedvādā, the 'Kukurooa' of the maps in N L. 24° 28' and E L. 780 42 The Vikrauni territory of these plates is probably the same as the Vikaura territory of the Semra platest which was identified by Dr Cartellieri with Bikaur in Saugor district, the Beekore of our maps, 10 N. L 24° 13' and E L. 78° 41' Lõhasihāni in the Vikraunı territory nar be the same as Lohāni in the Bijām ar State, situated in N. L 23° 23'5 and E L 790 12 Kādõhã. one of the villages granted, must be identical with Kādoa n the Chhatarpur State, situated in N. L. 24° 48' and E L. 79° 52', just south of Gaira, the place where the plates were discovered Pānuli might possibly be identified with Panna, capital of the Indian state of the sanie name, in N. L. 24° 43' and E. L. 80° 16'

Trailokyavarmma-dēvasya [ma]tam mama | chha | chba | 
TRANSLATION. 
Ll. 1-2. Om. Hail! Victorious is the linestge of the Chandrätrēja sovereigas, refulgent 28 the moon, by reason of its gladdening the universe, and its being held on the head (i.e. respected) by the rulers of the world (just as the moon is held on the head by the Lord of the Universe, i.e the god siva). 
Li. 2-5. In that (family), resplendent with the birth of heroes like Jayasakti, Vijayasakti and others, shining with ever-increasing victory over (their) foes, (was born) the illustrious king Trailõkyavarmman, Victorious, overlord of Kalenjara, great devotee of the supreme god (Sıva), Supreme Lord, great king of kings, meditating on the feet of the illustrons Para marddi-dēva, Supreme Lord, etc., who meditated on the feet of the illustrious Madanavarmma dēva, Supreme Lord, etc. 
LI. 5-7. He, here, having overcome all hostile families by his unbearable Talour, protecting the earth without any disturbance, as if it were the) young bride of a (noble) family, with his intellect purified owing to his unobstructed discrimination, informs and instructs the headmen aud so forth of the village of Kādāhā, situated in the territory (vishaya) of Paņiúli:

$ son $a-sarrrän see note 5, p. 275, above.-F. W, T.] * Read bhadr-asanan. 5 Rend ohhattrack na rafvā. "[The letter za is not visible on the plate. Perhaps yñan as in Plate I has to be read after ra. H. K, S.]

LI. 7-11. Let it be known to you that this above-mentioned village with (its) land and water, moyable and immovable (objects), overhead and underground, circumscnbed within its bound aries, with its whole producem-past, present and future, with access to it prohibited for 177718 and others, --- has been graciously granted by us together with a charter (for the same) by way of maintenance for the heirs of one who suffered) death (on the battlefield), issued fron (4221) camp at the village of Vadavāda, on Friday, the second (day) of the bright half of Vaigākbe in the year 1261 to Rauta Samanta of the Bharadrája götra, son of Räut& Papē, lo was killed at Kakaðādaha in a fight with the Turushkas, grandson of Bžuta Sabana pāla, and great-grandson of Rāuta Raņapāla. 
Ll. 12-14 Knowing this, you should be intent on obeying (these) instructions, and piya. + him all his dues, such as the claim to a portion (of the agricultural produce), etc So, alse, one should obstruct him in the enjoyment of this village, with its houses and surround , walls, with its ingress and egress, with its trees (and plants), such as sugarcade, cotton, 1987, hemp, mango, nuadhūha, etc, with its forests, quarties and hidden treasures and mines ci uir, 
etc., and other sources of wealth within and without its boundanes. 
Ll. 15-16. Here also, the kings and officers of the kings should forego all their respect.Te rights. Future monarchs should likewise protect this grant of ours, considering that it cagl. not to be wrested or seized. “The conch, the throne, the umbrel stately elephants (in fact, all the insignia of royalty) are (but) the blossoms of (the nert accruing from) the grant of land; its fruit is the attainment of heaven, O Purandara" is the handwriting of the king. 
II. 
Almost identical with the above, except that the persons who are called upon to obey the instructions in lines 7-8 are · Brahmans and other respectable dignitaries and householders, as köyast7ras, dutas carriers of messages), physicians, aud mahattaras (headmen), eren durato mē das (a low-caste people of Bundelkhand) and chandalas. The last line (17) contains : signature of king Trailokyavarmma-döya in his own handwriting. 
No. 21.--SOME MINOR RASHTRAKUTA INSCRIPTIONS. 
BY LIONEL D. BARNETT. 
The inscriptions contained in this series have been edited from ink-impressions Orgir: "T prepared for the late Dr. Fleet, and now preserved in the Department of Onenral Printed B and Manuscripts in the British Museum. 
1. KUNIMELLIAALLI INSCRIPTION OF SAKA 818. 
The village of Kunimellihalli lies in lat. 14° 52' and long 75° 22', about 11 miles S E. fium Shiggaon, in the Bankápar täluka of Dhärfär District, and is marked on the Bombay Sarie: sheet 309 as “Kuni Milihali” and on the Indian Atlas sheet 42 as “Koonee vehicehu. The word Kuni distinguishes it from a neighbouring “Milhalı” or “ Jebleehuller Whether it is identical with the village of Dautavũr or Dauta fura mentioned in the printit record is a matter for conjecture The inscription was found on a stone in front of the wall temple of Hanuman, in Survey No. 41. The inscribed area is about 1 ft. 10% in Wind 2 ft. 4 in. high. The character is fair Kanarese of the period, with letters varying in te sit from in. to 1 in., rather inclined to be upright and rounded, and generally some that are not 
278 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA, 
(VOL. XVI. 
. 
.. 
www... 
w 
ww 
.mm 
in strle. The i (in idans, 1. 16) is of the old style, two curves with two dots beneath, as desembed by Dr Fleet above, Vol XI, p. 7. The and > are written in both the earlier and the later manner. The X is of the old knife-shaped type, but somewhat broad. The i, b, and y approach the later types; the b has a large rounded top. In nal of Anniyana (l. 12) there is a somewhat unusual variety of 1). The 1 sometimes has the archaic inward curl, and 
sometimes appears to be without it, in the later fashion. The ñ occurs in pañcha (1. 5) and panñclia (1 18).-The language is Old Kanarese prose, but not of the most archaic type. The word bidisidon (1 15) is worth noting, cf. above, Vol. XI, p. 6, 1. 17. 
The record opens by giving its date (11. 1-4), and then refers itself to the reign of the Mahäsämantadhipati Kannara-vallaha (II 4-6), who seems to be the Rāshtrakūta Krishna II Akālavarsha. The title Mahasamantadhipati however raises some difficulty, for already in the Batgere inscription of A.D. 888, eight years previous to our record (see above, Vol. XIII, p. 189), Kannara is given the full regal titles; and it would hence seem that, as he had for some years before his accession reigned as Yuva-rāja, or Heir Presumptive, jointly with his father, and had then borne the title of Mahasamantadhipatı, he was still locally described as such The alternative inference is that this Kannala-vallaha is an otherwise unknown viceroy of the same family, but the predicate" reigning over the earth * practically bars this possibility. 
The inscription then states that at this time the Bapavāsi Twelve-thousand was under the government of Lökade (II. 6-7). This Lokade is the same as Lokäditya, of the Chella kētana or Sellakētana family, on whom see Dr. Fleet's notes in Ind. ant., Vol. XXXII, pp. 221-26, and Dynast. Kanar. Distr., p. 411 and 2. 3. Next it mentions Òmkāra-Siva-bhatāra, of the temple of Dindēšvara, as administrator of Palabür, and, as it would seem, two or three persons as county-sheriffs of " Anniga's Hundred of Pānungal ” (ll. 7-12). This last-named district must be a part of the Pānungal (Hangal) Five-hundred, and it would be interesting to know who Anniga was from whom it took its name, possibly he is the Pallava or Nolamba-Pallava Åppiga of the records (above, Vol. IV, p. 289, V, p. 191, X, pp. 58, 63 n., Dynasta Kanar, Distr., p 4:20). Finally in II. 12-15 the inscription mentions two other local officials and & person who induced Omkära-Siva-bhatāra to grant remission to Dautavūr or Dauta vura. This seems to mean that the village was granted some liberty or immunity from payment of taxes to Palasůr; perhaps Palasûr was a church-property, administered together with some neighbouring villages for the benefit of a local Saiva temple, and by the present act Dautavär became released from this service. 
The date is specified in 11. 1-4 as Saka 818 current, the cyclic year Bänu (sic!); Jyaishtha šu. 13; the nakshatra Uttare. This is altogether irregular. Saka 818 curre corresponded to Rākshasa in all systems; and in that year the tithi mentioned was connected, according to the Surya-siddhānta, with Saturday, 10 May, A.D. 885, ending about 14 h. 4 m after mean sunrise (for Ujjain), and corresponding to the nakshatra Svāti (or Višākhă according to Garga on the Brāhma-siddhanta). What nakshatra Our “ (ttare" 18 obscure. Nor is the difficulty solved by assuming that Saka 818 expired way intended, for Mr. R. Sewell, who with his usual kindness has investigated the dates in this paper, bas pointed out to me that in accordance with the Sürya-siddhanta the date would be 
1 In this connectiou I may note that in the Adür inscription of Saka 826 expired (noe Dynast. Kanar. Distr., P.411, n 3) the X is written with a rounded body. 
2 In the Bagumră grant, a few days earlier, he is still called mahāsāmantadhipati. * See Dynast. Kanar. Distr, p 411. + [In Tamų the nakshatra Uttiram corresponds to the Sanskrit Uttara-Phalguni.-H, K, 8.] 
No. 21.) 
SODE MINOR RASHTRAKUTA INSCRIPTIONS.

HVALAULA 
Friday, 28 May, A..D 896, corresponding to the nakshatra Anuradha by all systems, while according to the Brāhma-siddhānta the nakshatra would be Svātı and according to the equal. space system and Garga it would be Chitra. If on the other hand we reject the Saka date as wrong and accept “ Bāpu," ie Bhānn, as being the same as Subhānu (as is sometimes the case in Northern Calendars), we must fix the year of our inscription as either 786 or 846 Saka ; but in neither case can we obtain a nakshatra with Uttara in its name, and hence this alternative may be discarded 
The only place-names mentioned are the Banavāsi Twelve-thousand (1. 7), Palasīr (1. 9), “Anniga's Hundred of Pānungal" (II. 11-12), and Dautavūr or Dauta vura (11. 14-15) Palasor is now Halsûr, in lat 14° 51' and long, 75° 21', nearly a mile S.IV. of Kunimellihallı Of " Anniga's Hundred of Pānzigal" I have already spoken. Dautavür is very possibly the ancient name of Kasımellihallı; if not, it must have been a village in the immediate Deighbourhood.

(Lines 15-18 a Kanarese prose formula of the usual type.) 
2 KYASANUR INSCRIPTIONS OF SAKA 888, eto. The village of Kyāaanūr (" Kyásnur" on the Bombay Survey sheet 310, “Kasnoor" on the Indian Atlas sheet 42) lies in the Hängal taluha of Dhārwār District, in 14° 39 lat and 75° 73 long Its ancient name, as is shown in the inscription C below, 1 6, was Kesalūr, hence is derived the modern name, by change of ē to yâ (a very common modification in vulgar Kanarese) and of 7 to n. The epigraphs here published were found in different parts of the village , but with the exception of A., which is known to have been found in a row of stones in a road to the north of it, their exact location is not on record, as far as I am aware An incorrect and imperfect transcript of A is given in the Elliot Collection, Vol. II, fol. 335a of the Royal Asiatic Society's copy. 
This epigraph is on a rectangular stone surmounted by sculptures which are described by Elliot's copyist as representing respectively the Sun, īśvara (Śiva), Halāyudha (82c!), and the Moon The inscribed area 18 about 1 ft. 101 in. high and 1 ft in broad.--The character is Kanarese, somewhat irregular and cramped in style, with letters varying in height from in to 1 in. The vowels $ and ğ are written in both the earlier and the later manner The band i are of the later types ; but the l is somewhat archaic, except in Edevolal, 1 6, and ägal, l. 13, where it is almost modern We find the guttural naaal in 11. 3, 7, 10, and the palatal nadal in 1. 4 (twice). The cursive m appears in the last syllable of Asgeravāramurn, 1 10, and Gamundi ganol, l. 12; and there is an interesting form of y, in two lobes, in -entaneya, 1 8, and Pora tayyan, 1 11 --The language is old Kanaress, with the exception of the formal Sanskrit verse at the end, as in the rest of this series, it belongs to the second period of the archaio dialect. We may note the form mattal for the commoner mattar (see above, Vol XIII, p. 168) and bidisz (see above, Vol. XI, p. 6, 1. 17). 
Thermoord opens by referring itself in 11. 1-3 to the reign of king Kannara (the Rashtra küta Krishna III Akalavarsha, on whom see Dyngst Kanar. Distr, pp 418 ff), and then states that while the Mahasamanta Kali-Vitta of the Chellakētana lineage was governing the Banavasi province (11 3-4) and Gāmundiga was serving as nil-gāmundu or shemff of the Edavolal nīdu, on a given date, the revenue of a field was transferred by Gåmundiga, at the request of Poravayya, to a special account for the upkeep of a local tank. The history of the Chellakëtana or Sellakātana famıly, of which Kal-Vuçta is the latest representative on record, has been examined in Ind Ant., Vol. XXXII, pp 221 ff , by Dr. Fleet, who has noticed this inscrption and the next on p. 226 We have found an earlier representative of the same family in the Kuņimellihalli inscription above 
The date of the donation is given in 11 7-10 as Saka 848 current, Visväva81, the bright fortnight, Thursday, the nakshatra Uttarăl; hot with peculiar negligence the draftsman or the

This fragment is contained on a stone of which the inscribed area 18 about 1 ft 10 in. high and 1 ft. 7 in. wideThe character is a fine upright Kanarese with letters varying in height from i in to 10 in., and with a tendency to make the / very large The vowels and f are usually written in the older fashion, but the later style is used in-l=e., 1 8, -7:00, 1 7, -V0-, 1. 8, and -do-, 1. 11 The palatal nasal occurs in pancha-, 14 Thel is rather archaic in type, but the j and b are of a rather later style, and the general character is that of the transitional period.--The language is old Kanarese The words nuligi (1 7) and mattal, for the commoner mattar (11. 10, 11: cf. above, A. text line 11 f), are of sonie lexical interest. 
The purport of the inscription, so far as it is preserved, is to record the grant of some land for the maintenance of a temple. It prefaces this by referring itself tu the reign of Kandara. Vallabha, i.e Kannara or Krishna III (ll. 1-3), while the Mahisamantövlhupati Sankaraganda was governing Banavāsi (11. 4-6) and Gāmundiga was countr-sheriff of Edevolal (11 6-9) 
The places mentioned are the Banavāsi nādu (16), the Edevoll Seventy (1 8). the Pulil-kere, a local tank (1. 9), and the Buda-kanda, some local field or the lıke (1 11).

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
(VOL. XVI. 
D. 
This record is on a stone with inscribed aroa 2 ft. 6 in. bigth and 1 ft. 71 in. broad. The character is a fine upright Kanarese hand, with letters varying from in. to 1 in. in height. The style is somewhat archaic, with features of the transitional period. The is written in both the earlier and the later fashion, the ð only in the later. An 2 of rather archaic 
cursive m of the peculiar kind mentioned above appears twice in l. 15; and the y is composed of two parts, not, as is usual, of three. The language is Old Kaparese, except for the fornial Sanskrit verse in 11. 11-13. Some words are lexically interesting, as mattal for mattar, 11 6-7 (cf. above, remarks under A, and C.), damma, ll. 7-8, ūdigal, 1. 7, (?) gam-bonnu, 1. 8, vasa, 1. 9. 
The record refers itself in II 1-3 to the reign of Nityavarsha-Amõghavarsha, with the usual epithets of royalty. This is peculiar, for these two birudar are not elsewhere borne by a single king As the inscription seems to be perfectly genuine, we must conclude either that the draftsman made the mistake of combining the brrudas of two different kings, which seems rather improbable, or that they were actually borne together by some sovereign Who this sovereign could have been is a matter of conjecture; bat, as our epigraph mentions as his viceroy Sankaraganda, whom we have already met in inscription C., and as nāl-gámunda, Gāmundiga, who figures in A.-C., it seems at any rate possible that Nityavarsha-Amoghavarsha is the same as Nityavarsha-Khottiga, the son of Amoghavarsha-Vaddiga and the younger brother and successor of Krishna III (Kannara) Akälavarsha, so that the date of the inscription would be about A.D. 970. 
After mention of the reigning king the record states that at the time the Banavāsi province was under the governorship of Sankaraganda, while Gāmundiga was näl-gámunda of Edevolal (11. 4-6), and then sets forth a standing order in connection with the levy of the king's taxes on land and houses in Kēsalür and some cognate matters. 
The places mentioned are the Banavāki nádu (1. 4), the Edevolan Seventy (1. 5), and Kösalur, 1.e. the modern Kyasanur (1. 6).

SOME MINOR RASHTRAKUTA INSCRIPTIONS. 
14 mödada? pale(la)m-akā(kku) alido[m*] pamchcha-vaha. 15 patakan-akū(kku) Ma[m]gada(la) mah[ä*]-gıris 
TRANSLATION. (Lines 1-11.) Hail! while Nityavarsha, darling of Fortune and Earth, great Eraperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, Amõghavarsha, was reigning over the earth while Sankaraganda was governing the province of Bana väsi:--while Gämundiga was holding the county-shrievalty over the Eqevolal Seventy :-an arrangement was laid down for Késalar (a& follows): for a mattal (the tax is to be four damma, for an üdigal three, for a house two; the damma on houses (is to be) one... gold; when the thirty-two Crown-officials: hold the survey, they shall provide rice for one year; the county-sheriffs there shall provide 
(it) thence. 
(Verse 1: a common Sanskrit verse-formula.) (Lines 13-15 : a Kanarese prose formula.) 
NOTEūdigalge may have to be corrected into ūdigalge (üligakke ?) in the sense - for services" ; gan may be taken with the word ondu which precedes at and explained as a conjunc. tion corresponding to kkam. Evidently 10 dammas equalled 32 pon. In the phrase ondu tasuda kazaniklege I would insert di before vasada and translate : "the king, whoever at may be, should provide rice for one day." In the collection of taxes in former times, the bill collec tor used to be fed at the expense of the debtor ; cf. e.g. my remarks on remission of rottachchu, 
A. R. on Epigraphy (Madras) for 1911, page 77.-H. K. S.] 
This small fragment occupies an area of about 8 in in height and 1 ft. 55 in in width. The character is a fair Kanarose of cursive sloped type, with letters varying from in. to 1 in. The X is written in both the earlier and the later style, the ð only in the later. The guttural pasal occurs in I. 5, the palatal nasal in 1. 1. The ordinary cursive form of m is used in 
[a]mantanadhipati (sic!), l. 1, frimat, l. 2, -chasiraman, l. 3, and -9[a*]mundu, 1. 5. The language is Old Kanarene. The ļ 18 wrongly written for p in pannil-, II. 2-3 
As to matter, the fragment is part of the official preamble of some document, and reports that at a certain date the Banavāsi Twelve-thousand was under the government of the Alala #amantadhipati Kannayya, while the county-sheriff of the Edevojal Seventy was Polege and the town-sheriff Singa. On epigraphic grounds it may be assigned to a date a few years later than the preceding record. 
TEXT.6 pancha-mahāsa (sa)bda-mabās [a]mantana dhipati? Srimat Kannayya[m] Banavābi-pa 
nnilcha(rchchhā)siraman=āle @ srimat Ede 4 vola[1-6]lpattakk[e] Polegam n[a*]l-g[X*]mundu 5 geyye Singan-ür-ggănunqu-geyye 
3. DEVIHOSUR INSCRIPTION OF SAKA 884. Dāvīhogūr, literally “New Town of the Goddess" (probably because of some temple of Davā, serving to distinguish it from other towns called Hosûr), is a village in the Karajyı taluka of Dharwår District; the Bombay Survey sheet No. 309 places it in lat. 14° 471" and long. 75° 22', about 41 miles west of Håvēr In 1. 9 of the present inscription, which was found at the local temple of Bhogēšvara, it is called by its ancient name, Pos&Yür, whence is 
Rosd -eri. Road ašvam ēdhada. 
2 Read pamoha-manāmpätakan. Apparontly the same as dramma. This use of a rasu for “officer of the lang " is noteworthy. * From the ink-inaprossion. 
* Read -sämantadhipati, 
O p m

286 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA 
[VOL XVI. 
w 
Con 
derived hosūr, the second element of the modern name. The stone is rounded at the upper corners, and in a band on the top are sculptures of the sun (proper right) and moon (left). Below this is an inscribed area about 2 ft. 3. in. high and 17 in. broad. It is somewhat 
from the top downwards to l. 5 -The character is a bold Kanarese hand of the period, somewhat affectedly angular in ll. 1-5, the letters vary in height from in. to lf in, and belong to the transitional type The vowels 8 and 7 are written in the later manner, except in trayodası (1.7), janakke (1 9), and bēlva (1 10).-The language Is Old Kanarose, but not of the more archaic type 
The record opens by referring itself in 11. 1-4 to the reign of Akālavarsha Kannara-slēve (the Rashtrakūta Krishna III, on whom see Dynast Kanar Distr., pp 418-422), while his subordinate Garvindara was. governing the Banavāsı nadul (11 4-5). It then states that on a given date in Saka 884 an impost of 55 gadyānas was required of the Mahājanas of Posavür, from the interest of which certain Brāhmans were to be fed at the samkrānti in the house of Binaga, son of Malakka (11. 6-13), and it concludes with a pious prayer that religion may increase for all time (11. 13-14). 
The date is specified on Il 6-9 as Saka 884, Dundubhi; Pausha su. 13, Sunday; the uttarayana-sankranti. There is a slight irregularity here The Saka year intended is the current year, corresponding to Dundubhi of the Northern Cycle; the tithi Pausha śu. 13 was connected in that year with Sunday, 22 December, A D. 981, ending 18 h 8 m after mean sunrise (for Ujjain). The uttarayana-sankranti occurred on the following Monday, 23 December, at 6 h. 25 m after mean sonrise. Thus the tithr ended at 0.8 A.M and the samkrānta occurred at 12 25 A M. on the same day, Monday These calculations are by true tathis, but if we reckon with mean tothis and months the resul 
a mean tithus and months the result is rather different, for thus su. 13 corresponds to Monday, 23 December (being current during 20 h 36 m. of the preceding Sunday, and ending 3 h 24 m. after mean sunrise on the Monday), while the samkrānte occurred 16 h 54 m 22 s after mean sunrise on the Mondays It is thus impossible to say whether the date in the inscription was calculated by true or by mean tithes 
The only place-names mentioned are the Banavāsi rādu (15) and Posavür, ie. Dēvīhosūr (1 9).

No. 22.) 
PADMANERI GRANT OF VENKATA I: SAKA-SAMVAT 1520. 
287 
WAN 
No 22.-PADMANERI GRANT OF VENKATA I: SAKA-SAMVAT 1520. 
By V. NATESA AIYAR, BA, M.R.AS, PESHAWAR. 
The subjoined grant is published with the aid of an excellent inked estampage, kindly supplied to me by Rao Sahib H. Krishna Sastr, Government Epigrapbist for India It is noted as No. 14 of Appendix A in the Annual Report on Epigraphy for 1905-6 
The copper-plates on which the grant is incised are seven in number is can be judged from the Telugu numerals at the right-hand corner, and they are bored at the top for the insertion of a ning and seal, which, unfortunately, are no longer to be founill Of these plates the first and the last are carved only on the inner side, and the remaining five on both sules The space covered by the writing measures 7" x 7" on each plate, u bile the size of the individual letters varies from " to " The alphabet is Nandınāgarī, with the exception of the sign manual' at the end, which is in the Kannada-Telugu script. 
Among the orthographical peculiarities and errors which occur in the grant may be men tioned (1) the doubling of consonants when preceded by r, as 10 °(20) yyo (17), törttiyiko (1. 10), sauyyệna (1 21), durggao (1. 55), 0y=ddadâtı (1. 149); (2) the doubling of dwhen preceded by an arustära or followed by y, as in Brunddhati (1. 29), maddhye (1 46), sui nullava' (1 70), Osaddhyuo (1 117), (3) the use of anu slāra instead of nasal, as su 
inte (146), "Vemgalāmbă (15+), "hondaziduo (l. 56), "Lasayain (1 100), bra nhandant (1. 136), Ov-ēmdrin (1 269); (4) the omission of lzsarga before conjunct sibilants, as 123 
hamini siao ( 
115), Prāga hushitau (1. 38), od-anuja sri (1 62), °dhe śrzo (1. 122), pruyata: oito (h. 164), (5) the use of dental n for cerebral n as in ? urnatao (1 88), szarnu (1. 228), (6) thu use of yi for i and ye for e and 22e versá as in yötao (L 33), yıtro (188), mārta(1. 91). and (7) nou-adherence to Sandhı rules, as in =abluüt=sla (1 2), śrīmat-chuo (1. 170), "y-otbiūta* (1. 191) 
The inscription consists of 159 Sanskrit verses and opens with an invocation to the god Sri Venkatesa in prose The peculiar Sanskrit words and the royal burudas used in tbix epigraph are the same as in the other published records of this king and of his successor, Vezzata 11 and Ranga VI 
The genealogy of the king (vv 3-28), both mythological and historical, agrees precisely with that given in the inscriptions already refered to, while the description of his VI:T044 and exploits (vy 29-45) adds nothing to what is contained in the Vilāpāka grants 
Verses 46-47 give the date of the grant, which was the twelfth tithi of the bright fort night of the month of Srāyana in the Saka year reckoned by the sky, the eyes, the arrows an. the moon (ie 1520), the cyclic year being Viļambin. This date corresponds with A.D 1598. 
Tbe grant was made in the presence of the god Venkatēsa, evidently on tke Tiromala hill, and at the request of Krishna, the Nāyaka king of Madhură. The latter's pedigree, as shown ia

the present record (vv 58-78), tallies exactly with what Mr. Sewell has given. I but is not included in the Königar Plates of Venkata II. This pedigree can be shown as follows: 
Nāga of the Kaśyapa race 
Viśvanātha

Krishna (or Kumāra Krishnapa alias Lingaya) 
As to the martial exploits and public charities of these Nāyaka kings, the record says that Vibranātha, son of Nága, defeated the Tıravadı king and the great Påndya Vāņāda-rāyas and his allies in battle and established his sway over the kingdom of Madhura (v 59), that his grandson Virapa Nayaka constructed a sculptured manda pa in front of the shrine of Sundalo sa, the presiding deity of Madura, gave the goddess Minākshi a golden karacha set with gems, instituted pājās, performed the ceremonies and made the gifts hēnz-āsta, hēma-garbha, Karaküm manz-tula-pūrusha, etc. (Tv 63-64); that Virapa Nayaka's son Krishna obtained the glace of Rangapatı (1 e the god of Srirangain) by gifts of jewelled kavachas, silk garments, and zieh ornaments, such as (liadems, ear-rings, and waistband, by the endowment of villages, gardens and orchards, by the celebration of car-festivals and by the due performance of daily rituals 12 bis temple (v. 69), and that he also founded agrahāras for the exclusive use of Brahman well-versed in sõstras, and bestowed villages on them in perpetuity. 
The object of the grant was the village of Padmanēri (11 107 sqq.), surnamed Tirumalanb puran, presumably after Krishna-Nayaka's mother, and belonging to the Tiruvadi-rajya, ia Vänava-rādu, and in Pachchättuppokku (Tamil: Pachchárruppökku), evidently so called because it was irrigated by the Pachchārru river. The village was situated to the east of Kottakudi Marugāl and the Bhinnäśman, to the south of the boundary) stone of Vêttekärankulan and Modayankulam, to the west of the bridge (1 e anicut) of Devanallūrá alias Sömanatha. kshētra and to the north and west of the river Srāma-nadi. The village enjoyed a rogular supply of water from the Syäma-nadı ancut and possessed the ownership of the two dans CiUSH the mountain streams between Cholagin and Vallıgı, as also the numerous canals. 1310 village of Padmanēli may be identified with its namesake 24 miles east of Nânguniéri in the Tinnevelly distrct Mr Sewell (Insts of Antiquities, Vol. I, p 315) says that there is here a large temple with inscriptions in Tamil, Telugu, Grantha and Malayalam characters. 
The terms of the grant are the same as those used in similar records of this dyoasty and embrace every kind of proprietary night, including immunity from all taxes and unha p ered powers of enjoyment and alienation in perpetuity

Some of these donees, it may be noted, seem to have come from distant provinces Thus, Akkala-Bhatta is stated to be the son of Peru-Bhatta of Yodya or Orissa (v 86); Tirumala-Nam. bikonda, the son of Pina-Madhava, of Madavada or Marwar (v 88); Bhuma-Bhatten the son of Nāgā-Bhatta of Mahamkālı, or Mahākāli or Ujjain (?) (V 92), and Närayana, the son of Yallam Bhatta of Huggi or Hotgi (v. 115). It is also worthy of note that the donees belong to vanou, Brahinanical sects and to different sākhās, gotras and sūtras, from which it is apparent that the 
292 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[Vor. XVI. 
- 
- 
mam 
m oda 
t 
ion 
-memadamom 
king was very tolerant in matters of religion and confined his munificence to no particular sect or class.1 
In y. 81 it is said that the village of Padmanëri was divided into 83 shares, and the actual number of shares distributed among the donees comes to that number. 
The inscription was composed by Krishnakavi-Kamakoti, grandson of Sabhāpati, and engraved by Virana-Mahacharya, son of Ganapaya.s 
The grant closes with the usual imprecatory rerses (vv 155-59) and the sign-manual of the king 
TEXT.

First Plate. 1 श्रीवेंकटेशाय नमः । यस्य संपर्कपुण्येन नारीरत्न 2 मभूशिला' । यदुपास्यं सुमनसां तहस्तुइंदमाश्रये ।। १*] 3 यस्य हिरदवकाद्याः पारिषद्याः परप्रशतं । विन निघ्नंति भजतां 4 विष्वक्सेनं तमाश्रये ॥ २*] जयति क्षीरजलधेर्जातं सत्येक्षणं हरेः । पालं. 
Lines 5-94 are omitted as the verses 3-42 which they contain have been printed above (Vol. XI, No.34) as occcurring in the Marédapalli Grant, most of them also in the Dalavay Agraharam Plates (Vol XII, No. 21), the Aryilimangalam Plates (Vol. XII, No 38) and in the two Grants of Venkatapati (Vol. XIII, No. 22). Some of the following verses also occar more or less exactly in the same.

? The composer of the Viläpäla, Kondyta and the Kaliakursi grants of Yerk. i I, Venkata II, and Ranga VI was Rima, son of Kimaköti and grandson of Sabhāpatı. 100 शाखी सुधीसार्थानां भुजतेजसा खवयं कर्नाटसिंहासनं [*] 101 आ सेतोरपि चाहिमाद्रि विमतान् संहृत्य शासन्मुदा सर्वोवी प्र. 102 चकास्ति वेंकटपतिश्रीदेवरायाग्रणीः ॥ ४५*] व्योमनेत्रककंवेंदु 103 गणिते शकवत्सरे । वमरे च विळंब्याख्ये मासि श्रावणनाम 104 नि ।। ४६*] पक्षे वळक्षे पुग्यायां द्वादश्यां च महातिथौ । श्रीवेंकटेशपा 108 दालसबिधौ श्रेयसानिधी ।। ४७*] नानाशाखाभिधागोत्रसूत्रेभ्यो (भ्यः) 106 शास्त्रवित्तया । विख्यातेभ्यो हिजातिभ्यो वेदविट्यो विशेषतः । । ४८*] 107 श्रीसमग्रे तिरुवडिराज्ये वानवनाडु के । पञ्चात्तुप्पोक्कुके चापि 108 प्रख्याति समुपाशि(थितं ।। ४८*] प्राचं कोडाकुडिमरुगालो भिवाश्मनो 109 पि च । वेट्टेकारन्कुळपाट्यो दक्षिणं मोडवन्कुकात् । ५०*] सोमनाथ 110 क्षेत्रदेवनसेतोच पश्चिमं । श्यामनद्याः पश्चिमां च दिशमा 111 श्रितमुत्तरां ही ५१*] निरुपाधिश्यामनदीसेतुपाथोभिवाईता(तं) । त 112 चोळवल्लिगिर्योश्च मध्ये सेतुइयांभसा ।। ५२] कुल्यावलौजलानां 113 च स्वातंत्रण समन्वितं । एतनामतटाकावुनिनिरोधस्थला 114 न्वितं ।। ५३*] - -------- । श्रीमत्तिस्म 115 लांबायाः पुरमित्यपराभिधं । पद्मनरीतिनामानं ग्राम 116 मारामशोभितं । ।५४*] सर्वमान्यं चतुस्सीमासहितं च समततः ।

No. 22.7 PADMANERI GRANT OF VENKATA I : SAKA-SAMVAT 1520. 295 156 कहिजस्थापनामित्वेक्ष्य' स्मृतिमग्रहाररचनारक्षे कते येन किं । ७२*] देश 156 स्मिन्कतसर्वमान्यकतया षट्कर्मनिष्टा हिजा दैवातिथ्यविधौ सदाशिषि 157 रता यस्येति नैवाङ्गुतं । तत्तद्भपकरप्रदानकलितक्षेत्राधि[नि*]र्मोचकस्मो[य]-3 158 हानधनान्यदेशधरणोदेवाशिषोच्च श्रियः ।। ७३*] तस्य दानधुरीणस्य तरुणादित्य 139 तेजसः [*] तरवारिलताकोटितांडवोद्यज्जयश्रियः । ७४*] वक्षःप्रदेशे 
मांधातुर्बाह्रो रुग्मा]. 160 गदस्य च [*] लक्ष्मणस्य मुखांभोजे हृदये हर्षशोमिनः । ७५*] 
प्रत्यंगमादिभूपानां प्रक 161 टीकुर्वतः प्रथां । श्रीदक्षिणसमुद्रेशप्रख्यातबिरु दोनतेः । । *] श्रीमत्यं 
चर्तिर 162 वडिसप्तांगहरणौजसः । वरवीरमहोपालवाराकरसुधानिधेः [ ७७*]

Fifth Plate · First Side 164 परीतः प्रयतै स्निग्धैः पुरोहितपुरोगमैः [*] विविधैर्विवुधै' श्रौतप 166 थिकैरधिगिरा | ७८*] श्रीवीरवेंकटपतिमहारायमहीपतिः । स 166 हिरण्यपयोधारापूर्वकं दत्तवान्मुदा [ ८.*] सोयं कृष्णमहीपालम्मुत्राम 167 समवैभव: । त्रयोत्तराशीतिवृत्तीः पद्मनां विधाय सः ।[1 ८१*] नानागोत्र 168 हिजातिभ्यो धारापूर्वमदान्मुदा [*] वृत्तिमंतोत्र लिख्यते विप्रा वेदांत

Seventh Plate. 258 श्रीवेंकटपतिरायक्षितिपतिवर्यस्य कीर्तिधुर्यस्य । पास 259 नमिदं सुधीजनकुवलयचंद्रस्य भूमहेंद्रस्य । । १५२*] [ोगकटपतिरा 260 यमापनिदेशेन शासनश्लोकान् [*] कृष्णकविकामकोटिमर 261 समभाणीमभापतेः पौत्रः । । १५३*] श्रीबंकटमहारायसूतया गणप 262 यात्मजः । श्रीवोरणमहाचार्यो व्यलिखि(ख)त्तांमशासनं [ १५४*]

ABSTRACT OF CONTENTS. 
Verses 1-3. Invocation to Venkatesa, the feet of Rama, Vishvaksana and the Moon. VF, 4-6. The genealogy of the Arariţi famıly down to king Bukka. Vy. 7-8. Praises of Bukka and his wife Ballămbikā. VF. 9-11. The conquests of Rāna-Rāja, son of Bukka. Vy 12-13 Praises of Sriraäga-Rāja I, son of Rāma-Raja and Lakkambikā. 
Vr. 14-15. Praises of Tirumalambika, wife of Sriranga-Raja and the mother of Raja, Tramala-Raya and Venkatadri. 
Vy. 16-17. The military exploits of Rāma-Rāja. V. 18 Praises of Venkatādri-Räja 
Vr. 19-28. Of the three sons of Sriranga, Tirumala-Raya alone by his military. succeeded to the throne. His pilgrimages and benefactiorg.
