PADMANERI GRANT OF VENKATA I: SAKA-SAMVAT 1520. 
297 
w 
ww wwwwwwwwwwwww 
wwwwwwwwwwwwwww 
w 
wwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwWWW 
Vv. 24-25. The conquests of Konduvidu, Vinikonda and other fortresses by Sriranga Rāya (II), son of Tirumala-Rāya and Vengalamba, while staying at Uddagiri (Udayagiri) and at his capital Penukoņda. 
V. 26. Sriranga-Rāya's coronation ceremony and his praises 
Vv 27-28. Venkatapati-dēva-Rāya succeeds his brother Sriranga-Rāya on the latter's death. 
V. 29. Venkatapatı-Rāya's coronation performed by his preceptor Tātayārya and his con quest of the Yavanas (Muhammadans). 
V.30. His queens were Venkatāmbā, Rāghavāmbā, Pedobamāmba and Krishna mâmbă. 
V. 31. The defeat of Mahamanda-sābu (i.8. Muhammad Shah), son of Malik-ībharama (1.e. Malik Ibrāhīm). 
Vy 32-45. His numerous birudas and praise 
Vv 46-48 In the Sake year vyoma-rētra-kalamb-indu (ie 1520), in the cyclic year Vilambin, in the month of Srāyana, in the bright fortnight, or presence of god Venkatēśa, the grant was made to Brahmans of vanous sākhās, names, gotras and sūtras, most of whom were well-persed in the Vēdas. 
Vv. 49-57. The object of the grant was the village of Padmanērī, in the Tiruvadi rāgya, vānava-nādu and the Pachchatcuppökku, of which the boundaries are set forth in detail. The terms of the grant. 
Tv, 58-59 The genealogy of the [Nāyakı) kings of Madhură--Nāga and Visvanātha. The latter conquered Vānādaraya, the great Pandya and the Tiruvadi kings. 
Vy 60-61. Praises of Visvanātha's son Krishna, the Nayaka of the south and his wife Lakshmyambikā. 
Vy. 62-64. Praises of their son Vira and his gifts to the temples of Sundara-Nayaka and Minākghi (at Madura) and the numerous religious rites which he performed. 
Vy. 65-66 Praises of Tirumalāmbikā, wife of Vira. 
Tv. 67-77. Praises of Křishna (Nayaka), son of Vira, his gifts to the god of Ranga (i.e. Srirangam) and his birudas 'lord of the Southern Ocean' and 'the conqueror of the army of Pañchar-Tiruvadi ? 
Vv 78-80. The gift of the said village of Padmanēri was made by king Venkatapati Rấya at the request of Krishna (Näyaka) of Madura. 
V.81 The village was divided into 83 parts. Vy. 82-83. Grant to Sambhu, Madhava (Vishņu), and Mahāśāstrı, the village deities. Vy. 84-151. The names of the donees and their shares. 
Vy. 152-153 The poet who composed the verses in the grant at the command of Venkatapatı-Rāya, was Krishnakavi Kämakoti, grandson of Sabhāpati. 
V. 154 The engraver of the grant, at the bidding of Venkata-Mahārāya, was Virans Mahāchārya, son of Ganapaya. 
Yv, 155-159. The usual admonitory and imprecatory verses, folloyed, ILL Iine 270, by the sign-manual' Sri-Venkatēša in the Kannada Telugu script. 
298 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
No. 23.-YELLANGUDI PLATES OF VENKATAPATI-DEVA-MABARAYA I: SAKA 
SAMVAT 1520. BY THE LATE T. A. GOPINATHA RAO, M.A., TRIVANDRAM. The inscription edited below is engraved on a set of seventeen copper-plates. These have the shape common to all inscribed plates bearing the deeds of grauts made by the kings of the Vijayanagara dynasty of the period to which this set belongs. In the curved upper part of each of these plates ig & round hole through which the binding ring is meant to pass ; to the proper left of this hole and on the first side of each plate is marked the number of the plate in Teluga-Kannada numerals. The rims are raised to protect the writing from damage. When the Bet came to me for examination, there was no ring The first plate is engraved on the second side, and the last one on its first side only. Plates 7, 13 and 14 are lost, since these belong to that part of the document which enumerates the names of donees, the historically important portion of the record is intact. The preservation of the inscription is very good. From impressions taken under my supervision, as also from the originals, I now edit the inscription. 
The alphabet of the record is Nandināgarī ; the sign-manual of the king, the word Sri-Torikataša, is in the Telugu alphabet. There is nothing peculiar in the orthography of the inscription demanding special comment. All the faults usual in the other documents of the Vijayanagara kings are also found in this; for example, the use of the anusvåra for the varga-panchama, sa for śa, eto. 
The graut belongs to the reign of the king Veikatapati-déva-Mahārāya. His genealogy is traced from the moon as follows: 
Moon 
Budha 
Paräravas 
Nahdaha 
Yayati 
Puru 
Bharata 
Santana 
*** 
*** 
(Fourth descendant) Vijaya (Arjuna) 
Abhimanya 
Parikshit (Eighth descendant) Nanda 
(Ninth descendant) Chalikka (Seventh descendant) Rājanarēndra 
(Tenth descendant) Bijjalēndra (Third descendant) Vira-Hemmäli-RĀya

The doings of each of these kings are given in the document in some detail Sömidēva is represented as having taken seven forts from his enemies in a single day (v.7) Pinnama is described as the lord of Aravidu, and his son is reported to have established Saluva Nrisimha firmly on tbe throne (v.8). His son Rāma-Raja was a staunch devotee of Vishnu, and through His grace he got over the effects of poison administered to him by his jñātis in the fort of Kandanavõlu durgam, which he had just then taken after defeating Sapāda at the head of an army consisting of 70,000 horses and taking from him tbe Avanigiri dungam, driving off with him Kasapp-Udaya (vv. 13 and 12). 
Rama-Raja, the son of Sriranga-Raya, ruled the country justly, after destroying the enemie's of the world (the Musalmans), and was a veritable kalpaka-urilisha in his munificence Of the three sons of Sriranga-Raya, the middle one, Tirumala-Mahālaya, having routed his enemies in battles, was anointed to the throne and like Vishnu, the middle member of the Hindu Trinity, protected the kingdom. This king performed again and again all the mahadānus such as the svarna-tula-purusha and the upadanas in such holy places as Kāñchi, Srirangam, etc., and in all important places of pilgrimage and holy tirthas (vv. 20 and 27). His son Sriranga-Raya, being stationed in Uddagiri, conquered the forts of Kondavida, Vinikonda pura, etc., and began to reign in Penagonda. He had emblems, such as the makara, as signs of royalty. The great gifts which this king made on the occasion of his coronation permanently removed poverty from poor people (vv. 29 and 30). After him succeeded to the throne his brother Venkatapati-deva Mahārāya, aluo born to the same mother, Vengalamba, Jost

A Rama was anointed by Tasislıtha, lus family priest, Venkatapati-dēvarāya's coronation was performed by the learned Tātajārya, his gall. Having conquered the Yavanas, he ruled the earth. He defeated Muhammanda Sāhu, the son of Malikibharām, in battle, and during the continuance of the war the latter used to return laome day by day after losing his elephants, horses, weapons and unbrellit. Venkatapati-déra-Mabarāya was extolled by the kings of the Kuinbhoja, Bhoja, Kāluigiz, Karahāta and other countries, waiting at the entrance of his palace He bore the 621 wedis, ('lanaś2-durg-arla-vibhala-varya, Hosaburudana-ganda, Raya-1ūlanitta Irindu, Avalaligaya-in/Til-11202 lika Biruddi-manniyara-ganda, Otkul-éndori-jaya-pandata-tira, Mannyrī uslīnzul, Gandurci-guli, Manya-prili, Mandalīka-dharani-zaraha, Venga-trabhu?'un2-nialla, Tin jūla-suratıām, lanirizohla-kamabhadra, Mandaliha-ganda, Aratta-Jagadha-pânya-pada, Chilchki-clickr alan tuz, Eberudu-rāya-aluta-vēšy-arka-bhujanga, Kulyjäna-pu? -adhipa, Oddiya. rñlju-lheslīpaita, D'hesilege-tippuva-rāyara-ganda and Müru-rāyara-gandu. 
Having obtained the throne of the Karnāta kingdom by the prowess of his arms, and defiatıng bis enemies, Venkatapatı-depa-Raya ruled the earth from the Himalayas to Satu (kanaśvaranu). 
Tho genealogy as given in this grant agrees as far as Tirumala-Rāya with those giren in the Koņ.lyäta, the Kallakurśı, the Küạiyir and the Vilāppäkkam grants and cntirely with that found in the Dalatās-Agrabāram Plates of this king. This grant, like the last nrcntioned, omits the names of Rām. III and Raghunatha among the sons of Tirumala-Rüya and gives only those of Srilanga-Raya (Ranga Il) and Veokatapati I. 
The historical importance of the erents pairated in relation to the individual kings, the Elncestors of Venkata pati l, as also about Tātayarya, his family priest, has been discussed already in my article on the Lalavāy-Agrahāran Plates of Venkata pati-deva-Mahārāya (Ep Indo, Vol. XII, pp. 159.187), and the efore Deed not be repeated here. 
The present graut is dated the Saka Samvat 1520, computed by the moon (indu), the arrows (hulumba), the eyes (11ētra) and the sky (vyoma), which corresponded with the cyclic year Vilimbin. On the dvādıśí tithi of the bright half of the month Srāvana the king Vira van aap ti-Makarāya granted as an agrahāra to a large number of Brāhmanns the village of Vell ogollı together with Ksiyattankurichchi, Uppu-vāņiyan-puttür and Mānāmongalam in Porumpattu,all clubbed together under the name of Vīrabhüpa-samudram, at the request of prince Krishna-Bhajati of Madura. The villages grapted were in the Mulll-rādzi which forned part of the sub-division Añjarakkarô of the Tiruvadi-dēsa Their boundaries are stated in yv. 56-66 
The prilice Krishna-Bbūpati, at whose request the grant was made, was the tben Nayaka of Madura His pedigree 18 traced thus .--In the Kaśyapa götra was born Nāga, a devotee of the god Visteśvara (evidently of Käsi or Banarasi). His son was VI conquered the T1-uvadı, the great Pandya, the Vānādaraya and other kisgs in pitched battles and took from theiu their kingdoms solely by the prowess of his arms and became the lord of the H20hurā country. Krishna, the lord of the south, possessed of valour, justice, intelligence and courage, was burn to Visvanālba. The queen of Krishna was Lakshmyambikā To these was born Vira-Bhrpati, of cbarming manners. This last mentioned prince constructed & 977 anda pa, containing several beautifully sculptured pillars, in front of the shrine of the god Saundara-nājaša (that is, Sundarēsvara of the famous Siva temple at Madura) and prescnted to the goddess Mināksbī golden covering (kavacha) set with genus. He is described as having performed the gifts called hēni-āśva, hēma-garbha, tulā-pūrusha (weighing against gold and precious stones), vasva-chakra, brahm-ānda, gö-sahasra, elephané chariot and lami-dhēru mare of gold, sapt-ān.bhadhi, horse chariot made of gold, riqhabhūta. gluuta, svarnu-kshmã and ratna-dhēmai. Prince Krishna-Nahīpati granted enouyh money to the Brahmanas of other kingdoms to redeem their lands, which they lost to their kinys owing to their inability to pay the taxes thereon By this statement we are to ouderstand that the government of otte kings was so oppressive even in the case of Brāhmanas, and consequently much muie so in the cuse of other castes, that the former had, on account of their lanbility to make good the beavy taxes imposed upon their lands, to abandon them; whereas the government of Krishna-Mabīpatı was so good as to attract Brühmanas even from other conntries to seek the benefit or las munificence. The statemont is not a mere boast, as will be seen from the list of villages from which came the Brahmana donees of this grant; I shall revert to this matter later on Kệishna. Brahmanas and, curiously enough, to some Brālmana ladies also ; it is a very rare thing to meet with the allotment of shares to women in the agraharas which are conferred on Brāhplanas. T 16 stated that the aqzahara was divided into two hundred and sixty-one urithis and that each 
zite was further divided into five ansas, thus making a total of 1,305 ainsas, and the gift to each Junee is made in terms of the ainsos We learn that each zritte was sufficient to meet the needs of fire persons; it appears that the shares were granted, perhaps, proportionate to the number of members in the family of a donee In tbe existing plates of the set a total of one hundred aud eighty-twozrittis and one ansa are accounted for, and the plates seven, thirteen and fourteen. which are lost, should base contained an account of the distribution of the remaining seventy eiglit irittis and four amsas. abstract of contents" at the end 
From that list it would seem that most of the donees were residents of the Telugu country and bau either already migrated into the Tamil country or had come down south at the invita tion of tłe donor Anyhow the record is of mure than ordinary importance in that it accounts. like a few others, for the existence of a large number of Telugu Biābmaņa families in the "Tinnerelly District. Tuezuselyes Telugas by birth and possessing strong liking for the men of their own country, speaking their own language, the Nāyakas of Madara would have imported large colonies of Telugu Brāhmauas from the north and settled them down in Madora and Tinnevelly Districts. At present there are numbers of Telugu Brāhmana families in several villages in the Tiuncvelly District as, for instance, Tenkāzi, Sērmādēvi, Pāvür, Vellangudi, Pêttai, Nālāttinputtar, Köyalpattı, Tirunelvēli and Elavēlangal and in many villages in the Madura Distriob. A parallel to this tendency to import their own countrymen, speaking their own tongue, is to be found in the Marāthă Räjas of Tanjore, who planted a considerable colony of Maratha aud Gurjara Brāhmanas in the Tanjore kiugdom, some of which families are not found scattered over the whole of the Marras Presidency, having at one time occupied the highest positions both in the British Government and in the Native States. 
ME 
The present record is of great importance for the history of the Nayakas of Madura, which is not very clearly known. The late Mr. Nelson had attempted a continuous and fairly fall History of this dynasty of princes in his dadura Manual, from all available sources, such as India. chionicles, traditions and manuscripts and a few inscriptions, as also the valuable records of the Jesuits of the Madara Mission Attempts have been made quite recently by some others with the help of the same materials to reconstruct the history of this country and of this period, with, to my mind, no whit better success than that achieved by the pioneer, Mr. Nelson, All attempts at tracing Iudian History murely from the sources referred to above have proved incomplete, if not always incorrect. It must be constructed mainly on the strength of inscrip. tions, supplemented largely from literary and other sources, wherever the latter do not militate against the statements made in inscriptions. Some amount of new information regarding tee Nayakas of Madura has been brought to light in my articles on the Krishnapuram Plates of Sadasiva dēva-Mahārāya, the Dalaváy. A grabāram Plates of Venkata pati-dēva-Mahārāya and other records. The first of these deals with the reign of Krishnappa Nayaka I, son of Višvanātha. Nayaka, and the second with that of his son Vira-Bhāpati, Virappa-Māyaka or Periya or Peda Virappa Nayaka , the copper-plate grant auder consideration belongs to the reign of the latter's son Krishna-Vahipati or Krisbnuppa-Nayaka II Thus the three records belong to three consecutive reigns, and the last is of greater historical importance than the others. It is necessary therofore to discusa here the historical information contained in this inscription in the light of other epigraphical ieuords.

In the Krishṇāpuram Plates, Nāgama-Nayaka is said to have been a devotee of the god Visvanatha and to havo borne the burudas, Kāñchi-pura-var-adhisvara, Mökalapatta-vardhana, Samaya-dohara-ganda, Samaya-kolahala, Ailāvali-purd-var-adhiśvara, Pandya-kula-sthapan acharya and Dakshina-samudrādhīśvara and to have taken the kingdom of Tirnyadi. An old Tamil work called Tiruppanz-mālas, quuted by me already in my article on the Dalaváy-Agra hāram inscription, also describes Visvanātha and Virappa as Kuchcha-nāyakan Vršuvanathan and Kachchi-val Krishna-Viruppan. Evidently the Nāgakas of Madura will have been originally residents of Kāñchipura and hence must have borne the title Kanchi-pura-var-ādhīśvara 
The reading of the Velladgudi inscription, where it deals with Visvanātha-Nayaka, is defective and therefore unintelligible. The Padmanêr grant of Venkata 1,3 dated also S. 1520 gives the correct reading, which runs as follows: 
TEHTGATTITU 
[:*] Part qata: 
(Inne 120) 
Irelangt grant angeferê क्षोराब्धेरिव चंद्रमाः कुवलयानंदानुसंधायक: सौम्य[:*] श्रीवरविश्वनाथनृपतिसर्वत्रचूडामणिः । प्रख्यात श्रीस्तिरुवडिमहापाण्डवाणादरायप्राण्यानन्यानपि रणमुखे पार्थिवानाशु जित्वा । तत्तत्सीमां निजभुजबलादाहरन् विश्वनाथक्षीणोपालोभजत मधुराराज्य साम्राज्यलक्ष्मी । 
From this passage we learn that Viśvanátha, after having conquered in battles the Tiruvadi, the Mahā-Pandya, the Vânāda-Rāya and other kings, and having taken possession of their kingdoms by the true prowess of his arms, became the lord of the Madhurā-rajya and was ruling What were the circumstances under which. Visvanātha conquered the kings named above and who the Vāņāda Rāyas were and how they happened to be in the south are questions which require a clear answer Let us now try to explain briefly the points raised above. Turuuadr is the name applied in inscriptions, as well as in literature, to the king of Travancore The Tiruvadi of the time of Achyuta-dēva-Rãyą needed chastisement, since he bad harboured the enemics of the Vijayanagara emperor and had refused to acknowledge his suzerainty. Achyuta-dēva-Ray himself led the expedition as far as Srirangam, but at his own request Salaka-Tirumala- Rayu, the king's brother-in-law, was put in command of the army to subdue the Tiruvadi. Salaka-Tilunala-Rāya defeated the Tiruvadi and his confederates on the bank of the Tämra parni and made him surrender all the territories daurped by him from the Pandya. Nāgama-Nayaka evidently held then the military command over the Tondai mandalam and lived in Conjeevaram, and would therefore, on account of his familiarity with the people and their languages, have been taken by the king with bim as one of the Vijayanagara generals in his expedition against the Tiruvaļi. The Pāodya king Srivallabha, who applied to the emperor for help, must have been put in possession of his lost kugdom after the defeat of the Tiruvadi; and io remembrance of this event Achyuta-dēva-Raya, Srivallabha Pandya and Nagama-Nayaka severally called them selves Pāndya-raya-sthapan-acharyaset The Tiruvadi king then roling must, according to the inscriptions in iny collection, have been Bhätalavīra. Udayamārttánda Tarman of the Tiruppãppar branch. 
It is doubtful whether Visvanatha also formed one of the party which proceeded against the Tiruvadı at the time of Achyuta-dēva-Raya. It looks more than certain tbat Visvanatha distin guished himself in the southern regions on a subsequent occasion sud not during the reign of Acbyuta-dēva-Rära No. 140 of the Madras Epigraphist's Collection for 1395 states that the

Vijayanagara general Vitthala-déva-Mahārāya conducted an expedition against the Tiruvadi in the reign of Sadasiva-dēva-Rāya, some time before S. 1466 (=AD. 1544-45), and that a Brahmana of Tiruvidaimarudür, named Tiruchchirrambala-Bhattan, s joined Vitthala's ariav and continued to fight on his side from · Anantaśayanan in the south to Mudagal in the north Visvanatha must have been one of the military officers who accompanied Vitthala, for, No. 17 of the Madras Epigraphist's Collection for 1912 distinctly afirms that Viśvanātha obtained from Rāmarājarayyan (2.e Aliya Raunarāja), the powerful minister of Sadāśiva, the Tiruvadı-dosa as a mara-nayakam, and his son Krishnappa-Nāyaka granted seven villages in this province to the god of the Krishnapuran temple, which he bad newly built Trouble cropped up evidently once again in the Tiruvadi rālyan during the reign of Sadāśıya-dēva-Rāya, and a pupitive expedition against the king of that country was necessary, and it was accordingly despatched ander Vitthala. From one of the inscriptions in my collection we find that in the Kollam year 722 (=A.D. 1547), Blütalavīra Rāmavarman, of the Jayatunga nādu brınch, who calls himself the zēļarkkāı an of (the god ?) Sankaranārāyanamártı (probably of Nāvāykkulam, near Attingal), made arrangements for the (monthly ?) celebration, in the Vishnu shrine at Sachindram, of the day of Rohini, the natal star of Vitthalēśvara-Mahārāyar. The Tiruvadi must have lost a large portion of his territory on this occasion, and what was taken away from him appears to have been bestowed upou Višvanātha as an amuura-1āyakam. Tbe Tiruvadi was ruling, very probably, over what remained, as a vassal of the Vijayanagara king. 
The kingdom of the Pandya, king was situated on the way to the Tiruvadi rāyan, and had necessarily to be passed through If the Pandya, as stated in the document, had also to lose his kingdom, it must surely be that he had offered resistance to the passage of the Vijaya nagara army thiough his territories or offended Vitthala in some other way. Anyhow the Pāodya does not appear to have been deprived altogether of his kingdon, but was subjugated and saffered to rule as a subordinate of the Vijayanagara Emperor. 
The princes called Vānāda-Rägars were the lineal descendants of the Bana kings, who, in the earlier period of South Indian History, wore the vassals of the Pallavas and ruled over the North Arcot District and portions of the Mysore Province; their kingdom was known as Banappādi or Perunnbānappādi When the Pallavas were subverted by the Cholas, they became subordinates of the Cholas, and the Vānāda-Rayars continued faithful to the latter till the reign of Kulottunga III Rājarāja Vānakovaraiyan, alias Ponparappināņ Magadaippera māl, one of the rasgals of Kulottunga III, rebelled against bis suzerain and entered into political compacts with some southern petty princes. He drifted on to the south and appears eventually to have joined the Pandyas, who were then growing in power and were soon to subvert the Chola supiemacy during the reign of Rājarāja III and his son Rājēndra-Chola III. The Vānāde Rāyars continued to be friends and subordinates of the Pandyas till the Musalman invasion of Madara under Malık Kafür When the Pāndya king was taken prisoner and carried away by the Mubammadans, the Vāņāda-Rāyars took service under the Vijayanngara kings and ruled over the Madura country. They were Vaishnavas in religion, and they gave donations, as may be seen from their inscriptions, to the Visbnu temples at Alagarköyıl, Tiruppullani and Srivilliputtar. Visvanatha-Nayaka had evidently ousted the Vānāda-Rāyars from Madura and made it the capital of a kingdom which he formed from the districts of Madura and Tinnepelly and portions of the Travancore State. 
In fact, Visvanatha was the founder of the Nayaka dynasty at Madura, and that in the reign of Sadāśiva-dēva-Rāya. It is difficult to say how far ciedence can be given to the tradi. tion that Visvanätba fought against Năgama-Náyuka, his own father, to regain for the Emperor of Vijayanagara the Madura country said to have been usurped by him. Unless it be Presumed that he joined in a coutederacy With the Vanāda-Riyar; the Pandya and tho Tiruvadi and asserted independence, the tradition cannot be upheldNo 23.7 VELLANGUDI PLATES OF VENKATA I SAKA-SAJIVAT 1520. 
$03

1 
Tumbichchi-Nayaka by Kșishnappa. The T2ruppani-nālai enumerates the donations of this prince to the Madura temple, whereof details have already been given in Ep. Ind., Vol. XII, p. 161. 
The Srirargah-Köyrl-olugu states that Krishnappa Nayakkar gave a number of valuable ornaments to the god Ranganātha and built a landing place and a manda pa on the bank of the Kāpēri, south of Srirangam. 
Krishnappa-Nāyaka's son was Virappa-Nayaka The Vellangudi inscription describes his donations and services to the temple of Minākshi-Sandarēśvara at Madura. The acts of devo. tion attributed to him by the Tiruppani-palau have already been given by mne (Ep. Ind. Vol. XII, p. 161), and I now quote the verses in a foot-note below.? Neither the Vellañgudi inscrip tion uor the Srirangan2-Köyıl-olugu mentions any donations made by him to the temple of the god Raóganátha of Siziangam. 
The son and successor of Virappa-Nāyaka was Kumāra Krisbnappa-Nayaka II The Vellaigudi inscription is rather profase in its praise of the munificence of this prince. The statements made in this record are also corroborated by other documents. The Trouppani. nalaz states that he built in Madura the temples of Vilēśvara, Krisbuēšvara and Ayyangārīs Vara, as also the north and west mandapas in the second príkära of the temple of Mīnāksu1,3 The Srirangan-Köyıl-olugu informs us that, through the influence of Narasimha Dēsika already mentioned, Kumāra Krishnappa-Nāyaka II piesented the god Rangapātba with a coat set with gems, a herița studded with precious stones and other ornaments worth a lakh and a half pons 
Mr. Nelson, on the authority of certain manuscripta, states that on the death of Kumāra Krishgappa I (son of Viśvanātha) his two sons, Krishnappa or Periya Virappa and Visva nātha II, ruled jointly at Madura, and similarly on the death of Krishňappa or Periya Virappa his two sons, Liðgayya or Kumāra Krishnappa and Visvanātha III (ox Visvappa), ruled joiutly, but that Visvanatha III died very soon. The hitherto discovered copper-plate inscriptions dealing with the Nāyakas of Madura do not appear to corroborate the statements of the manuscripts. Mr. Sewell, following Nelson, gives in Vol. II of his Lists of Antiquitiss of Afadras brief notices of the reigns of the Nāyakas of Madura.

The Vellangudi plates mentron that Krishnappa II set up a mianz-stainbla in the temple at Madara. It is not quite easy to find out what is meant by a mana-stamula The 7'272 ppunze nālai seems to throw some light on the matter; a pillar in the temple of Winālshi vas plated with gold by one Mallappa In course of time the gold plating was word out and Krishna, Virappa (that is, Virappa, son of Krishnappa I) regilded the pillar! It is per baps this act which is attributed to the father of Krishnappa II in the Teruppune-inālur, that is alluded 10 a having been performed by the son. 
Another fact which is not quite clear about Krishpappa II 16 that he conquered whe king dom of the Pancha-Tiruvadis. Wbo these five Tiruvadīs vele it is not possible to say in the 
sent state of our kuowledge of the history of the Tua yadı kingdom He may however, provisionally assume that the term Pancha-Tiruvadi refers to the members of the various branches of the Tiruvadi liae, such as the Tiruppāppar siarūpain, the Sirziydy siili 7 Plein the Jayatunga-nada svar ūpam, etc., which were ralıng simultaneously over portions of the favol rajyam

Sræth Plate : First Side. 199 सोयं कृष्णसहीपाल: सुत्राम(स) समवैभवः [ ८५*] साहित्यर 200 ससम्मा[ज्य]भोगभोजमहीपतिः । कैयोत्तान्कुरु (f)चीमुप्युवाण्यं पु 201 त्तरमाश्रितं ॥[ ८६*] समानामंगलग्रामं कलणेकुरुचिस्थले । सकं 202 नडियकाल्पोक्कुपेरंपत्तुकडेस्थलं ।। ८७*] इमं श्रीवीरभूपसमद्राप-12 203 रनामंक । वेडंगोळीति विख्यातं ग्रामं सस्योपशोभित । ९८*]

ABSTRACT OF CONTENIS. 
(Verse 1) Adoration to Rāma s feet (V.2) Adoration to Vishyaksēna. (V.3) Idoiation to Varāha (Vishnu) (T+) States that the Moon, born from the ocean of milk, is resplendent. 
(Tr5-7) Frum the Moon came in regular succession Budha, Pururavas, Ayu, Nahushar Yayari and Pūru. In this family was born the kug Bharata, and in his lineage Santanu ; tb: Darth aftur Santanu was Vijaya (Arjuna); his son was Abhimanyu; his son Parikshit i the eighth in descent from Parikshit was Nanda ; the ninth from Nanda was Chilikka; Bājanarendra was the seventh from Chalikka; the tenth from Rājanaröndra vas Bijjalēndra ; the third from him was Vira-Hemmālı-Rāya, the lord of Mayāpuri; and the

fourth from him was Tāta-Pinnama. To Táta-Pindama was born Söml-dēva, who took from his enemies in the course of a siagle day seven forts To Somi-deva was born Vira-Rāghava dēva, and to the latter, Pinnama. 
(V.8.) The son of Pinnata, the lord of Ārayiti-nagara, was Bukka-Rāja ; he consolidated the kingdom of Saluva-Nrisimba. 
(VF 9-10 ) Bakka-Raja was married to Bailambika; to these was born a son named Räma-Rāja. 
(Vy 11-14 ) This prince Rama-Rāja conquered the army of Sapāda, consisting of seventy thousand horses, and took from him the fort of Avanıgırı durga,1 driving away Kåsapp-Odeya. This king, who was a great devotee of Vishnu, took the fort of Kandana yõli laga by the prowess of his arms, here he was poisoned by his relations, which did no harm to him He had a queen named Lekkāmbikā. A son named Sriranga-Raja was born to them. 
(Vy 15-16.) The name of the queen of Sriranga-Raja was Tirumalámbikā. By her he had sons Rāma-Räja, Tirunala-Rāya and Venkatādri in the order in wbich they are mentioned. 
(Vy. 17-18.) Rāma-Rāja ruled the earth with justice, after having destroyed his enemies, who were a pest to the world He surpassed even the wishing tree of the gods in his gifts 
(V. 19.) Venkatādrı-Rāja wus also distinguished in the world as a warrior. 
(V 20.) Tirumala-Mahārāya, the middle one among the three sons of Śrīranga-Rāya, having defeated his enemies and being anointed king, protects the earth like Vishnu among the 
Trimurtis. 
(Vy 21-26 ) Praises of Tirumala-Mahārāya. 
V. 27.) This king performed frequently all the danas mentioned in the ajamas, such as the kanaka-tul-pūrusha and the upadanas, iu ths temples at Kaichi, Sriranga, etc., and at the sacred tirthas. 
(Vy. 28-30 ) Then was born to him by Vengalamba, Sriranga-Rāya, who, residing at Uddagiri, conquered the forts of Konda vīdu, Vinikonda-pura and other forts and, making Penugonda bis capital, raled in splendour with all insignia of royalty, such as the nakara, etc. By the gifts made by this king at the time of his coronation poverty was completely wiped out for good men. 
(Vy. 31-35 ) After Sriranga-Rāya bad reached the region of Vishạn (i e. died), his brotber Venkata pati-dēva-Rāya, born of the same mother, ascended the throne and ruled the tarth with justice. Just as Rāma was crowned by Vasishtha, conquered the rūkshasas oud governed the world, this king was anointed by the learned Tātayārya, defeated the Yavanas (Masalmans) and ruled the earth He had four wives, named Võnkstāmba, Rāghavāmbā, Pedobanămba and Krishnamãmbā Mahamanda-säha, the son of Malukībharama, being defeated repeatedly by the army of this king, used daily to return dejected from the battle-fiald after being deprived of his elephants, horses, arms and umbrella 
(V. 36 ) Description of Venkatapati-deva-Raya's reiga. (Vy. 37-50.) The birudas of this kiog as employed by the court-heralds. 
(V. 51.) The kings of the Kamboja, Bhõja, Kalinga, Karabāta, etc., countries used to stand at the gate of this king and praise him 
(V. 52 ) Having made, by the power of arms, the throne of Karnāta his own and after conquering all his enemies living in the legion between Sēta and the Himadri, Veokatapati dēva-Rāya ruled the kingdom in joy. 
(Vv 53-98.) In the Saka year 1520 (counted by indu=, Kalımba =5, netru=? and vyona=0), whicb corresponded to the cyclic) year Vilambin, on the dvadasi tutki of cue 
i [Tuis should be Adoranı durga see above, p. 209, a. 1.-F. W T.]

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA.

RAW 
bright half of the month. Śrāvana, in the holy presence of the god Sri-Veokatēśa, the villages of Vellangolli, Kaiyottānkuruohī, Uppu-Vänyam-puitür and Manamangala in the Perumbatt-ulkade, being clabbed together under the name of Virabhüpa-samudra, were granted, together with all the eight kinds of enjoyments, to & number of learned Brāhmanas of various sākhas, names, gõtras and sūtras, with privileges of free disposal, mortgage 
the request of Krishnabhūpa, whose genealogy is given as follows: In the Kāśyapa götra was born Nāga-Prithvīpati (=Nãgama-Nayaka). To him was born king Visyanátha, who, llaving conquered in battle the Tiruyadi, the great Pandya, the Vānāda-raya and other kings, and having annexed their territories, became the master of the kingdom of Madhurā. To bunn was born the prince Krishna who acquired the 'overlordship of the south' (Dakshina-Nayaka tuam); Krishna's wife was Lakshmyambikā To these was born Vira-Bhüpati. He built in front of the shrine of Saandara-Nayakat a mandapa having pillars of rare workmanship, he also presented the goddess Minākshit with a karacha (body cover) made of gold and set with rare gems. He made the sixteen mahadanas, beginning with muēn-āśva His queen was Tirumalāmbikā. Their son was Krishna-Mahīpati He gave to the god Ranga-patis a kavacha studded with precious stones, a similarly bejewelled usinīsha, yellow silk garments, necklaces, kirita (crown), Hundalas (ear-rings), kati-sütra (waist zones), and presented him farther with villages and gardens, and made arrangements for the celebration of rath-otsavas (car-festivals) and the daily services. Ho set up a number of lights in the presence of the god Saundara-Nayaka; made arrangements for bathing the image of the god in milk and for the car-festival; gayo ornaments (?); and set up a large man-stambha. He performed the ceremony of weighing himself against gold and the mahādānas of hēmagarbha, $147-dhēnu, (sapt]-ambudlır and kalpa-säkhin. His praises ; he founded agrahārās for Brahmanas and protected them , he paid to Brāhmaṇas enough money to enable them thereby to redeem their lands situated in the countries of other kings, which were mortgaged for tho purposes of paying taxes, the Pandya, the Chéra and the Chola kings served him as his mūgadhas. He possessed the berudas 'dakshina-samudr-éśa' and 'the taker of the kingdoms of the Paöcha-Tiruvadis." 
The villages granted were situated in the Tiruvadi-dēša, in the Mulli-nādu sub-division of Añjarakkare, and they belonged to the eastern portion of Kallaņaikkurichi. The boundaries were - 
on the south-east, the tank called Kailasanatha-tataka on the boundary of Virava-pallur : on the north, the boundary stone of Attala-nallür; on the east, Kottālakurichi, the channel of the village of Kottālakarchi, the high 
road called Sankar donahāpatha on the boundary of Aricha-nallür, and the way 
leading to Virava-nallür; on the south, the boundary stone of Kurungudi, the watercourse of that village called 
Pädaryoda, the Kannadiyankal-arăcche (channel), the boondary stone of Kallane kurchi, the eastern ridge of the sixth kannāru (froni the Tānra parni evidently) 
and boundary stone of the seventh kannāru flowing into Tadichéri; and on the west, the river Tämreparni, flowing northwards, and the channel of Pon 
nadikulyā, of the village of Tadchêr. The stone on the boundary of the eighth kannāru of this Tadchéri village, the mound lluppayadı-ttidar, and the garden: called Kudureyodi. 
This is the name of the presiding deity, Siva, of the famous temple at Madura. 2 This is the name of the goddess of the same tempie. * This is the name of the god Visbnu of the largest temple at Srilangam in S. India. * See above-P. 307, foot-note 2.

(Vy 99-100.) The total number of crittrs (shares) was two hundred and sixty-one; and each share was divided into five ansas (parts), so that eacbarittu might suffice for the maintenance of five persons. The following is a list of the names of the donees.

[Śrīvatsa]. 
979 
(LI. 552-4.) The passage here is somewhat obscure. It seems to state that the charitable acts performed by Krishna [II] were equal to those done by Visvanātha, Virabhüpa and Periya Nainār Mudalı put together. I 
(LI 555-9.) This order of the king Venkatapati-Raya was the composition of Krishnakayi Kamakõtı, the grandson of Sabhāpati, and the engraving was executed by Virana-mahāchārya, son of Ganapaya, under orders of Venkata-mahārāya. 
(L1, 559-567.) The usual exhortatory and admonitory verses. (1. 568.) The sign-manual “ Śri-Venkatëća” in Telugu-Kannada characters. 
OY 
201 
No. 24.--HULGUR INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGN OF VIKRAMADITYA VI : 
SAKA 999. 
BY LIONEL D. BARNETT 
Hulgür, aaciently named Hullumgür, is a village in the Baikāpür Division of Dharwar District, and is situate in lat. 15° 5' and long. 75o 191, some eight miles to the north-east from Shiggaon It contains several inscriptions ; among them is the present record, which was found on a stone standing against, or fixed in, the wall on the south side of the local temple of Siddba. linga. An ink-impression of it was made for the late Dr Fleet, who bequeathed it with others to the British Museum From it I now edit the text. The stone is surmounted by a rounded top, on which are sculptures : in the centre is a linga, and to the proper right of this are a cow and a calf, there were some other figures also, but they are now worn away Below this is an inscribed area 2 ft. 7 in high and l ft 4 in. wide The character is Kanarese, of a some 
. 
? [Excluding the (former) grants made to gods, Brāhmans and mathas by Visvanatba, Virabhūpa and Periya Nainār Mudali, the rest now grantod by Krishna was to be enjoyed by the Brühmans mentioned, as an judu kual unt.Ed.] 
330 
EPIGRAPHIÁ INDICA. 
[ VOL. XVI. 
H.. 
. 
- 
.... 
. 
. 
. 
. . 
. 
. 
- 
- 
- 
- 
- 
- 
- 
- 
-- 
- 
- 
- 
- 
---- 
-- 
- 
- 
- 
...... 
. 
.. 
. 
.... 
OL 
2 
what crabbed and angalar type of the period ; the letters are from in. to in. high. The language is Old Kangrese, except for three formal Sanskrit verses The archaic is replaced by r in hdr-ggarundu (1. 14) and parttiya (1.21 : see Kittel, 8.v. palta); elsewhere it has be come l. Initial p is retained. The upadhmānīya appears in bhāginah=po (1. 31). The words talaböyi (1 17), -kharattige (1. 19), partta (1 21 ; the later patti, hatti), mulave (1 21), Koylāti 
(1. 22), and puttavalu (1. 25) are of some lexical interest. 
The record refers itself in ll 2-6 to the reign of Tribhuvanamalla [Vikramāditya VI), and thon in 11. 6-11 introduces as regent of the Belvala Three-hundred and Puligere Three hundred the prince Trailokyamalla Nolamba-Pallava Permā di Jayasingha, of the Pallava lineage, ie Vikramaditya's younger brother Jayasimha III, on whom see Dyn, Kanar. Distr., p. 453. We are further informed in ll. 11-14 that the nãl-gauunda was the Mahasamanta Jaya - kēsiyarasa, of the Manaleyara lindage, whose device was a lion and who bore the title “ lord of Puligere best of cities." This family appears also above, Vol. VI, p 52, and Ann Report 
Iysur birch Dept., 1908-9, p 16. Then follow, after the date, the specifications of endowments greated by some fiscal officers and others to a local Saiva temple, under the trusteeship of Isänasingi Jiyar (1l 14 ff). 
The date is given on 11. 14-16 as : Saka 999 expired, the cyclic year Pingala ; Āshādha su. 2; Sunday ; a samkranti. This is quite regular The tithi mentioned corresponded to Sunday, 25 June, A.D. 1077 ; it was current at sunrise of that day, and ended about 3 h. 37 m. after mean sunrise (for Ujjain). On the same day, about 13 h 16 m after mean sunrise, occurred the Karka-sankianti, the following Monday being reckoned as the first day of Karka. 
The only places mentioned are the two Three-hundreds of Belvala and Puligere (19) and the town of Puligere (1 12), on which see above, Vol. XIII, pp 178, 328

No. 25 -HULGUR INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGNS OF JAYASIMHA II (SAKA 960) 
AND THE YADAVA KANHARA. 
BY LIONEL D, BARNETT. 
The site of Hulgür has been discussed by me above, p. 329, in treating of the inscrip tion of Saka 999. From the second part of the present record, 1. 32, we learn further that it was a Bananju-vattanas or market-town of the Banañjus or Vira-Valañjiyas, an important corporation of traders whose centre was at Aiyāvole (the modern Arhole), the seat of toeir Five-hundred Svāmis, and whose organisation seems to have spread over the greater part of Southern India They claimed to have originally come from Ahichchhatra, and some 
one of regal pomposzty. The present inscription was found at the temple of Kalameśvara in Hulgār, and an ink-impression, from which the text is now edited, was prepared for the late Dr. Fleet and bequeathed by himn with others to the British 
I See above, Vol XIII, p. 313 n. 
? See Ind. Ant., Vol. 38, p. 52. $ The name Koyläla seems to be derived from the Tamil Köyıl-ala, "uling in the temple ", and the Koylalis mentioned in the next paragraph must be the temple-women 
4 See Ind Ant , Vol 30, pp. 107, 267, Ep. Carn X 1 (Kolar), MB 172 f., 259, CB 9, Bg. 71, Ct. 1, 14; Kisanwar Glossary, p 92. 
Definitions of the term pattaną are given in the Kamikāgama XX. 8 f. and Yugādı-defanā v, 50; see also my translation of the Antagada-dasão, p. 45 
On these see Mysore Inscr, pp. 73, 120, 123, Epigr Carn, VII, 1., Sk 94, 118-19; Madras Epign, Report, 1905.06, PP. 11, 17, 1912-13, pp. 99-102, 1914-15, P. 102; above, Vol. XIII, pp. 21, 26. 
No. 25.1. 
HULGUR INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGNS OF JAYASIJHA II, ETC. 333 
Museum. The stone is broken at the top, on the proper right, so that a considerable part of the text of 11. 1-7 is lost; otherwise it is in fairly good condition. Of the inscribed area the maximum height is 2 ft. 91 in., its width being 2 ft. 4, n. It contains two distinct records, The first of these, dated Saka 960, and covering 11. 1-26, is in a fair sloping Kanarese script of the period, with letters varying from in, to 10. The cursive m (above, Vol. XII, p. 335) occus here only once, in mūnürum, 1. 7; the other cursives are not found. The second recorl. comprised in 11. 27-35, belongs to A.D. 1255, and is in the somewhat crabbed upright rounded Kanarese hand typical of that period, it shews a free use of all the cursives, un appearing in that form 10 times, y 4 times, and v9 times, and it marks the aspiration in dh and ph by writing a and p with a curl underneath them very like a subscript t -The language of the first recor.l. which (so far as it is preserved) is entirely in prose, is Old Kanarese. It changes ? tor in ërpattarn (I. 15). The second record contains four introductory verses and one final rerse in Sanskrit; the rest is in Kanarese prose, of the medieval dialect. We may note the spelling for a (1, 31), initial h for p (hamriruvaru, 1. 32), mixture of l and n (Tūralīsiyalz, 1 3). beside Võranāsiyalu, I. 34), and l from original ? (allo, II, 34, 35). The word dana-bala (1, 33) is of some lexical interest; it seems to mean literally " cattle-section" (of land, of above, Vol. XIII, p. 179 and n.). 
The first record, so far as it is preserved, begins with the statement that at the time of the donation the Three-hundreds of Belyala and Purigere were under the administration of the General Vayanarasa, an officer of Jagadekamalla (Jayasimha II), who among many other titles is described as “a comet (portending woe) to the Konkan” (11. 1-8). Then Fre are told that there was a nal-garunda or county-sheriff of the Purgere Three-hundred, the Mahásāmanta Irivabe langa Mārasinga-dēva,l of the Minala or Manalēra famıly, who among his many other 
a that of " lord of Purigere best of cities" (Il. 8-12). Then is introduced, in anacoluthic style, a certain Nidugundara Būta Gāyunda (11. 12-13), and after this asome what obscure episode of previous history is narrated (11. 13-16), to the effect that after king Satyasraya had gone away after taking possession of the Bennegere Seventy: there was 7 lack of roast meal for the festival shows of Nidugunda (no doubt in consequence of the t'e quisitions made by the royal army), and accordingly the above-mentioned lõraxiaga-dora and 
e need. It seems that this event took place when D[ārasinga-dera was serving as nãl-gāvunda of Purigere, some years previous to the present record, Rererting now to contemporary history, our record details its present business (11, 16-26), stating that the nai-garunda of the Purigere Three-hundred is now Jayakėsı, also of the Manalēra famıly. entitled ( lord of Purigere best of cities" and bearing the device of a lion, and that in the Saka year 960 the above-mentioned Būta Gāvunda obtained from him some land and granted it to a temple. 
The second record opens with four Sanskrit verses (11, 27-29), of which nos. 1 and 2 are devotional and nos. 3 and 4 complimentary addresses to the protagonist, the High Blinister Tippa or Tipparasa. The following prose (1, 29-33) reports a donation by Tipparasa and (his wife ?) Goņa-madēvi in the 9th year of the reign of the Yādave Kanhara. Concluding formulæ of the usual type follow. 
I Cf. Dynast. Kanar. Destr., p. 437 % On this family cf. the Halgür record af Sakı 999, abovo. 
& The exact force of the phrase friman- Näyıbbarasıyar besase, on the command of Navibomasi," iz not quite clear. If, as seems probable, it qualifies the inmediately following clause, it would :ppear that Nayabbare-i WAS dowager queen holding a position very like that of Akkā dēvi in the next generation. 
* See Dynast. Kanar. Distr., p. 520 and n. 4.

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL. XVI. 
The date of the first record is specified on 11. 24-25 as : Saka 960, Bahudhānya; the uttarāyana-samkrāntı ; Sunday; the day of new-moon. This is not quite regular, The Makara samkrānti for the given year occurred on Sunday, 24 December, A.D. 1038, at 4 h. 28 m. after mean sunrise. But tbat day, according to the Sürya-siddhānta, corresponded to the tithi Pausha krishna 10, which ended about 2 h. 7 m, after mean sunrise, and not to the full. moon, Practically the same result is obtained if we reckon by the Arya-siddhānta : by the former the tithi-index at mean sunrise was 8301, by the latter 8295, so that the difference is negligible 1 
The date of the second record is given on 11. 30-31 as, the 9th year of the reign of the Yādava Kahnara (Kanhara), Ananda, the full-moon of Phálguna; Monday; the yoga Vyatipāta. a samkranti. This is fairly regular. The tathi corresponded to Monday, 22 February A.D. 1255, ending about 21 h. 54 m, after mean sunrise. The Mina-samkrānti, according to the Arya-siddhānta, took place 7 h. 50 m. after mean sunrise on the following day. vir Tuesday, 23 February, only about 10 hours after the moment of full-moon. 
The geographical names that occur are the Konken (1. 5); the Belvala Three. hundred (1.6); the Purigero Three-hundred (11. 6, 11 f., 23 f.), Purigere city (u. 9, 17): the Bennegere Seventy (1. 15); Niųugunda (1. 15 f.), Hulungūr (1. 32); and Benares (1. 33 f.). Purigere town is the modern Lakshměshwar (see above, Vol. XIII, p. 179, XIV. p. 188), Bennegere seems to be Bengeri ("Bhingerree " of the Indian Atlas sheet 41 of 1852), situate in lat. 15° 21' and long. 75° 12', about 13 miles north of New Hubli. Nidugunda is perhaps Nidgundi, in lat. 14° 56' and long. 75° 143', nearly 4 miles S.S.W. from Shiggaon, Huluñgür is the modern Hulgār,

adorned by a terrible scimitar, a sun of battles, an ornament of the Jonas' Church, conversing with refinement, wishing-gem to dependents, crest-gem of bold warriors, athlete against furious elephants, friend to the needy, a Vatsa-king with horses, a celestial tree to Brahinans & Rādha's son Karna) in truthfulness, a Vinata's son (Garuda] among kings, an ocean to seekers of bis protection, an ocean of gems of virtues, a Love-god to lovely women, a Bhīma of the Mañalas & cuffer of hostile nobles, a destroyer of foes," Jayakēsi, was holding the office of countr-shezit for the Purigere Three-hundred 
(Lines 24-26 ) At the uttarayana-samkrānti, on Sunday, the day of new-moon, in the cyolic year Bahudhânya, the 960th year) of the Saka era, Nidugundara Būta Gāyunda granted to the god Nārāyana two matta, according to the rood, which he had obtained from 
Jayakēsiyarasa on sarva-namasyu tenure, at the side of the field of the rest-house 
(Verse 1.) Homage to Sambhu lovely with the yak-tail fan that is the poor kissing his lofty head, the foundation-column for the construction of the city of the threefold world. 
(Verse 2) Homage to him who stills all obstacles, who casts out the serpent of pride, who brings prosperous ending, who reveals himself in native radiance. 
(Verse 3.) Good fortune be thine as long as moon and stars endure, O great Minister Tippa by contact with whose fame Sarasvati shines in perfect whiteness, 
(Verse 4 ) Coming under the shadow of whose parasol, the excellent Lady who bestoweth all [Fortune] shall with speed bring hither complete prosperity of life 
(Lines 29-33 ) On Monday, the full-moon day of Phålguna in the cyclic year Ānanda, the oth of the years of the rise of the victorious reign of king Kahnara, the Nārāyans of the Yadayas, the Emperor strong of arm (and) splendid of majesty, during the Vyatipáta. (yoga), in a conjunction, the High Minister Tipparasa, who possesses all titles of honour, and Gona-madēvi, that perfect Goddess of Fortune, granted to the twelve Sheriffs of Hulungūr, the immemorial town of the Baņañjus,3 to the whole population, the merchants, and the onummuri-dandas" a cattle-pound (?) for that place on sarva-namasya tenure. 
(Lines 33-35 : a Kanarese prose formula of the usual type.) (Verse 5 : a common Sanskrit commonitory verse.)

No. 26.-TILVALLI INSCRIPTION OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA I. 
BY LIONEL D. BARNETT. 
Tilvalli is a village in the Kod taluka of Dhärwär district, situated 'in about lat, 140 371' and long, 75° 17'. The name is spelt in the Indian Atlas sheet 42 as “Teelowly," and in the Bombay Survey sheet 310 as “Tilvallı " The present "record was transcribed for the Elliot Collection, Vol. I, fol. 75a. of the Royal Asiatic Society's copy. The copyist there states that it was found in the temple of Sankoji Basappa in front of the Turchi Math; but & note Which I have found among the papers of the late Dr. Fleet reports that in his time it was on a Blab standing in the temple of Virabhadra near the Charchi Math. An ink-impression of it was made for Dr. Fleet, and bequeathed by him to the British Museum, The slab is a mere fragment : besides a strip along the left-hand side, the whole of the latter part is missing. What remains is 2 ft. 51 in. broad, and 2 ft. 3 in. high. It is surmounted by some sculptures, namely, a linga on stand in the centre, with officiant priest by the side; to the proper rigat 
1 800 above, Vol. V, p. 236, Vol XIII, p. 313 n 
* The adjective gunavati seems chosen for the sake of a play upon the name of Goņe-midēvi (11. 31-82), who would seem to be tho wife of Tippa. 
* See above, p. 332 
* A class of oticials. 100 above, Vol. XI). p. 26 
KA 
838 
(VOL. XVI. 
. 
18 
of this, a COW with calf ; to the left of it, a bull, above it, the sun; to the proper left, the moon. The charaoter is fair Kanarese of the period, angular and slanting, with letters varying 
in height from in. toin. The cursive m above, Vol. XII, p. 335) occurs in rajyam (1,5), agamane (1. 6), and frima[t*]- (1. 7).-The language is „Old Kanarese. The ? is preserved, scil. in negald-ilda (l. 19). The 7 is doubled before y in kallyān- (1. 6); cf. Panini, VIII iv. 47, and Siddhānta-kaumudi, 48; and the upadhmānīya appears in -amtahpura- (1,7). We may note the instrument -sriye in Il. 1-2, on which of, above, Vol. XIV, p.127, n. 9. The words Köpekara and arthana (1. 12) are of some lexical interest. The first of these occurs in an 
inscription of Kolar, in the phrase vaddaşrāvulada khenzkāra ; so it denotes some fiscal officer, and atthana may be from Skt. ästhāna. 
The record opens (11. 1-2) with a kanda verse which may be thus rendered :--- By For tane's, blessed benediction (is won) the realm of bliss of glory (and) of bliss of victory ; in the primal sunnit by Fortune's blessed benediction may Abhava [Siva], (who is) the realm of bliss of glory (and) of bliss of victory, be won." Then, after an ungrammatical salutation to Siva 
(1, 2), it refers itself to the reign of Irailokyamalla [Somośvara I) (11. 3-6), and announces that at the time his senior queen Mailala-dēvi was administering the Banavāsı Twelve-thousand (11. 6-9). Next it proceeds to give the names and titles of certain high fiscal officers who apparently made an endowment for the cult of Siva (11. 9ff.), and breaks off before giving the details of their arrangements. These officers are the high minister and vadda-rāvulada pergade Söyanāthayya, by whose instructions the endowment was made; Nāgavarmayya, śivanā gayya, and Singayya, the presidents of the kënžkāras of the atthāru-antaras (Privy Courts ?) of . . . ppatür and Pānungal; and the high minister and perjurkada pergade Chattimayya or Chatta. 
The date is not certain. It depends upon the authority of Elliot's copyist, who read a few fragmentary words after the portion attested by the ink-impression, among them the word 975neya (see below). If we accept this statement, we must assign the record to Saka 975; this year, if taken as carrent, corresponded to A.D. 1052-53, and, if lapsed, to A.D. 1053-54. 
The only places mentioned are the Banevāsi Twelve-thousand (1.8), . . ppatür (1. 12), the Five-hundred of Pānungal, i.e. Hāngal (1. 12), and Tıļıvaļļi (1, 20).

No 27 -A SECOND PLATE OF BHASKARA RAVIVARMAN FOCND AT 
TIRUNELLI. Bi LA CAMMIADC, B.A, BL, BAR -AT-LAW, AND THE LATE T. A. GOPINATHA RAO, J.A. 
The copper-plate, the inscription on which is edited below, as discoverell years ago b, ult of us at Tirunelli, and from the inpressions then taken we edit the recoiti below, 
The copper-plate measures 81" by 23", is engraved on both sides, and contains a complete document Very near the left margin of the plate is a ring-hole, but, when the plate me to us for examnation, there was 10 ring strung to it. The preservation of the 11 ( 1PTIOIL is good. The alphabet employed in the record is Vatteluttu of about the tenth or eleventh century AD. A few Sanskrit words and letters which occur in the record are written in the Grantha characters, e.g. Svustz Sri occurring in l. 1, sapta in pañcllumcīdiptu in 2 13. $'$ 2 
Vâsulēva in / 15, Sri and sina in Srivarshnava in l. 19, and go-prahmanitno svastion! At the end of the inscription occurs ôm naino Narayanaya pumuh written in tba Vāgari islphabet of the type employed in the Mahabalipuram and the onetsimini insonpan of

EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[VOL XVI. 
the early Pallava kings.2 The language of the record is Tamı). The words pandiradi (17. 4 and 10), ari (1. 11), para iññu (1. 19 f.), vaichchu (z. 20), vaippichchu (1. 21), Kuññio (1l. 21 and 26), marinala (1. 22), etc. may be cited as instances of Malayalam words and therefore the language of the document might be called Malayalam; but against this contention it may be stated that these words are pure Tamil, with here and there a slight change in the pronunciation, an alteration which is also common to the Tamil language and is, therefore, no special feature of Malayalan. It is from about the period of this record that we begin to meet with the slight changes in the Tamil language which go to make its ancient dialect pass for the supposed separate language, VIZ, Malayalam For example, the retention of the words which have become obsolete in the spoken Tamil language, the abolition of the gender suffixes at a comparatively l'ecent period and a few 
duce an impression of ditference between the two languages, Tamil und Malayālam. It is, however, easy to establish the identity of the two languages in so far as the vocabulary and the grammar are concerned; a rough and ready proof of their identity is offered by the fact that a man from the Tamil country is able to make himself understood by the Malayali and vice versa, which is however not possible between the Tamil and the Telugu and the Malayālı and the Telugu. One peculiarity of the present document worth coticing is that it omits in many cases the final m in the conjunctive particle umi 6.g. in üru (1. 7), "Kuññiyu (. 23 f.), Ayyanu (I. 23), etc. The final m in such words as muttikkum (I. 20) is also omitted. 
The most important feature of this inscription of king Bhāskara Raviyarman is the mention of a complete set of astronomical details necessary for the determination of the age of the king. The grant recorded in the document was made in the sixth year opposite to the thirty-fifth, which was opposite the second year, that is, the forty-third year of the reign of the king. In this year, at the time when the grant was made, Jupiter stood 
sun in the Mina-rasi, the date of the solar month being the eighth expired, the day a Wednesday and the nakshatra Uttara-Phalguni. Regarding this date the Hon. Dewan Bahadur L. D. Swamikannu Pillai writes as follows: 
“I took the period from A.D. 949 to 1329 (380 years) and found only one year in which the 9th Mina was a Wednesday, when Jupiter was in Tula and the moon in Uttara-Phalgoni (ettu-benra is, I believe, 9th and not the 8th). 
“The year in question is A.D. 1020-21, when 9th Mina was Wednesday, 1st March 1021 AD., on which day Jupiter was in Tulá (longitude about 1869=Tula), and the moon 
csbatra Uttara-Phalguni, whose ending moment was 571 ghatīkās after mean sugrise. 
“In A.D. 1115-16, the next most likely year, the 8th Mina was Monday, 29th February A.D. 1116, and the 9th Mina was Tuesday, 1st March A.D. 1116. I do not find any other year in the period of four centuries examined (AD. 950 to 1350) when the 8th or 9th Vina was # Wednesday and when Jupiter stood in the Talā-rasi and the moon in the nakshatra Uttara Phalgani. 
"For the present we may rest satisfied that your Tiranelli grant was dated on Wednesday, 1st March A.D. 1021, and that Bhāskara Ravivarman who made a grant to the Jew, Rabbi Joseph (Cochin Plates, Ind. Ant., Vol. XX), began to reign somewhere about A.D. 984. 
[The letters in the Tirunelli Plate are abnormally box-headed. Excepting in the case of no, I do not see Mby resemblance but woun these and the Pallava Nagari charr.ciers of Salavenkuppam Deal Mababalipuram (Ep. Itd., Vol. X, Plate opp: P. 14).- Ki.) 
No. 27.] 
A SECOND PLATE OF BHASKARA RAVIVARMAN. 
. Dates when, Jupiter being in the Tula-räsi, the moon was in Uttara-Phalguzi and the gun in the Mina-rāśi and the day of the month 8th or 9th of Mina, a Wednesday, could occur only once in 95 years, e.g. A.D. 1020-21, 1115-16, 1210-11 and 1305-06, but only A.D. 1020-21 satisfies all the conditions." 
In the collection of Travancore inscriptions there are some belonging to the reign of Bhãakara Ravivarman which contain more or less astronomical details which enable as nors to Verify the date deduced from the Tirunellı plate under notice. The date portions of these are extracted below in chronological order, togather with the notes kundly supplied to as by Mr. Swamikannu Pillai.

Ko-pPakkaran-Iravivarmmar Tiruvadikku-chchellänınra aran-andark-edir. ēlam-andu Idabattul Vryalan-ninta Tula-nayırt ... “In the seventh year which was current and which was opposite to the sixth (of the reign) of the king Pakkaran-Iravivarmmar Tiruvadi, when Jupiter stood in the Rishabha-rasi and the sun in the Tula-rāśi." 
"No 89 of 1086 M. E. of the Travancore Collection 13th year. Jupiter in Risbabba and Tulă month. Of the years A.D 990, 991 and 992, which correspond to the 13th, 11th and 15th years in this series, only A.D. 992, Tulă month, answers the description "Jupiter ID Rishabha', and I suspect that irandām-ändarkk-edir', which is present in all the other Bhaskara Ravivarman dates, has been left out in this case and that the regnal Fear is really the 15th common L D , S.

“No. 102 of 1084 (of the Travancore collection) 23rd year Jupiter in Makara, Trischase month-8th day (he senza). A D. 1007 (Oct.-Nov.). 
"N.B.--Had the week-day or the nakshatra been giren, tihe year could lave been verified with certainty." mm LD.S.

"In the thirty-sixibl year (carrert) opposite the second of (the reign of) the king Pækkaran-Iravivarma, who possessed the quality of diseaselessness, when Jupiter stood in Idaba (rishabha-rasz) and at the end of the (solar month) Idabaru(rishabha). 
"No. 84 of 1086 (of the Travancore collection) 38th year. Jupiter in Rishabba, Rishabha month April-May 
56 N B.-It follows from the date of the Tirunelli inscription under notice and II gived above that the reign must hate commenced in or before October and after April in other words that the regnal years changed numbers in this internal, so that, of April 2016 was at the end of the 38th voar and March 1021 was at the end of the 43rd year, October 1021 nay have been in the beginning of the 44th year, and, dedacting 21 from either side, we hare October 1000 A.D. beginning of the 23rd year."

From the various dates noticed above it 18 nov quite certain that the reign of Bhāskara Ravivarman began, as already stated, some time after October A.D. 984. 
The inscription records that Kunjikkutta-varman alias Adigal Vira-Kurumburaiyar Tiruvadi, who was governing the Mütta-kūru of the Kurumburai nādu, granted a piece of land known as Kilkāttiy-pPõlachchêrıkkal (2.c. the chérıkkal, or mountainous tract, Põlachchériykkäl of Kilkkādu), for a rice-offering at the pandiradi time of the day and for & perpetual lamp to be burot before the god of the temple at Tirunell. This charity was placed uuder the management of the members of the family of the donor, haps residing in or near the temple) and the Srivaishnavas; the community or assembly kaown as the 'seven hundred of the Mütta-käru, the villagers and the Vellalas who are the major land-lords of the village-all these, without entertaining among themselves any difference of opinion on the matter of this chailty, were obliged to arrange for the supply of the rice for the offering and for the burning of the perpetual lamp. Kuñjikkutta-varman also gave to the temple a silver pot, a silver parāgar, and a silver sword, and a pearl neck-lace to the god of the temple at Tirunelli. 
There are a fety words occurring in the document which are still current in the Malayalam language and which require a few words of explauation. The word pandiradi is a technical term commonly employed for the service which is conducted at a time when the sun standa at such a height in the sky as to cast the shadow of a man which measures twelve feet reckoned by his own font. Assuming the height of a man to be about seven feet measured by his own foot,l the time when the sbadow measures twelve feet would be about eight o'clock in the morning Mutta-kūru occurring in li. 5 and 26 may mean either the portion of the country roled over by the elder branch of the family to which Kanjikkutta-varman belonged or the larger of the two sections into which the Kurumburai nadu was divided and one of which was governed by the members of the family to which the donor belonged, while the other was goveri.ed by some other person. Again elinārruvar, occurring in 7.7, is employed here evidently to denote & community consisting of seven hundred members ; this term may be compared with advantage with the müvāyrravar of Tiruchchenganrür, occurring in the Nālāyrra-prabandhum, the não patt-ennäyrravara of Kanyakumari, the munnurtuvar of Nazrulai nādu+ occurring in some of the inscriptions of Tiruvanvandūr, etc. It will become patent from the references given above that the phrase nütta-kürril elunürruvar cannot mean the seven hundred members of the elder branch of the family governing the Kurambarai nādu, but that it refers to a community of men living in the Mütta-kõru of the said nādt. Idavagai is another word employed in a particular sense in Malayalam and means the property belonging to an important personage or a very rich landlord; for example, we hear of the Piññārru idavaga, the estate belonging to the Paññārru Rāja, or Chief, in Travancore. Nammālvár, the great Vaishnava saint, also uses this term in the same sense. Nirāttu-paļli is

used to mean the bathing of the image of the god with water or the place where such a bath takes place. The words padi-pada-mülatrāt, prakritiyar, adrgāru, etc. occur in several other documents and have been explained by those who have edited those inscriptions 
The names of places that occur in the record are Tirunelli, Kurumbural nadu and Kilkkāttiy-pPõlachcbērıkkāl. Of these, the first two are the names of a town and of a district respectively in the Wydad and the third is the name of a plot of land, which is not possible to be identified

Lines 1-3. Hail Prosperity ! In the sixth year opposite to the thirty-fifth year, which was opposite to tbe second year that was current in the reign of the glorious king Bhaskara Bavivarman Tiruvadi,vben Jupiter was standing in the Tula (rāśi), on the expiry of the eighth day in the solar) month Mina, on the day of the ascendency of Budha (Wednesday). in the rakshatra Uttiram, the following was the business that was transacted in the temple of Tirunelli 
LI. 4-7. Kufijikuttavarman alias Adigal Vira-kKurumburaiyar Tiruvadi, governing the Mütta-kira (larger division of the Kurumburai madu), was pleased to make a gift by the pouring (of water) to the god at Tirunelli (of the land known as ?) Polachcherikkal in Kilkkādu for the upkeep of the daily offering of three times foar nälıs? of rice (to be offered) when the sun stood at an altitude at which the shadow of a man is twelve feet (as measured by his owo feet) and for (burning) a perpetual lamp. 
LI. 7-11. The community of) the seven hundred (residing) in the Mitta-kūru (larger division of the Kurumbagai nadu) and the Nāyag who bas service (rights in the Tirunelli temple), the townsmen and the Vellalas who hold estates in Tirunelli), the inhabitants who are ..... to the larger division of the Kurumburai nadu, the estate holders in it and the Prakriti,all these, having unanimously agreed among themselves. granted by the pouring of

Ll. 11-13. Out of the three times four mals of rice, six nālis, (that is) one half, should be utilised for feeding Brāhmaṇas; the (remaiving) half should be taken by the drau mers who sound the five great (musical) instruments at the time of bathing (the image of the god).

May the cows and Brāhmanas probper: be it well. 
LI. 26-29. Kuññikuttavarman alias Vira-Kurumburaiyar, the governor of the Larger division of the Kurumburaiyi nadu, gave a silver pot, a silver sword ), a Hag (?), & pecklace of pearla (made of) eight hundred and seventy-eight pearls, which is to be taken out daily and used to adorn the image ....

No. 28.-SRIRANGAM PLATES OF MALLIKARJUNA SAKA-SAMVAT 1384. 
BY THE LATE T. A. GOPINATHA RAO, MA, TRIVANDRUM. The inscription edited below is engraved upon a set of three copper-plates (size 9f in. high, 6 in, broad), of which the first and the last have writing on one side only, namely the 
The word agattu used with pandiradi is the tadbhava forn in Tamil of the Sanakrit alor or alatt, a day The phrase agattu pandirad: literally means 'when the day was (at) twelve feat." The word agattu is found also in the compound attālam, which is a corruption of agatta amagattu * täla,' when the day was down,' that is Biber sunset. The Malayalan language has created the word muttalan, meaning the early morning, in opposi tion to attālam, which is as meaningless as the introduction of an l in the English word could, which is formed in imitation of the word should. (Agattu in agattu-pandiradi cannot be considered to be a tadbhara of the Sanskrit werd abar : agattu means “ within or before." The full expressinn of which "agattu-pandimada is a shortened form is " uchchi agattu pandiradt, which means "twelve feet (time) botaro (the son gets to) zenith “ und this term is opposed to “uphobi tiriayu pandiradı ", meaning "twelve feet (time) after wenith.” A given shadow lengtia will occur twice daily, oncs before the sun reaches the zenith and once after it. Thus, agattz-pandiradı - 8 A.M. and its antonym teringi pandiradi=3-47 P.M. I may note that * agattu-irubattaiyaợr " and " uccis firit ja irribattayadı" occur in an inscription of Mülikkaļam in the Travancore State.-K. V. S.) 
*[Munnanäliyāl arunāli means "six nau (as measured by) the tunnānált " and not "three times foar hali", 46 has been rendered. Munnāna bt might, however, mean " three times four nā Iz , and in this cas "$ muunīnā uyal runā! " would be equivalent to seventy-two nált.--K. V.S.] 
* FThis must be altered into" Tirupārāyanaz . . . . of Tirabell."-K.V.S.) 
* [Talavara in Kanarese means a village watchmar, Perlepa Tirunellittälvariyan here donate 410 Watchman of Tirunelli.-H. ) 
EPIGRAPHIA INDICA.. 
[VOL. XVI. 
second side of the first and the first side of the third, or last, plate, and the plates are numbered 1, 2, and 3 on their written sides, the number 2 being marked on the first side of the second plate The wiiting is very well preserved. The inscription is in Nandi-nägarī characters. and the language is partly Sanskrit and partly Kannada, the Kannada portion occupies only a few lines at the end, that is, Il. 08-73. The chief peculiarity of this document is that the vzsarga is omitted in a very large number of instances where it is required and, as in all grants, the anısrarı serves as a substitute for the varga-panchamas. 
The grant was made by Mallıkārjuna, who is also called Immadı Deva-Rays and Inmadı Praudha-bhüpatı' in the record. His genealogy is given as follows 
Sangana 
Bukka-Raya 
Hazıhara (II 
Déva-Räya (I 
Vijaya-Raya 
Déva-Raya (II) 
Mallikärjuna alios Immadı Deva-Rāya. In the Sake year 1384, expressed by bhū=l, gund3, ashta=8 and vēda=4, which correc sponded to the cyclic year Chitrabhānu, on the full moon tithi of the bright half of the month Vaisakhay at the sacred moment of a vyatipi ta, the king Mallikarjuna alias Immadı Déva Raya or Imnadi Praudha-bhõpati made the grant to the god Sri-Ranganātha of the village of Uttamanchēri-kiliyür, in the presence of the god Chandramauli, the object of the grant being that by its virtue it should secure for the king victory, long life and success in the conyuest of the four quarters. It was made at the request of Chammatı Somaya, who bore the brrudas Antembara-ganda and Manne-gajapati. From the income of the village the following items of expenditure had to be met for each paritāna daily, viz. --mice, 10 mūnakas, ghee, 3 mānukus; plantain fruits, 10, coconuts, 2; green gram, budupa; and fruits and vegetables 
At the above rate six (complete) dishes of food should be daily offered to the you together with a hundred and twenty apūpa cakes. A water-shed should be maintained perpe tually in front of the temple. Again, areca nuts, 50; betel leaves, 100; and chunāni, ghanasario (pachchan-karpuram), 10 panas in weight, hastüri (musk), 2 pants in weight, sandal, 6 palas, costing 5 panas; kurkuma (-hesara=saffron) and camphor (=puchchai-iarpuram), 5 panus in value; and hinzu-jalum (Tamil, Pant-nir-rose-water) with hastūrī (mixed in it), costing 3 panas; should le used for daily offerings to the god Ranganatha. Besides these arrangements were made for three grand feedings, one in the month of Phalguna and the other two in Dhands, the following articles were to be used on those occasions --'ice, 5 kharis green gram) I droni, ghee, 1 aduha, and fruits and vegetables 
Again. the king ordered that sixty Vaishnavas should be fed daily in the Ramanuja-kata, and the amount required for this item of expenditure was also to be derived from the village granted. The village Uttamachẽrı-Kițiyūr belonged, it is stated, to the Chinchițan-palli (a very corrupt form of Tiruchchirappalli) rājya

The last plate contains the statement that the deed was engraved by Virage, the son of Muddan-acharya, for whom one share was allotted, at the end are the usual admonitory and imprecatory verses and the sign-manual, Sri-Virupaksha, of ke king. 
The articles kastūrī, kur kuma, pachchar-karpuran and sandal form to this day rery im portant objects in the toilet of the image of Ranganatha The paste of kasturi is applied as a tilaka, or forehead-mark, every day to the image, and pachchan-karpüram, kruh 10 ree and sandal are applied to the body. The word hima-jala, or rose-water, is the literal translation of the Tamil word pani-rr (which is the same as the vulgar pannir), this article does not appear to be employed in the temple of Ranganātha at the present time The term arasara employed in the document needs a few words of explanation; in every temple there are three to six different times, beginning from the early morning and ending at midnight, during which pújūs dre per folined and offerings made, the pūjās are of different degrees of elaborateness, and the offerings are also of vallous kinds of preparations, such as rice, sugared rice, cakes, etc. Each of these clafferent times of püsã and offerings is called an avusilic in the Srirangam temple and, in imita tion thereof, in other Vaislinava temples also. I have not heard the term employed in Sira temples The king Mallıkārjuna had made by this grant arrangements for the performance uf one such pija every day with tho offerings evidently of pongal (a kind of cooked rice mixed with green gram, salt, ghec, cumin seeds and pepper) and dõśars (a kind of cake made of nice 
url black gran1 ground together with water, salt and cumin seeds) or appum (a sheet cake) and with vegetable oures Rimiruja-hūta is the name of buildings set apart for the accon Tuolation and hoarding of Srivaishnavas, and any Vaishnava town which lays claim to inport ale will generally have a Rūmna1224}\-hūta The inscription mentions the names of different mioasures, lich as khari, dronni, adhuhu or ath(?)aka, prasriti and hidupa, which are measures of rnlic contents, pana and pala are measures of weight. In the Tuchinopoly District al and 
Thee ale Inelusured in terms of the standard called ādan even to this day. 
The raptr in this instance in Chammatı Somaya, of whom no particulars are given in the inscription, nor am I able to find any from other sources. He may have been an officer administering the portion of the country surrounding Trichmopoly, there is a village called Sömarasainpiitta five miles to the west of Trichinopoly, which may possibly have been named after (hanımlata Somaya 
The following uapes of places occur in the inscription Chirichitāmpalli, Utt-machéri Kiliyür and Srirangam ; of these Chirichitāmpallı is a corrupt form of Tiruchchirapalli, Fhose modoin vulgar, furn is Trichinopoly; it is the head-quarters of the district of the same pame in the Madras Presidency Srirangam is three miles north of Trichinopoly and contains the famous 
It is temple of Ranganatha, which attracts daily hundreds of pilgrims from all parts of India the centre of Brīvaishnavism and was the head-quarters of the great Śrīvaishạnia achóryas, kroginning from Yâniuuärya, Clown to Manavāla-mámuni and others Uttamachēri is & village situated in the island of Srirangam and is at a distance of 8 miles due east of Srirangan

64 युष्यचाभिवृद्धये ॥ ३५॥*] दिसा च विजयार्थं च इम. 65 डिप्रौढभूपतिः । वैसा खे च सिते पक्षे पौर्णिमा 66 स्यो दिने तथा ॥ ३६॥*] व्यतीपातसमायुक्तपुण्य काले 67 विषेशत: । श्रीचंद्रमौळिदेवस्य सन्निधौ हर्ष 68 मानसः ।। ३७॥*] श्रीरंगनाथ देवस्य । चिरचिटांपलि(ल्लि) यचा 69 वडिगै सलुव उत्तमचेरिकिरियर ब ग्रामद चतु 70 सीमेय वीळगुळ निधि निक्षेप जल पाशा'ण अक्षि. 71 णि आगामि सिद्ध साध्यगळेब अष्टभोगतेज[:]खा. 72 म्य श्रीरंगद श्रीरंगनाथदेवरिगे समर्पिसि f[] 73 तैस्तेवागि मुखदि भोगिसुवदु ॥ 
Thard Plate · First Side. 74 त्वष्टा श्रीमुहाणाचार्यसूनु[:*] शासन 75 खकः । वीरण[*] सुगुणो धीमान्हत्तिमेकां समथुते ।। ३८॥*] खद 76 त्ताहि"गुणं पुण्यं परदत्तानुपालनं । परदत्तापहारण 77 सदत्तं निश्फलं भवेत् ॥ ३६॥*] स्वदत्ता परदत्तां वा यो हरेत वसं 78 धरा [*] षष्टिवर्षसहस्राणि वृष्टाया जायते क्रिमि[:*] [४०॥*] ऐसे 79 व भगिनी लोके सर्वेषामेव भूभुजा । न भोज्या न कर 80 ग्राधा विप्रदत्ता वसुंधरा ॥[४१॥*] दानपालनयोर्मध्ये दामाच्छ्यो 81 नुपालनं दानात्वर्गमवाप्रोति पालनादच्युतं पदं ।। ४२॥*] स[7] - 82 मान्योयं धर्मसेतुं"पाणां काले काले पालनोयो भवद्भिः*] 83 सर्वानेतान्भाविन[:*] पार्थिवेंद्रान्भूयो भूयो याचते रामचंद्राः] [॥४३॥*] 84 श्रीविरूपाक्ष 
ABSTRACT OF CONTENTS, Adoration to Gapādhipati. Verse 1. Adoration to the primeval Boar (incarnation of Vishnu). V. 2. Adoration to child Ganapati,17

Talai-viri-kadakkai-mālait-tani madal sadaiyir-chuqun-kulavi-ven-dingalirra kõttadu kuraiy-enr-enni-ppula Dadua-karattār-parri-pporpufar-inaitta nokka-malai mada-kkalifrig seyya malar-adı senni vaippan.
