EPIGRAPHIA INDICA. 
[Pon. XVI 
Wie 
3-4. In the race of Ysdu there was a good king pamed Sangama. He enabled the goddess of prosperity (Lakshmi) of the Karnața kingdom to wear the ear-ornament (tatanku) permanently (i e, did not allow her to remain without a lord reigning over it).1 
7.5. To this king was born the famous Bukka.Bāga, who destroyed his enemies with his sword. 
V.6. King Harihara was born to Bakka-Rāya; he made other kings bow down to his mandates. 
V 7. Dēva-Raya [1], who possessed a pair of arms which crusked the hostile kings, i was born to Harihara. 
V. 8. From him came Vijaya-BA post the abode of leaming. 
V. 9. Dēva-Raya [LI], wba appeared to be a copy of the King of Gods (Indra), was bom to Vijaya-Raya. 
Vv. 10-11. He was not only as skilled in the use of the bow as Arjana himself, but also possessed wealth to be counted by lakhs. His further praipe. 
V. 12. To Déva-Raya was born Mallikarjuna, who outshone his father in prowess, etc. and who was praised also as Immad Dēva-Raya. 
Vy. 13-15. His praises. 
Vv. 16-37. This king, Imma Praneha-Bhopati, the lover of charitable deeds, having taken his bath in the holy watex brought for that purpose, and wearing two silk cloths, garland: white akshatas, having come to the dharma-sthāna (place where charities are given) with a band of Brahmagas of good eharacter, in the year 1384 of the Balipahana Saka tera), which come sponded with the cyclio year Chitrabhānu, on the Paurpamägi tittade of the month Vašākha. on the auspicious occasion of a Vyatāpāta, made a gift of the village of Uttamachēri-Kilyūru or Uttamachêri-Kiļyūru in the Chirichiţampalli (Tiruchchirappalli) rājya or chavadı, with all the eight kinds of enjoyment such as guidhi, mikshapa, eto., and the request of Chammati Somaya, in the presence of the god Chandramauli, for the offerings, etc. of the god Ranca. nātha of Srirangam, to ensure himself (thereby) victory over his enemies), protection (from their violence) and for long life. 
Half of the income from the village was required to be used for the ayagara, eta, of the god Raiganátha, and the other half was meant for feeding sixty Vaishnavas. 
LI. 37 ff. An offering of six parivānas, together with a hundred and twenty apupa cakes, in a separate parivāna was to be offered daily (to the god Ranganatha). The scale of offerings fixed for each parivāna is :-rice, 10 mánakas.;a ghee, 3 mānakas; plantain fruits. 10 Gin namber); coconuts, 2 (in komber) ; green gram, kudupa, along with fruits and vegetables. 
The tämbüla consisted of 50 areca nuts, 100 betel leaves, chunan, ghanasāra (pachchai. karpüram) of 10 panas, and 2 panas of kastürt (musk). The sandal must consist of 6 palau of sandal, costing o panas, with 5 panas in value of kurkuma (-kösara) and ghanasära, kasturis (musk) of 3 panas, and of 3 panas of hima-jala (pannir). 
All these are to be offered to the god daily. 
LI. 47 ff. One mahopahāra (a grand feeding) should be performed in the month Phaltung and two others in the wronth of Dhanus; thus there abould be three mahopahāras in a year. 
Hindu widow: do not wear any ornament after the decease of their hosbands. 
Yanukalpata-manaka is idently a mana measure as determined by Manu; the same phrase oaxar alga inNO. 28.7 SRIRANGAM PLATES OF MALLIKARJUNA: SAKA-SAMVAT 1384. 353 
The articles required for each mahopahāra are 3-5 kharist of rice, i drönaka of green gram, 1 ādhaka of ghee, along with fruits and vegetables. 
The above are to be measured by māna and adhaka as fixed by Manu. 
LI. 53 #. The water-shed kept in front of the temple should always be full of water, and Levery day sixty Vaishnavas should be fed in the Rāmānuja-huta. 
V 38 The document was engraved by Virans, son of Muddan-achārya. He received one share in the village 
Vv. 39-43. Usual admonitory and imprecatory verses L. 84. The signature, Sri Virupaksha, of the king, written in Telugu-Kannada alphabet. 
No. 29.-TWO BANAWASI INSCRIPTIONS OF THE KADAMBA KIRTTIVARNA 
DEVA. 
BT LIONEL D. BARNETT 
18 
Banapõsi, formerly a seat of splendid royalty, and now a decared village, lies in the Sisi taluka of North Kanara District, in lat. 14° 32' and long. 75° 41' It still contains a temple of Madhukēsvara, the ancient tutelary deity of the Kādamba princes who once boie rule there; and in that building were found the two records which are here presented, from ink impressions which were prepared for the late Dr. Fleet, and are now in the British Museum. 
A.-OF THE REIGN OF SOMESVARA I: SAKA 990. This fragment is contained on a slab found in the Madhukēśvara temple. It has been briefly described by Dr. Fleet in Ind. Ant., Vol. IV, p. 206, No 3, and translated in Mysore Insor., p. 320, No 170 (cf. above, Vol. VII, App.. No 173). A transcript is given in the Ellot Collection (Royal Asiatic Society's copy, Vol. I, fol 106 b.). At the head of the stone are sculptures, viz., in the centre a linga; to the proper right, a cow and calf; over these, the sun; to the proper left of the linga, a lion; over the latter, the moon. The inscribed area below this is about 2 It. 1 in. wide and 4 ft. bigb; but a great part of it on the lower left side 
s been lost.--The obaracter is Kanarose of the period; the script is somewhat angular and slanting, with letters between in. and in.-The language is Old Kanarose, with the usual conclading formulæ in Sanskrit. 
The record opens by referring itself to the reign of Trailökyamalla-dēva, i.e Sömēsvara 1 (Il. . 1-3), and then states that at the time the Banavāsı Twelve-thousand was under the government of the Kadamba Mahamandalasvara Kirttivarma-döya, whose name is preluded by a long series of titles, among them being those of " lord of Banayini best of cities," " warrior for his elder brother," and "hon for Taila” (11 3-16). This Kirttivarman's exploita in the service of his father Tailay of whom we shall bear more in inscription B. Then comes the date (1l. 16-17), followed by fragments of twelve more linea of which it is impossible to make out much consecutive sense, except that they record a grant to the kalla dãyulada devar or “god of the Stone Temple." They conclude with the usual formulæ for the maintenance of the foundation, and the mention of grant to the stone cutter Malloja 
The meaning of the second part of the counpoand is not 
? Tho test actaslly uses the word partona-Aisudar. intelligible.

The date is giveu on 11 16-17 as. Saka 990, Kilaka, Chaitra suddha 13. This tithe corresponded to Wednesday, 19 March, A.D. 1088, when it ended about 14 h 2 m after mean sunrise 2 
The only places mentioned are the city of Bana väsi (1. 6) and the Bana vási Twelves thousand (11. 15-16).

TRANSLATION 
(Lines 1-3.) While-hail the favourite of Fortune and Earth, great Emperor, supreme Lord, supreme Master, embellishment of the Chālukyas, king Trailökyamalla, was reiguing over the earth - 
(Lines 3-16.) Hail! While the Mahānandalēśvara Kirttivarma-dēva, who possesses all titles of honour such as "a fiery sun in the sky of the Kadamba race, which is conspicuous by the puie sunce of the might of its lineage being established on the face of the massive summits of the great

No. 29.) BANAWASI INSCRIPTIONS OF THE KADAMBA KIRTTIVARMA-DETA. 355 
chwin 
owwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww 
Mount Himayat, which has the dignity of being the emperor of the whole group of central moun. tains; he whose two lotus-feet are rubbed by the diadems of hostile kings ; lord of Banavisi, beat of cities ; having the banner (with the device) of a great apo ; having for crest a lion attended by the noise of permatti drums ; sprung from the race which presides over eighty-four towns and is consecrated in eighteen world-famed horse-sacrifices to the god of the Frontal Eye [Siva] ; jewel-mine of truthfulness ; receiving the grace of boons from the goddess Ajjā; fragrant as the lotus, a Bhairava for opponent arrows; attended by peals of bells for victory in battle ; lion of the Kādanbas; warrior for his elder brother ; unencumbered by foes ; lion for Taila ; exalted in valiant enterprise ; adamant chamber to refuge-seekers ; shatterer of foemen's arogance ; a Sarvajña (?) among men of distinction ; unique man of valour in the world ; sun of the fray , Rudra with the attributes of a king ; lion of the Highlands; thrice gambler of warriors, was governing the Vanavāsi Twelve-thousand nder the shadow of his single parasol :~ 
(Lines 16-17) On the thirteenth day of the bright fortnight of Chaitra in the cyclic Year Kilaka, the 990th year) of the Saka era 
B.OF THE REIGN OF VIKRAMADITYA VI. This record was found on a stone in the south-eastern corner of the temple of Madhukāśvara, A transcript of the greater part, viz. lines 1 to 37, is given in the Elliot Collection (Vol. II, fol. 302 b. of the Royal Asiatic Society's copy), and the copyist there, after coming to the end of the paragraph on l. 37, has added untruthfully that the rest of the inscription is wanting. The inscribed area of the slab is 2 ft. 4 in. wide, and comprises two compartments : the upper one, containing lines 1-7, is 8] in high, and the lower one, containing the rest of the record, so far as it is preserved, is 3 ft. 8 in. high. The inscription is unfortunately incomplete, breaking off about the middle. The character is a very good Kanarese of the period : the letters in 11. 1-7 are from in to in. high, while those of 11. 8 ff. are from in. to 1 in high. The language is old Kanarese, except for the introductory Sanskrit stanza For the archaic is substituted i (balikkavæ, 1. 8, balikari, l. 9, negal', 11. 11, 16, 23, 39, 47 ; ēlu, l. 12; galaps, 1. 14; elo, 1. 14, alge, 11. 22, 40; pogal, ll 23, 43; pēl, 1. 40; nelalg=, 1. 42), and r (erppatt-, l. 12), on the other hand, ) is wrongly written for r in alaldu (1. 5) and kavaldu (1.9). Initial p has been changed to n in hadavala (1. 38), elsewhere it is preserved, e.g, in pada [va]la (1. 46). As to worda of lexical interest, we may note loñchu, 1. 41. 
The record, after the usual prelude Namas tungao, and a verse invoking blessings upon Kirttige, ie. the Kadamba Kirtti-deva of Hangul (11. 1-4), traces in three stanzas the descent of the Chāļukyas from the mind-born sons of Brahman (II. 4-7), and then devotes two verses (11. 8-11) to the glorification of the reigning Chăļukya monarch, Permā di-dēva or Vikramăditya. dēva (VI). It then turns, still in verge, to the history of his fendatories, the Kadambas of Hängal,s beginning with Ghattugs or Chatta, who received the title kafakada gova (" Guardian of the Highland” or “ of the Camp") from king Jayasinha (the Chălukya Jayasimha II) for his success in repelling the Mālvas and penetrating to the river Gautama-Gange (1.e. the Godavari; cf. above, Vol. IV, p. 358) (11. 11-16). Chatta's son was the valiant Jaya simba (11. 16-17), who had five sons, Māvuli, Taila or Tailapa, Santaya-dēva, Jöki-dēva, and Vikramanka (11. 17-21). Tailapa, who was extraordinarily brave, wise, and glorious, begot by Chívupdala-dovi, Kirtti (the game as the Kirttivarma dēva of the previous inscription), who is marvellously comely and famous (11, 21-28). Next comes a prose prasaati, giving the usual Kādamba titles of this same Kirtti-dâyaraba, and stating that at the time he was ruling the BanayĀue Twelve-thousand (il. 28-37). It is followed by five verses (11. 37-47), which dwell 
1 Sarvagña, meaning “ omniscient," is sometimes applied to Siva, the Jinas, and Buddha, 2 A metaphor signifying that he tossed the heads of enomies about like dice. * See Dynast. Kunar. Distr., p. 558 ff.

The only geographical names mentioned are the Gautam -Gange mer, i e., the Godavari, 1 14; Bonavāsı, 1 29, tlie Binavāse Twelve-thousand, 1, 36, the Sētu, 3 8. Adam's Bridge, 1 12, and Himayat, 1l 13, 31

TRANSLATION. (Verse 1.) Homage to Sambhu, lovely with the yak-tail fan that is the moon kissing his lofty head, who is the foundation-column of the city of the triple world 
(Verse 2.) May Mrda, the god giving blessing of glory, whose pair of lotus-feet is adored by kings of the celestials, whose inass of high hair-coil is adorned with Ganges' lofty breaking waves and the tremulous young moon, whose half-body is occupied by the Mountain's Daughter, grant fortune of fame and fortune of victory to thee, O Kirttiga. 
It is not clear whether the reading of the stone is sutta Ol fictti. 
? See note on translation, below. 8 kao Bahadur R Narasimhachar, who has kinuly favoared me with his views apon this verse, proposes to fill the gap at the end of l. 40 by reading durchchi and that between Il 42 and 43 by reading "balan=umte. In ny translation below I have accepted the forinor suggestion, but conjectarg for the second passage "balak autu (ot 
74, and trunslate accordingiz. 
No. 29.7 BANAWASI INSCRIPTIONS OF THE KADAMBA KIRTTIVARMA-DEVA. 359 
11 
2 
(Verse 3.) The lotus of his face is radiant in bloom, so that one may say: “What a surprising thing it is, when one considers ! a lotus-bed has blossomed forth in the midst of tha fiower of the golden lotus (issuing) from the radiant belly of Fortune's Lover!" 
(Verse 4.) In the mind of that God arose first that God himself), afterwards bringers of blessing, they who covered with radiant splendour the circle of space, seats of series of stainless Yirtues.” 
(Verse 5.) Many monarchs descended from these mind-born (Patriarchs), exalted in majesty, stainless jewel-lamps of the Chalukya race, anequalled, have ruled this earth. 
(Verse 6 ) After these (there has been a home of excellence, a mine of valour, a crest-jewel of monarchs, one delighting in bounty, a prince lustrous-white with heroism, Permā di-dēva, a dēla [god, or king] of the brave. 
(Verse ) Inasmuch as, after he has threatened and plundered unbending monarchs, the solid gold of their treasures), when piled together, becomes solidified into a Mountain of Gold, look you inasmuch as thereupon Jambi-dvipa has verily become a Golden Chersonese, alike to the suutor for riches and to the suitor who approves not richest king Vikramăditya, landed by the learned, has created for himself and sent abroad a mass of glory. 
(Verse 8.) While king Vikramaditya, thus renowned, was protecting the whole earth in the enjoyment of pleasant conversations, in the goodly Kadamba lineage which is praised by the folk of the earth 
(Verse 9) There was king Chattuga, an abode of greatness, a Meru of kings, exalted in the Kādamba race, among the sovereigns of the world beginning with the monarch who was a hhatrānga-club to kings, who, being sprung from the goddess Earth and Isvara, have borne sway for serenty-seven reigns over this earth here with its bounds at Setu (on the south) and there with Himayat (on the north). 
(Verse 10 ) Was the title “ Guardian of the Highland "5 an idle phrase, when the seven hosts were there? When he drove into fight the Malaya confronting him on the Highland and drank water in conspicuous wise from the Gautama-Gange, verily the title of * Guardian of the Highland" accrued to king Chatta in the camp of the sovereign Jayasimha? 
(Lane 16 ) (To him) who was thus renowned 
(Verse 11.) To this Méru of kings, in the same wise as is born on the ridge of Méru a lion, there was born the monarch Jayasımha, stout of arm, sbatterer of squadrons of foemen's elephants. 
(Line 17 ) (To the latter) who is thus descnbed. 
(Verse 12) To the lord of earth Jayasimha, as though power, ability, knowledge, greatness, (and) glory were born to him, there were born five august (sons), Māvuli, an ornament of kings, the monarch Taila, Santaya-dēva, Jökı-dēva, who delighted in the spint of battle, (and) Vikra mankendowed with present majesty, embodiments of authority, sincere, administering the seven elements of the state), lofty in generosity. 
* A poetical description of the god Brahman. The figure is urbhāvana, * peculiar causation" 
2 The meaning is that Brab man first meditated apon himself to create the cosmos (Manu-samnitām i. 12), and tlen gave birth to his mind-born sons the Patriarchs (ibig i 34 f.). 
3 Cf above, Vol. XIII, P 38. * These two classes are the seekers after material and spiritual happiness. # Kataka may mean both “highland" andı camp." * Apparontly the seven angas or divisions of a complete army. * On the grammatical construction of this senteoce cf. Kittel's Grammar, 361, p. 4*. 
The seven angas are the kingship, ministry, aliea, territories, fortressen, tronures, and arraies.

(Verse 13.) Looking with admiration at the five princes, men reflect, saying: “were the Five Papdayas (really) ten, or have the five of them now come back and been born (again)" 
(Line 21.) Among them 
(Verse 14.) King Tailapa attained to great majesty, so that his power, eminent amongat all the scions of the race of the moon-crowned (Siva), bis greatness, his striking vigour, his authori tative influence, the fulness of his invincible arm's might, his knowledge, his unique energy, his fame, were conspicuous in the circle of the earth. 
(Line 23.) (To him) who was thus a site and head of praise and renown 
(Verse 15.) To the valiant king Taila, awful in majesty, gallant against foes, and to Chāvundala-dēvi was born king Kírttı, who has unbroken glory for the victories of his arm. 
(Verse 16.) The Love-god, seeing the form of the Love-god of the Kadambas, has for sooth gone into hiding and lets not bis form become visible. Yon moon surely, as it shines, has waned and wasted away at the sight of him who is a moon of kings. Must not the Thousand eyed [Indra] be thousand-eyedi as he gazes (on him), saying: “Verily a Dēvēndra of princes ! and what a seat of virtues ! "? 
(Verse 17.) The fame of the king who is the unique Warrior of the world increases like the growth of all the lotuses that the waters produce, as all extol him to the utmost degree. 
(Lines 28-37.) Hall! When the Mahamandalēśvara possessing the five great musical sounds, the lord of Banavāsı best of cities, who bears all ti receives the grace of boons from the god Madhukēśvara of Jayanti; fragrant as the lotus ; scion of the race born of the) Three-eyed [Siva] and the Earth ; Love-god of kings; ornament of the race of the great king Mayuravarman, which presides over eighty-four towns and 18 consecrated in the consecratory rites of eighteen world-famed horse-sacrifices to the god of) the Frontal Eye [Sıva] and the Four-armed [Vishņu), which is regarded with the sidelong glances of the lady Victory, which is splendid in virtues revealed by the puissance of the might of its lineage being established on the massive suminuts of the great Mount Himavat, which is charming by the great majesty of furious elephants tethered to crystal columns ;' who is an ornament to the race (born of) the great king Mayūravarmma ; he who is attended with the noise of permattu drums and (other) musical instruments, splendid with the banner (bearing the device) of a great ape ; having for crest a lion lofty in pride; giving unlimited gold to suitors; ornament of the Kadamba race; cause of victory in battle; sun of majesty ; terrible in the fray, gallant against adversaries, unique warrior of the world,” the Dahāmandalesvara Kirtti-dávarasa, was protecting the Banavāse Twelve thousand so as to suppress the wicked and preserve the cultured one who finds sustenanse at his lotus-feet 
[Verse 18.) A lord of Fortune, a lord of the fortune of victory, a lord of the fortune of fame lustrous (?) as the moon, devoted to the exeroise of religion, 15 the Ulustrious Kirtti. a diamond among bearers of the betel-bag. 
(Verse 19.) Saying, “Where now is there not found one who has been burned up in flight ?" as the fire of his wrath flaming wreaks ruin-saying, “whom now has he hurled into Yama'a mouth, so that the black gore drips down; whom now has he cast away . . in
